answer: As flood risk management now falls within my portfolio, I met with Natural Resources Wales (NRW) together with officials on 11 December, to discuss the Roath Flood Alleviation Scheme.  This meeting came in light of concerns expressed by a number of people in the area.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: When will a final decision be made on the start date for construction work on the Caernarfon and Bontnewydd bypass project?
answer: Following the Public Local Inquiry, the Inspector’s Report was received on 18 October. We are currently considering the Inspector’s findings, recommendations and all issues raised before making a final decision on the scheme.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish a list of every advisory board and body that was abolished following the publication of the economic action plan?
answer: As part of the review of advisory bodies in my portfolio, discussions have taken place with chairs and members of a range of groups including Sector Panels and Enterprise Zone Boards. These are ongoing and will result in a number of groups either drawing to a close, undergoing transition to new forms or continuing according to the outcomes of the review. A number of groups including Sector Panels, will be replaced by an overarching Ministerial Advisory Board, which will be a tight, focussed group of individuals, providing strategic advice on economic development. I will be making further announcements on this and the broader advisory structure that will support it early in 2018.

name: Adam Price
response_name: First Minister
question: Does the First Minister have ministerial responsibility for the management and behaviour of special advisors, including their discipline?
answer: Special Advisers are civil servants, therefore routine line management is a matter for the Permanent Secretary. However, I am responsible for other aspects of their management including conduct and discipline.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary list any economic research that was used or commissioned when choosing the thematic sectors mentioned in the economic action plan?
answer: We have considered evidence from a range of sources including published research reports and statistics, internal management information and the views of social partners and others.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the role of the construction industry as a key sector to the economic wellbeing of Wales and state why it is not mentioned in the new Economic Action Plan?
answer: I recognise that construction makes a critically important contribution to the Welsh economy, sustaining as it does some 13,000 businesses and employing around 112,000 individuals across Wales.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What quantitative targets does the Welsh Government intend to use in assessing progress towards achieving the objectives of the economic action plan?
answer: The objectives in the Economic Action Plan are taken from the Prosperity for All national strategy and they also form part of the well-being objectives against which we will report annually. We will use existing systems, business planning, evidence and evaluation to monitor progress in meeting these objectives.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What role will the Welsh Industrial Development Advisory Board play in the implementation of the Welsh Government's new economic contract with businesses seeking investment?
answer: The Welsh Industrial Development Advisory Board (WIDAB) plays an important advisory role in terms of individual applications for business finance where the financial support sought is significant.  The experience, knowledge and expertise of WIDAB adds value to our process and it will continue to have a role in applications for business finance.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Does the Cabinet Secretary intend to publish further details about the calls to action that were published as part of the economic action plan?
answer: We will be discussing the calls to action and their implementation with social partners and others over the next few weeks.  As part of that process, we will consider any further information or guidance necessary to help facilitate delivery against the Calls to Action.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Where does the Cabinet Secretary believe that the balance should be struck between grants and repayable money in the support currently offered to businesses?
answer: In the Plan, we make it clear we will maintain a competitive financial offer to business and that means a mix of grants and repayable forms of finance such as loans.  We further make it clear the balance between repayable and non-repayable forms of finance should reflect the economic cycle.  We are not going to set an arbitrary target because we must have the flexibility to adjust our approach to suit the economic and business needs of the time.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Does the Welsh Government have a target for the percentage of the £6 million that is spent every year by the public sector in Wales that would like to be won by Welsh copmanies?
answer: Companies in Wales now win around 50% of the total £6bn public procurement expenditure and we will engage with business and others to identify opportunities to increase this further.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders

question: What steps is the Welsh Government taking to ban the use of wild animals in circuses?
answer: I recently consulted on the introduction of a licensing or registration scheme for Mobile Animal Exhibits (MAEs), including circuses.  The consultation also sought views on whether a ban on the use of wild animals in circuses should be considered.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What steps is the Cabinet Secretary taking to end the tethering of horses on roadsides and grass verges?
answer: The Welsh Government introduced the Control of Horses (Wales) Act 2014 at the request of enforcement authorities, commoners and welfare charities. The Act provides further powers for Local Authorities to combat the abandonment of horses and ponies found grazing on land where the owner of the animals does not have the consent of the land owner.

The Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee and Health Technology Wales commissioned reviews on cross linking for treating keratoconus in children and adults and their findings are due to be published in March 2018.

name: Simon Thomas

The Government will bring forward proposals in due course.

name: Mark Isherwood

Following the news that D Jones & Son has ceased trading on Saturday 16 December 2017, my officials held a teleconference on 19 December with representatives of Wrexham and Denbighshire Councils to help put in place measures to safeguard key local bus services previously provided by D Jones and Son.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth

question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update concerning the Welsh Government’s Information for People Programme?

The Group’s core objective was to help shape current and future work on information provision, both online and through more traditional formats, to ensure it is accessible to a wide variety of users.

question: What are the core objectives and priorities of the information for people programme?
answer: The “Information for People” Working Group was established to enable policy colleagues and key stakeholders to engage on ways to improve supply and distribution of health and care information. The Group’s core objective was to help shape current and future work on information provision, both online and through more traditional formats, to ensure it is accessible to a wide variety of users.

response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

answer: The recommendations of the Ministerial Task and Finish Group are being taken forward by the Endoscopy Implementation Group, representing all health boards in Wales and with links to Bowel Screening Wales. It was recognised in the initial recommendations that achieving Joint Advisory Group (JAG) accreditation for all units in Wales would be challenging given the environmental and capacity constraints, however, health boards continue to make progress towards achieving accreditation.

answer: The health boards are due to submit their Integrated Medium Term Plans (IMTPs) for 2018 - 2021 on 31st January 2018.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Does the Welsh Government/Openreach broadband contract stipulate completion of service availability by the end of December 2017 for Newcastle, Monmouthshire and, if not, what does it say on this matter?
answer: The Superfast Cymru grant agreement does not stipulate delivery to specific towns, cities or postal districts but requires BT to deliver specific premises volumes on a pan-Wales basis. It is a matter for Openreach to plan and build to achieve those outcomes, and to subsequently evidence the eligible spend that will secure the grant award from Welsh Government.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Does the Welsh Government/Openreach broadband contract contain penalty clauses for non-delivery?
answer: The grant agreement includes penalty clauses for non delivery.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Does the Welsh Government have adequate and effective monitoring and enforcement in place to ensure delivery of the Welsh Government/Openreach broadband contract in Newcastle, Monmouthshire?
answer: Welsh Ministers are ultimately responsible for the delivery of the pan-Wales Superfast Cymru grant agreement. The programme is overseen on a day to day basis by Welsh Government officials within recognised project governance structures. The programme is subject to audits from the Wales Audit Office and the European Union.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: What are the current plans and confirmed dates for the delivery of superfast broadband to Newcastle, Monmouthshire, and is it likely to be Fibre to the Premises?
answer: Openreach plans and delivers on a broadband structure by broadband structure basis rather than on a town, local authority or postcode district basis.  As such without specific postal addresses it is impossible to provide meaningful information for the delivery of fast-fibre connectivity to the Newcastle, Monmouthshire, NP25 area.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Have there been any changes to the decision regarding what superfast broadband service to deliver (and by when) to Newcastle, Monmouthshire, by whom has that decision been made and what were the criteria used?
answer: Openreach plans and delivers on the basis of broadband structures, rather than by town, local authority or postcode.. Without specific postal address information it is impossible to provide meaningful information for the delivery of fast-fibre connectivity to Newcastle, Monmouthshire, NP25 area.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What were the total costs associated with the researching and writing of the Prosperity for All: Economic Action Plan document?
answer: The researching and writing of the Economic Action Plan has been undertaken by Officials in the normal course of business and at no additional cost incurred other than for printing the document.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: How many copies of the Prosperity for All: Economic Action Plan document have been printed and what was the total cost of that printing?
answer: 1,050 copies of the Economic Action Plan have been printed at a total cost of £5,785.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What meetings were held with Welsh businesses during the process of researching and writing the Prosperity for All: Economic Action Plan document?
answer: I have had a range of meetings with businesses, representative bodies and others and I have listened to feedback from the business community.  I have also utilised our existing stakeholder groups, including the Council for Economic Development and Social Partners Strategy Group.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Does the Welsh Government have any intentions to encourage the Welsh Ambulance Service to use the GoodSAM app to notify nearby medically qualified responders of a medical emergency?
answer: While the Welsh Government is supportive of the use of innovative technology to support health and care services, it is for NHS Wales organisations to determine and commission the products and services they feel necessary to improve patient outcomes, experience and value for money.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the Welsh Government plans to introduce an earnings threshold through universal credit for eligibility to receive free school meals?
answer: We are currently considering various options to ensure that Free School Meals (FSM) are targeted at those most in need; including  the introduction of an earned income threshold for recipients of Universal Credit (UC). We will be consulting on this in the Spring term

name: Adam Price
response_name: First Minister
question: Was a complaint received from Leighton Andrews in November 2014 that a member of staff had breached the special advisers' code?
answer: I recall no such complaint.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Has the Welsh Government estimated the percentage of small businesses that will benefit from small business rate relief during 2018/19?
answer: All small businesses will be eligible for relief through the Small Business Rates Relief scheme operating in 2018-19. Around 70% of all ratepayers in Wales will be eligible for some form of support to reduce their rates bills. The Small Business Rates Relief scheme will offer relief on up to two properties per ratepayer in each local authority area where the property is occupied for business purposes and has a rateable value of up to £12,000. Enhanced relief will be available on property with a rateable value of up to £20,500 where the property is occupied for the purposes of providing childcare.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the implications for the Monmouth constituency of a cut in funding for 2018-2019 in the Substance Misuse Action Fund?
answer: The final budget for 2018/19 protects the support we provide to frontline substance misuse treatment services, with the revenue budget allocations to Area Planning Boards (APBs) maintained at £22.663m. We will also be increasing the ring-fenced substance misuse funding for health boards by nearly a million pounds, to over £18 million from 2018-19.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that the only substance misuse centre in Monmouthshire, in Chepstow, will remain open despite a reduction in funding for the Substance Misuse Action Fund?
answer: The final budget for 2018/19 protects the support we provide to frontline substance misuse treatment services, with the revenue budget allocations to Area Planning Boards (APBs)  maintained at £22.663m. We will also be increasing the ring-fenced substance misuse funding for health boards by nearly a million pounds, to over £18 million from 2018-19.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What is the Cabinet Secretary's approach to tackling substance misuse in the South Wales East region?
answer: The Welsh Government’s approach to tackling substance misuse, not only in the South Wales East region but across all of Wales, is based on the core principle of harm reduction. We are committed to tackling the devastating effects of substance misuse on individuals and in our communities. Our latest Substance Misuse Delivery Plan (2016-18) sets out the detailed actions we and our partners are taking to deliver on the Welsh Government’s 10 year substance misuse strategy, “Working Together to Reduce Harm”.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ75426, relating to support currently offered to businesses, will the Cabinet Secretary state what the source for this estimate is and will the Welsh Govrnment be willing to update this figure annually to assess progress?
answer: We utilise a spend analysis tool called Atamis for Welsh public sector spend data.  We intend to update the figure on a regular basis, the frequency of which will be determined by the procurement review that is currently underway, as announced by the Cabinet Secretary for Finance on 21st September 2017.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide a list of all organisations invited to attend political or normal Welsh Government cabinet meetings since the start of the Fifth Assembly; and a list of all external organisations who declined invitations to attend such meetings?
answer: The Chair of the Parliamentary Review of Health and Social Care in Wales attended Cabinet on 16th May and 4th July 2017 and representatives of the Wales TUC attended Cabinet on 10th October 2017.  Further information can be found on the Government’s website

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary clarify whether the pay and conditions of supply teachers will be within the remit of the Independent Task and Finish Group review, Teachers’ Pay and Conditions in Wales?
answer: The statutory requirements for school teachers’ pay and conditions for maintained schools in Wales and England are set out in the School Teachers’ Pay and Conditions Document.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary clarify whether the pay and conditions of teaching assistants will be within the remit of the Independent Task and Finish Group review, Teachers’ Pay and Conditions in Wales?
answer: The statutory requirements for school teachers’ pay and conditions for maintained schools in Wales and England are set out in the School Teachers’ Pay and Conditions Document.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary clarify whether the teaching profession’s workload will be considered within the remit of the Independent Task and Finish Group review Teachers’ Pay and Conditions in Wales?
answer: The statutory requirements for school teachers’ pay and conditions for maintained schools in Wales and England are set out in the School Teachers’ Pay and Conditions Document.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what wildlife surveys were carried out by the Welsh Government in relation to the proposed Northern Access Road prior to planning applications being submitted to the Vale of Glamorgan Council?
answer: A full range of ecological surveys were carried out to provide information on potential constraints and opportunities, and to determine the requirements for mitigation and enhancement to support the application for full planning permission to construct the new Northern Access Road.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that there are no risks to habitat destruction as a result of plans to build the Northern Access Road to the Aerospace Business Park in St Athan?
answer: A full range of ecological surveys were carried out to provide information on potential constraints and opportunities, and to determine the requirements for mitigation and enhancement to support the application for full planning permission to construct the new Northern Access Road.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether any wild species are at risk from proposals to build the Northern Access Road to the Aerospace Business Park in St Athan, and if so, when was the Cabinet Secretary made aware of those risks?
answer: A full range of ecological surveys were carried out to provide information on potential constraints and opportunities, and to determine the requirements for mitigation and enhancement to support the application for full planning permission to construct the new Northern Access Road.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Given that the Cabinet Secretary is responsible for developing the agri-food sector, associated supply chains, promotion and marketing of food and drink from Wales, will the Cabinet Secretary explain why there is no corresponding duty for the promotion and marketing of forest products and the forestry sector?
answer: The Forestry Act 1967 creates a duty to promote the interests of forestry and the production and supply of timber and forest products. This duty is conferred on Natural Resources Wales (NRW) and NRW has a range of functions and powers under the Act to deliver this duty and support Welsh forestry.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how much Natural Resources Wales and/or the Welsh Government spend on the promotion and marketing of forest products and the forestry sector?
answer: As stated in WAQ75515, Natural Resources Wales (NRW) is responsible for the promotion of forestry in Wales. They promote and provide access to forest products and facilities for a wide range of users, from the marketing of timber supplies to the many recreational activities across the woodland estate which are funded out of their own budget.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: In light of the recently announced £1.5 million funding for Hybu Cig Cymru to deliver an enhanced export development programme to support the red meat industry in Wales over the next three years, will the Cabinet Secretary commit to provide a similar amount to support the woodlands and forestry sector?
answer: Welsh Government provides support through the Timber Business Investment Scheme within Rural Communities Rural Development Programme. The great majority of forestry products are marketed and sold within the UK and are well placed to serve these markets as the UK leaves the EU. As the UK is a significant net importer of forestry products, it is important to look at domestic marketing opportunities and I will be looking at support for forestry as part of the design of sustainable land management proposals which will eventually replace the current CAP.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of how the combination of a presumption in favour of tree planting as the default position of Natural Resources and a possible step-change in the efficiency of the regulatory process could result in a greater area of woodlands and forests in Wales?
answer: Forestry is one of my top priorities and I am exploring policy options for encouraging new planting. The Taking Forward Wales’ Sustainable Management of Natural Resources consultation sought views on amending Natural Resources Wales’s general duties under the Forestry Act 1967 to align more fully with the sustainable management of natural resources to maximise the multiple benefits our forests provide. The responses to this are currently being analysed and further proposals will be developed once the analysis has been completed.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: How will the Cabinet Secretary protect the productive potential of the Welsh Government woodland estate, in line with the central objectives of the Woodlands for Wales strategy?
answer: Natural Resources Wales (NRW) are the managers of the Welsh Government woodland estate and the Woodlands for Wales strategy is currently being refreshed. NRW will be inputting into this process and the productive potential of the estate will be examined as part of the refresh.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: How much has been spent on capital funding for active travel in each of the last ten years and what does each figure represent as a percentage of that year’s capital spend on transport as a whole?
answer: We are currently reviewing the funding model including historical spend and future need.  I will write to you separately once the information is available.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: How will the Cabinet Secretary ensure that consideration of active travel provision is made integral to any guidance issued in relation to the 21st Century Schools Programme before any further investment takes place?
answer: The business case guidance for the 21st Century Schools and Education Programme has been amended to make consideration of how learners travel to school a core part of the business case development process. Workshops with local education authority officers were held in 2017 to familiarise them with the new guidance, which will be published this Spring.

name: Adam Price
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister confirm, in line with his statement to the BBC on 7 April 2017, that the guarantee requested by the Heads of the Valleys Development Company for the Circuit of Wales project, originally set at £30 million, increased to £357 million in the last few days of the process?
answer: I believe the BBC interview to which you refer was on 7 April 2016. As the Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport set out in his response to WAQ73771, the level of Welsh Government support being sought by Heads of the Valleys Development Company changed significantly in the lead up to the Ministerial decision on 6 April 2016. Between August 2015 and March 2016 a range of funding options for the Circuit of Wales project were explored between the developers, local authorities and Welsh Government officials. Following those exploratory discussions, what emerged during March 2016 was a proposal that required a 100% Welsh Government guarantee of the £357million investment. I can confirm that this proposal was set out for Ministers in formal advice submitted on 5 April 2016.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Is it the Welsh Government's policy to market Wales as a principality?
answer: Cabinet recently agreed, and the Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport recently published, Prosperity for All: Economic Action Plan (EAP) which outlines a comprehensive, cross-government approach to branding, marketing and promoting Wales over the next few years as a proud nation through:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the impact of flooding on the Conwy Valley Railway Line, and explain what measures the Welsh Government are taking to ensure the line's long term viability?
answer: I recognise the impact that recent flooding has had on the line, with closures caused directly by flooding and related damage. I also note the importance of the provision of a good quality, well publicised and signposted rail replacement bus service when the line is shut. There is a need for Network Rail Wales Route to work to deliver greater resilience on the line, but I am also grateful for the hard work they continue to put in to re-open the line following flooding.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the importance of the Conwy Valley Railway Line to the tourism industry of North Wales, and explain what plans the Welsh Government have to further promote this link between the sea and mountains?
answer: The Conwy Valley Railway plays an important role in enabling visitors to enjoy the landscape and the growing number of visitor destinations along the Conwy Valley including, for example, Zipworld’s attractions at Betws y Coed and Blaenau Ffestiniog, and Surf Snowdonia at Dolgarrog. The Conwy Valley line runs between North Wales’ coast and the heart of Snowdonia, and traces the banks of the river Lledr, and is therefore a good example of an area that can and does capitalise on its links between Wales’ beautiful countryside and coastline.

name: Adam Price
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide details of every complaint made last year that he misled the Assembly under the Ministerial Code, including the identity of the complainant, the nature of the allegation, and the reason for the ruling in each case?
answer: There were three such complaints. The first two complaints were made by you and I responded on 18th July 2017 and 3 August 2017. The third complaint was made by another Assembly Member and concerned the Cardiff LDP, lobbying and RIFW - I concluded there was no breach of the Ministerial Code and responded accordingly.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Welsh Government explore shared apprenticeships across the hospitality, retail and tourism sectors so that small businesses can take advantage of the offer?
answer: Our current commitment is to continue to support our existing Shared Apprenticeship initiatives across Wales in the Construction and Engineering sectors.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why the Welsh Government is withdrawing all funding from Governors Wales?
answer: Governors Wales provide services such as an advice helpline, website with publications, self evaluation documents and a national conference for governors.  However, much of what the organisation currently delivers is duplicated across the sector and the overwhelming majority of governors use other means to access support and advice.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How will the functions of Governors Wales be undertaken in 2018/19 following the withdrawal of Welsh Government funding?
answer: Please see the response for WAQ75528 which stated that much of the services that are provided by Governors Wales are duplicated across the sector and that the overwhelming majority of governors use other means of support.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How will the Welsh Government help ensure that school governors play an active role in holding schools and school leaders to account?
answer: The Education (Wales) Measure 2011 includes provisions to allow the Welsh Ministers to make regulations to make governor training mandatory on specific issues. The Government of Maintained Schools (Training Requirements for Governors) (Wales) Regulations 2013 have been made for this purpose.

name: Suzy Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following the Cabinet Secretary's response to WAQ75441, could it be confirmed whether the loan provided, by Welsh Government, for Swansea Bay Tidal Lagon (a) was secured, (b) was conditional on anything, and (c) has been activated yet and if so when?
answer: The unconditional secured commercial loan was drawn down by Tidal Lagoon (Swansea Bay) Plc in February 2015.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What progress has the Welsh Government made in investigating allegations of fraud levelled against Kukd.com?
answer: The investigation is proceeding.  Any further comment may prejudice the situation.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a timescale for the publication of a report into the allegations of fraud levelled against Kukd.com?
answer: The investigation is proceeding.  Any further comment may prejudice the situation.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: If found guilty of fraud, will Kukd.com be required to repay back the full sum of its Welsh Government grant?
answer: The investigation is proceeding.  Any further comment may prejudice the situation.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary agree to a full postponement of all works for tree felling scheduled in Roath Brook Gardens, Waterloo Gardens and Roath Mill Gardens, scheduled to recommence on 8 January 2018, in light of a complaint being investigated by the Public Services Ombudsman for Wales?
answer: I met with NRW in December to hear the case for the scheme and met them again on 9 January with you and elected representatives. NRW are continuing dialogue with residents and attempting to reach a positive resolution in order for the scheme to go ahead

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that all legal requirements and obligations set out in the Environment (Wales) Act 2016 and the Well-being of Future Generations (Wales) Act 2015 were complied with before permission was granted for tree felling to take place in Roath Brook Gardens?
answer: NRW are the scheme promoter and they have assured me that all legal requirements, permits and permissions are being complied with.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm why flood risk priority was given to 60 homes in the Penylan area of Cardiff, a medium risk flood area, when there are other areas nearby that are far greater exposed to flood risk with no remedial works having been carried out?
answer: NRW is the relevant risk management authority for flood risk from main rivers and the sea. They brought forward the case for alleviation work to better protect 360 homes and 45 businesses, presently at medium and high flood risk.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the Welsh Government considers the findings of wildlife studies important in determining planning applications for flood prevention works and, if so, whether these should be taken into account when deciding if such works should take place?
answer: It is of course important for all relevant and validated information to be taken into account by the local planning authority in determining planning applications. They will consider all the statutory appraisals and decide what weight to attach to other studies if deemed material considerations.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm if trees scheduled to be planted to replace those felled in Roath Brook Gardens will be of at least equal or greater size than those already cut down or planned to be cut down?
answer: The trees being replanted will be mature, not saplings. Some will not be as large as those being cut down. The replacement trees in the park gardens will be 3m to 5m tall.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what alternative measures were considered to alleviate flood risk in the Penylan area of Cardiff before those set out in phase three of the Roath Brook Flood Scheme were agreed?
answer: NRW completed a thorough appraisal of flood risk management options to ensure a rigorous approach which considered all potential options and would support the selection of the preferred option, given the sensitive amenity value of the area and public interest in the park gardens. NRW identified a long list of options through an options workshop involving project team members.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: In light of considerable evidence that has emerged deeming tree felling in Roath Brook Gardens to be unnecessary, will the Cabinet Secretary reconsider the decision not to meet with local residents concerned by the impacts of the works?
answer: I met with elected representatives on Tuesday 9 January. As you will know, from the explanation of the scheme given by NRW at the meeting, the tree felling forms a key part of the works. However, NRW have continued discussions with residents, meeting again on Monday 15th January, and have agreed to look at the possibility of saving additional trees without compromising the level of protection required for the community.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm if the area surrounding Roath Brook Gardens, particularly around Westville Road, has ever flooded?
answer: NRW have confirmed that the properties bordering Roath Brook Gardens have not suffered internal flooding. However, there has been repeated flooding nearby alongside Waterloo and Railway Gardens. Modelling indicates the scheme is necessary to mitigate present and future flood risk to properties throughout the area.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How is the Welsh Government is dealing with this year’s winter flu, including Australian ‘flu?
answer: “Australian flu” is being used in the media to refer to the  influenza viruses that circulated during the recent season in Australia.  It is not a clinical term referring to a specific virus type. The influenza viruses experienced in Australia were not new virus types and were similar to those reported elsewhere during 2017.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many cases of Australian flu were reported in Wales between 1 January 2017 and 3 January 2018?
answer: “Australian flu” is being used in the media to refer to the  influenza viruses that circulated during the recent season in Australia.  It is not a clinical term referring to a specific virus type. The influenza viruses experienced in Australia were not new virus types and were similar to those reported elsewhere during 2017.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: For 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18 to date, how many working days were lost to staff sickness within GwE?
answer: The Welsh Government does not hold Information regarding staff sickness in the regional education consortia. I would refer you to GwE for this information.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the staffing structure of GwE and advise how many full-time equivalent employees it has currently?
answer: The Welsh Government does not hold information on the staffing structure or the number for full-time equivalent employees for the regional education consortia. I would refer you to GwE consortium for this specific information.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary undertaken as regards the effectiveness of Community Mental Health Teams in Wales, and how does he intend to improve clarity and transparency of their working structures and lines of accountability to help improve service user outcomes?
answer: Over the past year, the NHS Delivery Unit has been working closely with Community Mental Health Teams (CMHTs) across Wales to assess and support care planning processes, to ensure holistic approaches which achieve goal-based outcomes identified by service users. The findings of this work will help inform continued improvements to services.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary working with Health Boards, Community Mental Health Teams, other Social Services teams, and in communities to help reduce rates of suicide amongst adult males?
answer: ‘Talk to Me 2’, our strategy to prevent suicide and self-harm, sets out the aims and objectives to prevent and reduce suicide and self-harm in Wales over the period 2015-2020. It identifies priority care providers to deliver action in certain priority places to the benefit of key priority people, at a national, regional and local level.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: In line with recommendation 8 of the 'Branching Out' report, will the Cabinet Secretary commit to expanding the productive potential of the Welsh Government Woodland Estate instead of allowing it to decline?
answer: As I stated in my address at the Committee Plenary debate on 13 December, I am making forestry one of my top priorities. We want to increase the productive potential of all woodland in Wales as well as the Welsh Government woodland estate therefore we are looking at ways to ensure its value increases over time (including through restocking).

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: What plans does the Cabinet Secretary have to support the wood processing sector by facilitating woodland and forestry creation, in particular to replace the productive conifer areas already lost?
answer: As stated in WAQ75551, we will continue to work with stakeholders and examine ways in which we can support forestry as part of the design of sustainable land management proposals which will eventually replace the current CAP.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: With the UK now the second largest timber-importing country in the world, does the Cabinet Secretary aspire for Wales to become a net exporter of high quality timber and wood products to England and beyond?
answer: As stated in WAQ75517, I will be examining support for forestry as part of the design of sustainable land management proposals which will eventually replace the current CAP. I look forward to working with stakeholders in order to seek their input in this respect, particularly on how to encourage investment in long-term woodland management and creation, as well as adaptation and innovation proposals for new opportunities which support forestry post Brexit.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a full list of projects supported under previous rounds of the Timber Business Investment Scheme?
answer: The table below provides details of projects approved up to 31 December 2017. Approved projects for all schemes are published quarterly by the Rural Network on the Welsh Government internet. Document Downloads at the bottom of the page and can be found at the following link:

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how the Welsh Government will be paying due regard to the welfare needs of animals as sentient beings in formulating and implementing Welsh Government policy?
answer: One of the strategic outcomes within the Wales Animal Health and Welfare Framework Implementation Plan is “Animals in Wales have a good quality of life”. Our position on sentience is clear. We fully agree animals are sentient beings and we will continue to promote and enhance animal welfare, both now and after we have left the EU.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Welsh Government be putting forward a LCM for the Animal Welfare (Sentencing and Recognition of Sentience) Bill to determine the Assembly's support for it?
answer: It is my intention to put forward a Legislative Consent Motion for those aspects of the Animal Welfare (Sentencing and Recognition of Sentience) Bill which apply to Wales.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what factors were taken into account when determing the necessity of the flood defence schemes at Roath Mill Gardens and Waterloo Gardens?
answer: The flood programme is prioritised according to flood risk. NRW is the responsible authority for managing risk from main rivers and the sea and the case for alleviation work along Roath Brook watercourse came through NRWs programme board as a priority scheme, taking into account historic flooding and near-misses, detailed flood models and the Communities at Risk Register.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether dredging has ever been considered as an option to combat potential flooding at Roath Mill Gardens, Roath Brook Gardens and Waterloo Gardens?
answer: NRW considered dredging and raising levels at Roath Park Lake. These options were discounted due to the additional works required at the lake and their potential detrimental impact. Deepening the channel also has negligible effect on tidal flood risk at Waterloo and Railway Gardens.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether in Wales there exists an equivalent body to the National Emergency Pressures Panel in England and, if there is no Wales equivalent body, will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what is the executive decision-making body for alleviating winter pressures?
answer: Local health boards are responsible for planning and delivering services to meet winter pressures.  We have robust and long standing arrangements in place to manage operational challenges when pressures are at their peak.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how much the Welsh Government has spent on legal advice and action in respect of activities around the Regeneration Investment Fund for Wales land disposal since November 2015 and state which legal firm has been selected to undertake this work?
answer: Whilst litigation is ongoing it could be prejudicial to disclose information on costs. Geldards and Blake Morgan are acting on behalf of RIFW in respect to different aspects of the LLP’s interests.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what monies have been paid to the Welsh Government/the Regeneration Investment Fund for Wales in relation to clawback from South Wales Land Developments Ltd since November 2015?
answer: To date £5,031,132.44 has been received, in respect to overage payments, from South Wales Development Limited. Additional payments are expected in the future.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the progress of any legal action being pursued by Welsh Government against Lambert Smith Hampton around the disposal of land to South Wales Land Developments Ltd?
answer: Legal action with regard to the contractors involved in the Regeneration Investment Fund for Wales is being pursued. I expect to make a statement on progress shortly.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide a list of those invited to the First Minister's Christmas drinks for the media and provide a list of those who attended the event?
answer: Representatives from BBC (Wales and UK); ITV (Wales and UK) Media Wales/Trinity Mirror; Global/Heart FM; Channel 4, South Wales Argus, Guardian; Sky; Press Association; Golwg; Metro and selected freelance journalists were invited. Approximately 20 journalists from the above outlets attended the event.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister confirm who paid for his Christmas drinks reception for the media and also state the total cost of that reception?
answer: Representatives from BBC (Wales and UK); ITV (Wales and UK) Media Wales/Trinity Mirror; Global/Heart FM; Channel 4, South Wales Argus, Guardian; Sky; Press Association; Golwg; Metro and selected freelance journalists were invited. Approximately 20 journalists from the above outlets attended the event.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Minister for Children and Social Care
question: Where has the funding previously provided via the Children and Families Organisation Grant - and then the Children and Families Delivery Grant between October 2014 and September 2017 - now been allocated?
answer: The Children and Families Delivery Grant (CFDG), which provided funding for a suite of projects to support families and children ended in September 2017.  The CFDG was not designed to be a long term funding stream intended to support particular organisations or policy areas and was limited in duration to 3 years, with any future iterations of the grant intended to evolve so as to support changing Government priorities.

name: Russell George
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: What assessment has the Welsh Government made of the impact on local authorities in Wales following China's ban on plastic waste imports?
answer: WRAP Cymru, the Waste and Resources Action Programme, has been in contact with Local Authorities in Wales at our request and report Welsh Local Authorities are resilient in respect of the impacts of the Chinese National Sword. WRAP has collated information about where Welsh Local Authority collected plastics go – and almost none are currently exported directly from Wales to China. We are waiting for a further survey of Local Authorities being done through the Welsh Local Government Association (WLGA) but do not expect direct problems in relation to National Sword. There will be indirect impacts including commodity price fluctuations but these are influenced by numerous factors.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the policing of fishing licenses issued to commercial fishing vessels, and explain how regular compliance checks are undertaken?
answer: Working within the rules of UK Restrictive Licensing Scheme, there are currently 421 commercially licensed fishing vessels administered by the Welsh Government.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the fact that porpoise are being washed dead ashore in north Wales, and explain what measures the Welsh Government is taking to stop such deaths?
answer: Cetaceans – porpoises, dolphins and whales – wash up, or strand, around the Welsh coast throughout the year. Animals which strand alive are returned to the sea where possible. Occasionally some animals are euthanized on welfare grounds following veterinary assessment.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the threat fishing nets can pose to fish and sea mammals, and explain what action the Welsh Government is taking to reduce bycatch?
answer: EC Council Regulation No. 812/2004, which came into force on 1 July 2004, introduced measures to reduce incidental catches by fishing vessels of whales, dolphins and porpoises.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the fact that only 48.8 per cent of patients spent fewer than four hours in A&E at Ysbyty Glan Clwyd between the mornings of 1 and 2 January 2018, and what steps will the Welsh Government take to help health boards deal with A&E pressures?
answer: The member will be aware that hospital sites across Wales have experienced significant pressures in recent weeks.  These pressures have not only been experienced at the front door, but throughout the hospital which have, unfortunately, resulted in some patients spending longer in emergency departments that we would hope.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What steps is the Cabinet Secretary taking to improve treatment of sleep apnoea across Wales?
answer: The NHS in Wales produced a strategy document in 2010 to support the more equitable provision of sleep services. The 2014 Respiratory Health Delivery Plan also included commitments on the development of sleep services, which can be found at:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many sleep specialists are employed by each health board in Wales?
answer: The NHS in Wales produced a strategy document in 2010 to support the more equitable provision of sleep services. The 2014 Respiratory Health Delivery Plan also included commitments on the development of sleep services, which can be found at:

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish his ministerial diary for the week commencing Monday 1 January, including a daily breakdown of commitments?
answer: I had planned to visit Cwm Taf University Health Board as part of a series of visits over winter, but given the winter pressures, and at a request of the Health Board, these were postponed to later in January, to enable it to focus on the increase in demand. Details of my diary will be published as usual on the Welsh Government’s website. The next quarterly publication covering January is scheduled for publication in early April.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish an annual breakdown of Welsh NHS bed numbers from 1999 to present?
answer: This information is already published on an annual basis and is available at: https://statswales.gov.wales/Catalogue/Health-and-Social-Care/NHS-Hospital-Activity/NHS-Beds/nhsbedssummarydata-by-year

name: Suzy Davies

answer: The Welsh Ministers have freehold or long leasehold interest in the following film/television studios and production facilities:-

answer: The Welsh Ministers have freehold or long leasehold interest in the following film/television studios and production facilities:-

answer: The Welsh Ministers have freehold or long leasehold interest in the following film/television studios and production facilities:-

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: How much did each Ministerial department spend on taxi fares for the financial years 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18 to date?
answer: The Welsh Government does not separately identify taxi costs within its financial systems.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update and details on the forthcoming successor programme to the Superfast Broadband project?
answer: Work is well underway to develop the successor scheme and the procurement process for this new initiative has started. We will invite tenders shortly and I will provide further information in due course.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Did the First Minister seek the advice of the Counsel General regarding allegations surrounding Carl Sargeant AM during the period between Monday 30 October 2017 and Friday 10 November 2017 and, if so, will he publish all correspondence relating to this advice, including emails, letters, telephone conversations and face-to-face meetings?
answer: I do not comment on the provision of legal advice.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Did the First Minister seek the advice of the Permanent Secretary regarding allegations surrounding Carl Sargeant AM during the period Monday 30 October and Friday 10 November 2017 and, if so, will he publish all correspondence relating to this advice, including e-mails, letters, telephone conversations and face-to-face meetings?
answer: This was not a matter for the civil service.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Did the First Minister seek the advice of Welsh Government lawyers regarding allegations surrounding Carl Sargeant AM during the period between Monday 30 October and Friday 10 November 2017 and, if so, will he publish all correspondence relating to this advice, including e-mails, letters, telephone conversations and face-to-face meetings?
answer: I do not comment on the provision of legal advice.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Further to WAQ75492, will the Leader of the House provide maps or other evidence of which areas of the Monmouth constituency have been upgraded with superfast broadband during the contract with Openreach?
answer: Information about the premises which have been provided with access to superfast broadband under the Superfast Cymru programme is available online at http://lle.gov.wales/map/ngaomr2017

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Further to WAQ75493, now that the Superfast Cymru contract with Openreach has ended, have any penalties been imposed for non-delivery of elements of the contract?
answer: The final Superfast Cymru delivery figures will be available for scrutiny in late March/April of this year, any penalties to be imposed will be issued thereafter.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: What assessment has the Leader of the House made of the number of properties where the necessary fibre has been installed or local cabinets upgraded but properties have yet to access broadband services?
answer: Take-up of services through infrastructure provided under the Superfast Cymru project stands at 39.89 per cent of all premises able to receive a fibre based broadband service, this equates to 271,000 premises.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Further to WAQ75495, will the Leader of the House reassure residents in NP25 5NT that they may receive an adequate broadband service in the near future?
answer: Residents of NP25 5NT can already receive access to superfast broadband services, provided by the Superfast Cymru project.  However, without specific postal addresses, it is impossible to provide updates on connectivity to individual premises within the area.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: What assessment has the Leader of the House made of levels of access to superfast broadband in Monmouthshire at the end of the Superfast Cymru programme?
answer: Following the end of the Superfast Cymru build phase Openreach will provide me with their final claims for premises completed. This will then be subject to a robust testing and verification process. Only once this process is complete will I be able to announce final figures for premises provided with access to superfast broadband under the project. I expect this to be in the spring.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what action the Welsh Government has undertaken to ensure that suitable arrangements are in place for residents who may be unable to access their homes as a result of construction works for the proposed Northern Access Road?
answer: The Contractor appointed the deliver the Northern Access Road is contractually required to maintain access to properties at all times during the course of the works.  The Contractor is required to liaise with all affected parties to agree access arrangements and implement any security measures deemed necessary.  Temporary measures may need to be agreed for individual premises from time to time.  In these situations the Contractor will liaise with the affected parties well in advance to agree suitable measures.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister confirm the timetable for the recruitment of the next Older People's Commissioner for Wales?
answer: The Older People’s Commissioner for Wales is a prominent public appointment, with a robust process to ensure the successful candidate fulfils the requirements of the role. A number of applications have been received and I will announce the appointment, allowing time for handover before they assume their role in June.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the proposed restructuring of orthopaedic services in north Wales?
answer: The orthopaedic services across north Wales are extremely challenged and we have asked the health board to develop proposals for a sustainable orthopaedic service. We expect the plans to be clinically led and ensure that they will be able to respond to expected demand based upon robust forecasts for the future years.

name: Jane Hutt
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What considerations have been made to date about the frequency of services on the Vale of Glamorgan railway line, as part of plans for the South East Wales Metro?
answer: Transport for Wales is currently assessing the three bids returned to operate and develop the Wales and Borders Rail Service and South Wales Metro. Our minimum requirement is that services will be at least equivalent to those currently provided, while bidders have been incentivised through the procurement process to enhance services across the network.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Is the Pinewood Group still committed to operating the studio in Wentloog?
answer: Pinewood remains committed to operating the studio in Wentloog and continuing to promote Wales internationally as a destination for high end TV and film production.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide the total number of payments made to the Pinewood Group in relation to their advisory work for the Welsh Government since establishing an agreement with the company?
answer: As outlined in WAQ74277, Pinewood’s role was to structure commercial deals that were considered suitable for Welsh Government investment. They received no direct payments from Welsh Government for this role. Any fees earned by Pinewood for this role were paid directly by the production.

name: Adam Price
response_name: First Minister
question: Further to the answer to WAQ75459, does the First Minister have any memory of a meeting with Carl Sargeant on the night of 14 October 2014 and what was discussed?
answer: I do not recall a meeting with Carl specifically on that date but I do meet Ministers occasionally on an informal basis.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Has an assessment been made by the Valleys Taskforce or the Welsh Government of the investment required to create the 7,000 jobs referred to in 'Our Valleys, Our Future'?
answer: To clarify, the target in Our Valleys, Our Future is not to create 7,000 jobs; it is to help 7,000 economically-inactive and unemployed people in the Valleys into fair, secure and sustainable work.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the availability of Savitex for multiple sclerosis sufferers in Wales?
answer: Sativex is routinely available as an option to treat multiple sclerosis sufferers in Wales who meet the clinical criteria specified by the All-Wales Medicines Strategy Group and who are likely to benefit from it. This is for individual clinicians to determine.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: First Minister
question: What plans does the Cabinet Secretary have to extend the availability of Savitex to multiple sclerosis sufferers in Wales?
answer: Sativex is routinely available as an option to treat multiple sclerosis sufferers in Wales who meet the clinical criteria specified by the All-Wales Medicines Strategy Group and who are likely to benefit from it. This is for individual clinicians to determine.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary working to ensure that all public bodies in Wales providing health and social services have a thorough and adequate complaints procedure?
answer: The Welsh Ministers have established, through regulations, comprehensive complaints’ systems for use by persons who wish to raise a concern about NHS services or social services.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why the Welsh Government's strategy to tackle loneliness and isolation amongst older people will not be published until 2019?
answer: The Health, Social Care and Sport Committee’s recent report recognised loneliness and isolation presents significant challenge in terms of complexity and scale, affecting older people and many other groups. The proposal to publish the strategy in 2019 is therefore designed to allow sufficient time for the significant research and analysis necessary to establish the right actions, in accordance with the Committees recommendations. It also allows for a period of formal consultation so people across Wales can have their say.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: In relation to WAQ75499, will the Cabinet Secretary provide a detailed breakdown of the meetings including: the businesses and business organisations that were engaged with, who was present at those meetings and on what dates the meetings were held?
answer: As I set out in my response to WAQ75499, I regularly meet with businesses, representative bodies and others and have used these meetings to discuss the themes, ideas and priorities that have informed the Economic Action Plan. These meetings have been a part of normal business and so it is not possible to disaggregate them.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide the number of operations in each of Wales's health boards that were postponed or cancelled in December 2017?
answer: The data you have requested is not currently available. I will write to you as soon as it is available.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: How many new jobs does the Cabinet Secretary estimate will be created by the eight enterprise zones across Wales in 2018?
answer: We have published a target for jobs supported alongside other outputs at http://gov.wales/docs/det/publications/170719-kpi-16-17-en.pdf

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the impact of ending the tolls on the second Severn crossing on the Welsh economy?
answer: Research we have undertaken shows that the removal of the tolls would significantly reduce the cost for businesses and individuals coming into Wales. It is also estimated that removing the tolls would boost productivity in Wales by over £100 million a year.  As the ‘Impact of the Severn Tolls on the Welsh Economy’ report concludes, ‘tolls effectively increase the cost of doing business in South Wales, thereby making South Wales a less attractive location for investment.’  A copy of the report can be found here:

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What assesment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the impact of the current levels of traffic congestion in Wales on the Welsh economy?
answer: We are aware of the impact that congestion is having on the Welsh economy. The newly launched Welsh Transport Appraisal Guidance (WelTAG) 2017 includes specific criteria and outcomes relating to the Welsh economy and will be used for the development and appraisal of future transport proposals. Further details can be found on our website at https://beta.gov.wales/welsh-transport-appraisal-guidance-weltag

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What plans does the Cabinet Secretary have for the creation of new enterprise zones in Wales?
answer: We are confident about the location of our Enterprise Zones, but it is of course sensible to keep this under review and consider the case for any new locations as appropriate.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What assesment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the impact of electrification between London and Cardiff on the Welsh economy?
answer: We know that improving cross-border links are very important to the economies on both sides of the Wales-England border. This was recognised by the UK Government when it took its decision to electrify the Great Western mainline. The Welsh Government made the case for extending electrification beyond Cardiff through to Swansea and this case was accepted by the UK Government.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide figures for infrastructure funding provided by the Welsh Government, broken down by constituency and region since 2011/2012?
answer: Regional capital spending does not form part of the audited Welsh Government’s consolidated annual accounts.  However, following the publication of the Wales Infrastructure Investment Plan in 2012, information has been collected centrally on projected Welsh Government capital investments with a total value in excess of £0.5m.  A geographical breakdown of this information for the years available is provided in the attached table.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: What is the 2018-19 forecast figure for Welsh Government reserves, and will the Cabinet Secretary explain the reasons for this level of unallocated reserves?
answer: Details of the amount of unallocated resources in 2018-19 are set out in Table 5.2 of the final Budget 2018-19 narrative published on 19 December 2017.  As I indicated in my statement about the draft Budget on 3 October 2017, 2018-19 is also the first year of operation of the new Welsh reserve. I was able to plan the final Budget 2018-19 on the basis of making the best use of that flexibility. The opening balance of that reserve will be confirmed in my report on the 2017-18 outturn to the Finance Committee which I will provide in due course.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary had regarding the implications of new data protection regulations on town and community councils?
answer: I will be ensuring that all community and town councils are aware of the new data protection regulations and of the support the Information Commissioner’s Office can offer.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Has the Cabinet Secretary made any assessment of the financial impact of the new data protection regulations on town and community councils?
answer: I have not made an assessment of the financial impact of the new data protection regulations on community and town councils.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that the Welsh Government intends to bring forward the financial resolution for the Public Services Ombudsman (Wales) Bill within the required timescales?
answer: The Welsh Government will consider its approach in the light of the reports from the Scrutiny Committees.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How many prosecutions were made for breaches of marine permit licenses in 2014-15, 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18 to date?
answer: No prosecutions have been taken by the Welsh Government in relation to Marine Consents Licenses during the years 2014-15, 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Children and Social Care
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary working to ensure that all local authorities ensure compliance with safe catheterisation practices by social care workers, and social care providers, including private care providers contracted through a local authority?
answer: In most Health Board areas<U+200E> catheterisation is only undertaken by trained registered nurses unless the patient is self-catheterising or a relative/carer is trained. Where catheterisation is delegated to social care workers, this is done on a named individual basis, with the care worker only being able to undertake action for that individual once trained and deemed competent and for no other individual. This is monitored and supervised by the delegator.

name: Steffan Lewis
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide an update on the research commissioned by the Welsh Government from Cardiff University on the impact Brexit will have on businesses from across a range of sectors of the Welsh economy?
answer: The Cardiff Business School report on EU Transition is informing the development of our trade policy and will be published in early February alongside our forthcoming trade paper.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What consideration has been given by the Welsh Government to the use of concessionary bus passes from England being used in Wales?
answer: Welsh Government Ministers have for some time been keen to explore the potential for a reciprocal free local bus travel scheme for older or disabled passholders resident in Wales, England and Scotland. Officials have discussed the scope for this with the Scottish Government and the Department for Transport, but neither wishes to pursue this opportunity at this time.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the commitment of the Welsh Government to becoming a Blue Planet champion, following calls from the Wales Marine Link?
answer: I champion the marine environment of Wales and welcome the initiative to encourage a global effort to protect our oceans.  Hannah Blythyn, Minister for Environment, is equally committed and already a Blue Planet champion.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the task and finish group set up under the waste ministerial programme board to investigate a behaviour change campaign on recycling publish a report on its findings, and when will this be published?
answer: Task and finish groups are established under the waste Ministerial Programme Board (MPB) to facilitate open discussion of strategic and delivery issues between Welsh Government and Local Government.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: When will the Welsh Government make a decision on whether to proceed with a behaviour change campaign to target the 50 per cent of recyclable material that remains in residual waste in Wales?
answer: The compositional analysis of residual municipal waste in Wales shows that almost half is capable of being recycled. The physical infrastructure to collect and treat this waste already exists and the main barrier to this happening is behavioural.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Welsh Government be following the UK Government’s example and removing all consumer single use plastic in central government offices?
answer: We are currently updating our waste strategy and producing a resource efficiency route map which will include consideration of how we can lead by example. The route map will include measures for improving resource efficiency including single use plastic in government buildings and the wider public sector.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs

Once completed, individuals are shown their overall essential skill level and will receive a tailored individual learning plan, including relevant training materials.

The Coleg have been instructed to establish a specialist Advisory Board made up of stakeholders with representation from the further education and work-based learning sectors to advise on future interventions required to develop Welsh-medium post-16 provision which will be developed into a formal action plan. This action plan will be developed in partnership between the Coleg and Welsh Government officials. The Advisory board will meet for the first time on 26 January.

This approach provides individuals with the first vocational step towards their apprenticeship journey and it is made up of Local Authority and Further Education funding.  This means that school age individuals receive GCSE English/Welsh and Maths, Vocational Qualification, learning support and work experience at their local college.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What guidance, if any, has the Welsh Government issued in relation to the use of religiously compliant meat products in the Welsh NHS and Welsh schools?
answer: Guidance is available to support the mandatory food and fluid nutrition standards for hospital patients.  This guidance stipulates that hospitals must consider the needs of minority groups who require special diets early in the menu planning process. There is a requirement to have policies and procedures in place to ensure that these patient groups can meet their nutritional needs through the provision of appropriate and familiar foods. Special diets refer to cultural or religious needs such as halal or kosher diets. It is recommended that menu planning groups consult patients, local communities and their representatives to confirm their needs.

Special diets refer to cultural or religious needs such as halal or kosher diets. This level of borrowing within our overall limit is an ambitious but prudent level of commitment, retaining a sensible degree of flexibility to enable us to borrow over and above existing plans to support additional investment, new priorities and opportunities should this be required.
