question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the impact of potential changes suggested by the UK Department for Transport, to permits and licensing on the community transport sector in Wales?
answer: The legislative framework for issuing Community transport permits is a non-devolved matter and it is understood that the community transport permit regime will continue to be a matter reserved to the UK Government following commencement of the Wales Act enacted in 2017. It is the right and proper process that an Independent Public Inquiry is scrutinising the details of the project including its business case, environmental mitigation and suggested alternatives and allowing all views to be heard. The inspectors’ report will inform a final decision whether to proceed with construction this year.

answer: I am aware of the concerns around future funding for the All Wales School Liaison Core Programme (AWSLCP). The UK Government’s austerity agenda means that we have to take very difficult financial decisions.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What is the Welsh Government’s rationale for phasing out the All Wales School Liaison Core Programme in Wales, given that it is considered an example of good practice in England and the Czech Republic?
answer: In the context of reducing budgets, we have had to take difficult decisions across Welsh Government on how to prioritise our spending plans and this has meant making difficult decisions such as ending our contribution from the Substance Misuse Action Plan Fund to the All Wales Schools Liaison Core Programme from 2019-20.   We have looked very carefully at all aspects of our spend under the Fund in order to prioritise the support we provide to frontline substance misuse treatment services. This is in response to the latest figures showing a continued need for treatment services given ONS data at the end of last year showing increases in drug and alcohol related deaths – putting greater pressure on our frontline services.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Minister for Children and Social Care
question: Further to WAQ75476, will the Cabinet Secretary provide a timescale for the delivery of an all-Wales policy on allowances for kinship carers?
answer: We are working with our local government and other partners through the National Fostering Framework Strategic Steering Group on an all-Wales approach to fees and allowances for mainstream and kinship foster carers. The aim is to harmonise fees and allowances, to ensure that foster carers across Wales are treated fairly when it comes to financial and other support.  Mapping of local authority fees and allowances for mainstream foster carers was undertaken during 2016-17, and I am expecting a follow up report with recommendations by the end of March.  A similar mapping exercise for kinship care fees and allowances (and allowances to special guardians) is currently being undertaken, and this data will also be available in March.  Further work to develop an all-Wales approach will then be undertaken within the context of the National Fostering Framework during 2018-19, in consultation with all relevant partners.  This will include consideration of different models and approaches, and the need to develop further policies and guidance for local authorities.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Does the Welsh Government support devolving powers over permitting and licensing for community transport operators?
answer: The provisions in sections 19 and 22 of the Transport Act 1985 provides for a modified regime for Public Service Vehicle operating for certain purposes. Under the new devolved settlement introduced by the Wales Act 2017, which is expected to be commenced shortly, public service vehicle licensing, including community transport permit requirements, will remain a matter reserved to the UK Government. It remains our policy position that these matters should be devolved.

Following the positive evaluation of the Abertawe Bro Morgannwg Pathfinder, I asked to see a robust plan for taking forward the 111 service in Wales. The NHS through the 111 Programme Board have now devised and agreed a strategic plan to further roll out the service over the next 2-3 years.

question: What consideration will the Cabinet Secretary give, with Natural Resources Wales, to setting up a local management company for a four-year period to oversee an effective management of the Conwy River catchment in North Wales, with a view to reducing the risks posed to numbers of salmon and sea trout stocks?
answer: The River Conwy is an important salmon and sea trout river, supporting a number of local clubs as well as fishing tourism and 3 draft net fisheries. My Department is liaising with Natural Resources Wales (NRW) regarding its proposal for river recovery plans for all the principal salmon and sea trout rivers in Wales. This is in line with NRW’s statutory duty to “maintain, improve and develop salmon, trout, freshwater and eel fisheries”, as outlined in Section 6 (6) of the Environment Act. I expect proposals to include any measures NRW intend to introduce and how any restoration work will be taken forward in collaboration with stakeholders.

question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether Green Light laser technology treatment for benign prostatic hyperplasia is available in all health boards across Wales - and, if not, whether he has plans to make it available to all patients?
answer: Green light laser technology is available to patients in three health boards across Wales – Abertawe Bro Morgannwg University Health Board, Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board and Hywel Dda University Health Board

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the frequency of train services between Penarth and Cardiff will either increase, decrease or stay the same as a result of conversion to light rail as part of the South Wales Metro project?
answer: A decision will be made on the infrastructure solution to deliver the South Wales Metro as part of the selection of a successful bidder in May. Transport for Wales is currently assessing the bids returned to operate and develop the Wales and Borders Rail Service and South Wales Metro. Our minimum requirement is that provision will be made for existing freight traffic on Valley Lines and that services will be at least equivalent to those currently provided.

question: What is the Welsh Government doing to make sure specialist training is provided in the NHS for the treatment of dystonia, so patients in north Wales do not need to travel to England to receive specialist treatment?
answer: The Neurological Conditions Delivery Plan sets out the Welsh Government’s expectation for the future delivery of services and ensures a continued focus on the delivery of patient-centred services for people with all neurological conditions. Health boards need to put in place local plans to deliver co-ordinated services for the population they serve, including the provision of neurological services for conditions such as dystonia.

Some patients in mid Wales may access PET in Manchester if the travel distance is shorter. answer: Natural Resources Wales (NRW) announced on 7 February its decision to grant Biomass UK No 2 Ltd an environmental permit to operate a renewable energy gasification facility in Barry. In coming to their decision NRW has undertaken an extensive assessment of the company’s plans and has received specialist health advice from Public Health Wales and the Cardiff and Vale University Health Board. As the Welsh Ministers continue to have a potential role in appeals on the permit, it is not appropriate for me to meet with the Docks Incinerator Action Group. I would be happy for members of the group to meet with my officials to discuss their concerns. If the Chair of the group would like to contact my office, arrangements can be made for a meeting.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what factors were taken into account when the decision was taken to centralise services for thoracic surgery in Wales, and confirm why Morriston Hospital was chosen as a suitable location for south Wales patients?
answer: The reform of thoracic surgery services in south Wales arose from the need to reduce waiting times for surgery, establish a more sustainable clinical rota, provide for greater specialisation of the surgical workforce and help improve our whole service so that survival improves.  The review concerned the surgical element of treatment; all other parts, such as scans, biopsies and follow-up care, will happen in local hospitals.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide the details on the uptake of the Farm Business Grant, and explain both how the Welsh Government decided on the list of qualifying items, and on the percentage of its financial contribution towards each of them?
answer: To date, 831 farmers have been approved to the Farm Business Grant, requesting £5.7million in grant support. The list of items was developed in consultation with the industry and continues to be reviewed with stakeholders to ensure the items meet the needs of the industry. The percentage is based on 40% as laid out in Annex II of EC regulation 1305/2013. However, by using standardised costs, it allows the farmers flexibility to secure the items which meet the specification for the best price. By implementing the scheme in this way, the administrative burden for the applicants is minimised.

name: David Melding
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Since it was bought five years ago, why has the Welsh Government not yet developed on the land at Callaghan Square?
answer: The land was originally purchased by Welsh Government in order to stimulate delivery of much needed high quality offices in the city centre. The subsequent success of the private sector in delivering record levels of floor space (in the Enterprise Zone) eased the pressure for its early redevelopment. More recently, broader mixed use proposals have been presented but these have not been progressed or realised to date. With an ever more vibrant and maturing city centre, the opportunities for its successful redevelopment have never been stronger or more timely. There is currently interest in the Callaghan Square site from a number of parties and my officials are in the process of preparing advice. My focus is on obtaining the best outcomes from the sale of the site and its subsequent development.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the situation in relation to hepatitis B vaccinations in Wales?
answer: Due to manufacturing issues, there has been global shortage of hepatitis B vaccine since last summer which has had a severe impact on the UK supply. The situation is improving but supply constraints are likely to continue into 2018. To ensure that vaccine is available for those individuals at highest and most immediate risk of exposure to hepatitis B, guidance has been issued to NHS Wales on how to prioritise the use of the available stock. The supply of paediatric vaccine has been protected to ensure the continuation of vaccination for infants born to hepatitis B infected mothers. Supplies of the new “6 in 1” hexavalent vaccine, containing hepatitis B vaccine and introduced into the routine childhood programme from 1st August 2017, are not affected by the shortage.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement in response to the fact that productivity in north-west Wales was 28 per cent below the UK average in 2016, and outline how the Welsh Government will work to improve productivity in this specific region?
answer: There is no doubt that the UK figures are skewed by the economic success of London and the South East. Productivity is below the UK average in all UK countries and regions outside of London and the South East. We recognise that Wales, along with other parts of the UK, has significant work to do in driving up productivity and that is what we are addressing.  The latest GVA figures showed that Wales as a whole was the fastest growing country in the UK, with our GVA rising to nearly £60 billion in 2016; whilst our employment rate continues to grow.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain how Visit Wales is promoting Llanrwst as a tourist destination, and state how the Welsh Government will be working with local businesses to produce a strategy for marketing the town and surrounding area?
answer: The Welsh Government tourism strategy, “Partnership for Growth” sets out our priorities for developing and marketing all of Wales. This includes capital and revenue funding, and marketing activities at home and overseas.  In addition to this we recently launched ‘The Wales Way’ a new internationally focused tourism route initiative that aims to provide inspirational itineraries for visitors to Wales and includes a family of three routes including the Cambrian Way (A470), the Coastal Way (A487) and the North Wales Way (A55). A key objective of The Cambrian Way is to encourage visitors to explore beyond Cardiff, travel  up the A470 and stay and experience a range of tourism attractions along the route including Llanrwst which is described as the historic ‘capital’ of the Conwy Valley and highlights Gwydir castle as a place to visit along the way  - http://www.thewalesway.com/the-cambrian-way/explore-the-cambrian-way

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an assessment of the quarantine unit regulations?
answer: At the request of industry representatives the introduction of Quarantine Units was delayed from June to 11 September 2017 to facilitate attendance at summer shows and allow more time for keepers to put in place Quarantine Units. As the show season had ended only a relatively small number of applications have been received. A formal review of the QU scheme will be undertaken within three years of its implementation.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the number of licence applications for new livestock quarantine units on Welsh farms?
answer: As of 16 February 2018, there have been 77 applications and 68 quarantine units certified. The low level of applications was expected in view of the start being delayed to September at the end of the show season, as requested by the industry. We do not expect many, if any, new applications until the spring to enable livestock keepers to use their QU for two summer show seasons during their 18-month certification period.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the amount of money raised from the quarantine unit charge?
answer: The introduction of quarantine units is not a revenue raising exercise for the Welsh Government.  The certification costs for QUs reflect the certification body, QWFC Ltd.’s, costs in providing the service, which includes site visits to inspect and evaluate the QUs.  No part of the cost is provided to the Welsh Government. The Welsh Government has sought to keep the cost to farmers to a minimum by not passing on any other incurred costs, including UKAS accreditation of the certification body, extensive IT changes and the ongoing cost of the Animal and Plant Health Agency (APHA) inspections.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of the number of quarantine unit inspections that have taken place in Wales, by local authority?
answer: To date, the Animal and Plant Health Agency has carried out six in-use Quarantine Unit inspections. Two were in Denbighshire and one each in Powys, Monmouthshire, Vale of Glamorgan and Ceredigion.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary had with stakeholders regarding the implementation of quarantine units and what outcomes have been reached from those discussions?
answer: I met with the Farmers Union of Wales, National Farmers Union Cymru and National Sheep Association before and after the introduction of Quarantine Units. Following representations from industry the coming into force date of QUs was delayed three months from 10 June to 11 September 2017 to facilitate attendance at shows during the 2017 season and to allow more time for keepers to put in place Quarantine Units.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to introduce compulsory registration of elective home education children?
answer: The Welsh Government has no plans to introduce compulsory registration of electively home educated children.  On the 30 January I announced plans to consult on using existing powers to require local authorities to establish a database to assist them in identifying children not receiving suitable education. The consultation will also consider which partners will be able to provide the most complete database, such as local health boards.  To support local authorities in the operation of the database and in the arrangements to assess the suitability of education to children on the database, I will consult on statutory guidance to be issued to local authorities.  The statutory guidance will include advice for local authorities on making assessments regarding the suitability of education.  This will ensure the approach is consistent, fair and transparent across Wales.

The consultation will also consider which partners will be able to provide the most complete database, such as local health boards.  To support local authorities in the operation of the database and in the arrangements to assess the suitability of education to children on the database, I will consult on statutory guidance to be issued to local authorities.  The statutory guidance will include advice for local authorities on making assessments regarding the suitability of education.  This will ensure the approach is consistent, fair and transparent across Wales.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How do local authorities in Wales assess the progress of elective home-educated children?
answer: The Welsh Government has no plans to introduce compulsory registration of electively home educated children.  On the 30 January I announced plans to consult on using existing powers to require local authorities to establish a database to assist them in identifying children not receiving suitable education. The consultation will also consider which partners will be able to provide the most complete database, such as local health boards.  To support local authorities in the operation of the database and in the arrangements to assess the suitability of education to children on the database, I will consult on statutory guidance to be issued to local authorities.  The statutory guidance will include advice for local authorities on making assessments regarding the suitability of education.  This will ensure the approach is consistent, fair and transparent across Wales.

name: Mark Isherwood

question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm if the Welsh Government is spending above or below the current Barnett provision on both health and social care?
answer: The Barnett formula is a mechanism to determine changes to the Welsh Government’s budget relative to changes in budgets for relevant UK Government departments. It is not intended to be used to compare absolute levels of spending between England and Wales. The formula is based on the proportion of the Welsh population against the English population, adjusted for the comparability of spending responsibility between the relevant UK Government department and the Welsh Government portfolio. In respect of spending on health and social care, the formula percentage adjustment is 5.69%.

That is why the Welsh Government published ‘Global Futures – a plan to improve and promote Modern Foreign Languages (MFL) in Wales’, in October 2015.

name: David Melding
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: In the next five years what percentage of commercial property transactions are expected to be affected by the land transaction tax increase from five percent to six percent on commercial properties over £1 million?
answer: The forecast of land transaction tax for 2018-19, which was assured by Bangor Businesses School, included an estimate that around 250 non-residential transactions would be subject to the 6% rate. It is expected that there will be a total of around 6,000 non-residential transactions (including those which will be relieved) in 2018-19, so the percentage of transactions liable for the non-residential 6% rate is estimated to be 4%. In total, 96% of non-residential transactions will either be relieved, pay the same, or pay less tax than they would under SDLT.

name: David Melding
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: When the Welsh Government was developing the commercial aspects of the land transaction tax, what considerations were given to the impact that the reduced Scottish land and building transactions tax of 4.5 percent for buildings over £350,000 has had in increasing investment in Scotland?
answer: The Welsh Government took account of a wide range of relevant evidence from across the UK and elsewhere when developing land transaction tax policy.  Land and buildings transaction tax (LBTT) in Scotland has been lower than stamp duty land tax (SDLT) in the rest of the UK for non-residential transactions over £300,000 since March 2016, when the UK Government changed SDLT non-residential tax rates.  In 2016-17, non-residential LBTT revenues fell by 19 per cent, which seems to have been driven by a reduction in high value transactions.

question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how he will ensure reduced waiting times in trauma and orthopaedics within Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board by next month, and confirm targets for this period?
answer: The Welsh Government gave Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board an additional £13.1 million of funding in August 2017 to help reduce waiting times over 36 weeks by the end of March 2018, including orthopaedics. The health board has been using this money to run additional sessions locally and outsource patients to alternative providers, both NHS in England and the Independent sector. This funding is already having an impact, with the number waiting over 36 weeks for orthopaedics falling from 4,213 at the end of August to 4,078 at the end of December. I expect to see further reductions by the end of March 2018 as part of the overall improvement in RTT waiting times in the health board.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies

question: With regard to the Welsh Revenue Authority (Powers to Investigate Criminal Offences) Regulations 2018, will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of funding set aside for Welsh Revenue Authority training on anti-money laundering and counter-terrorist financing investigations?
answer: As part of the Welsh Government consultation on the Welsh Revenue Authority’s powers to tackle devolved tax crime, my officials met with representatives of the National Crime Agency (NCA) Proceeds of Crime Centre and HM Revenue and Customs (HMRC).  The purpose of those discussions was to consider how the powers contained in the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (POCA) are governed and used in practice.  These discussions have informed the making of the Proceeds of Crime Act 2002 (References to Welsh Revenue Authority Financial Investigators) Order 2018, which will, among other things, enable financial investigators accredited by the NCA to undertake money laundering investigations in relation to devolved tax crime

name: Lynne Neagle

question: How will the Welsh Government ensure that work on the forthcoming Obesity Strategy takes full account of the needs of children and young people ?
answer: The needs of children and young people will be core to the development of the Obesity Strategy and will be taken into account through a number of mechanisms. This will include a thorough assessment of the evidence of the factors influencing obesity levels in children and the evidence of the impact of obesity on children. My officials are developing proposals for early engagement prior to the consultation with Young Wales, Sport Wales Youth Ambassadors Forum and with Children in Wales stakeholder groups. There will also be direct engagement with children through the consultation process. The Office of the Children’s Commissioner is also represented on the Strategy Development Board, chaired by the Chief Medical Officer.

Cwm Taf University Health Board have been running this pathway for over a year and Aneurin Bevan University Health Board for the past 6 months.

The vast majority of underlying data used in the settlement calculations are updated annually.

The implementation of the strategy is supported by an independent national advisory group who regularly review information to inform the ongoing implementation of the delivery plan.

name: Mark Isherwood

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary detail the discussions he has had, to date, with third party sector and local authorities to improve social mobility for disabled people in Wales?
answer: While there are no specific targets for reducing poverty among disabled people, Welsh Government is committed to doing more to support those most at risk of living in poverty, which includes groups with certain protected characteristics such as disabled people and families with disabled children. We recognise that disabled people are disproportionately represented in both economically inactive and workless households. We will work with those individuals in Wales who are currently economically inactive and say they would like to work and who require additional support to help them overcome complex barriers.Our Economic Action Plan will play a full and active role in improving the life chances of all people in Wales. Its actions are focused on fostering inclusive growth and improving outcomes by promoting well-being and spreading opportunity.Our Employability Delivery Plan will be published later this month.  It will set out how we will provide tailored support ensuring a coherent pathway to employment for an individual seeking to gain, retain or progress in work.

It also requires multi-dwelling buildings to be equipped with a common access point to a network.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on childhood obesity, and explain what innovative solutions it is endorsing to make food and drink available to children healthier and more affordable?
answer: The Soft Drinks Industry Levy is due to come into force in April 2018, which will be a helpful tool to reduce sugar consumption. There is already evidence of a reduction in children’s sugar intakes from fizzy drinks, as manufacturers have moved to reformulate their products before the sugar levy becomes operational. We also have the Healthy Eating in Schools (Nutritional Standards and Requirements) (Wales) Regulations 2013 which sets out the types of food and drink that should be provided during the school day and define the nutrient content of school lunches. Over the 2017 summer holiday period, Welsh Government worked collaboratively with the Welsh Local Government Association (WLGA) and local authorities to provide good quality meals, nutrition skills and sports education to children living in areas of social deprivation. The Welsh model for tackling learning loss and holiday hunger over the summer holidays has been recognised as the best of its kind in the UK.

This can present as movement problems, fatigue and issues with muscles; including pain, weakness and shrinkage. Support and treatment focuses on helping people manage their symptoms and improving their quality of life. People with the condition are often treated by a team of different healthcare professionals working together.

name: Nick Ramsay

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline the reasons for the decrease in the post-16 education budget in 2019-20?
answer: The Welsh Government continues to set our Budgets against one of the longest periods of sustained austerity in living memory. The UK Government has consistently and persistently cut funding for public services. The Welsh Government’s budget will be 5% lower in real terms in 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11 – equivalent to £900m less to spend on public services, with our revenue budget 7% lower, some £1bn less to spend on front-line services.

Dr Tan is currently in the forming stage of her work, scoping activity and developing her engagement strategy. This engagement will include a series of Design Workshops for people with lived experience of eating disorders, their families and the public.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders

answer: The Welsh Government has a clear and long-standing commitment to schools funding. name: Janet Finch-Saunders

answer: The Welsh Government already provides support to farmers to drive innovation and transformational change in agriculture, including animal welfare, through the Sustainable Production Grant (SPG) and the Farm Business Grant (FBG).  Animal health and welfare is expressly referred to in the Welsh Government Rural Communities – Rural Development Programme 2014-2020, through which both schemes are delivered.

As a result the FDWIB launched a skills plan which can be found here

name: Janet Finch-Saunders

answer: The UK Government’s Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs (DEFRA) manages agricultural (and environmental) research budgets on behalf of England and Wales.

answer: Data from the Royal College of Physicians SSNAP database, based on the number of patients admitted to hospital with confirmed strokes over the past 24 months across Wales indicates that there have been 9,631 incidents of stroke.

answer: I raised the re-opening of the Irish Consulate with the Irish Ambassador when visited Wales in January. I’m keen to see the re-establishment of an Irish Consulate in Wales, which is even more important as the UK exits the European Union, and I intend to pursue this with the Taoiseach when we next speak.

name: Steffan Lewis

answer: Welsh health boards are providing evidence-based care for prostate cancer in line with the current National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guideline. Therefore, mpMRI scans are made available by all health boards in Wales in line with current guidance.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders

name: Janet Finch-Saunders

question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the state of the grass verge of the A470 between Llanrwst and Betws-y-Coed, and explain whether consideration has been given to ensuring that every vehicle access point to fields along this section of road has a hard surface?
answer: We continue to maintain the verges on this stretch in accordance with Welsh Government’s Trunk Road Maintenance Manual. Grass cutting is carried out in late spring (a safety cut adjacent to the carriageway) and a full verge cut in early autumn after wild plants have flowered and set seed. In addition, we seek to enhance verges where the opportunity arises, under our ‘Road Verges for Wildflowers’ initiative such as the wildflower seed sowing carried out at Llanrwst.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Given that the Welsh Health Circular (2017/048) on hepatitis elimination outlined the need to engage potential patients across a variety of services, including those who access substance misuse services, what KPIs have been introduced to ensure that those people are being tested proactively and offered treatment for hepatitis C?
answer: There is currently no specific KPI for blood borne viruses but Substance Misuse Area Planning Boards are required, under the Substance Misuse Delivery Plan, to implement routine opt-out testing for blood borne viruses such as HIV, hepatitis B and C, alongside providing hepatitis B vaccinations for those in contact with substance misuse services.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Following the announcement that five new medical schools will be opened in England in areas where it can be hard to recruit and attract new doctors, will the Cabinet Secretary follow the UK Government’s strong lead by opening a medical school in North Wales?
answer: I have been clear about the Government’s position on this matter, most recently in the statement I made about the NHS Workforce on 5th March. It is my view that Bangor University working with Cardiff and Swansea medical schools can deliver increased opportunities for medical education and training in North Wales. Proposals have been received and I look forward to responding to these positively within the coming weeks.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What measures the Welsh Government is taking in Wales to help improve output from all farms, given that 55 per cent of UK farm output comes from 7 per cent of farms in the UK using 30 per cent of the land?
answer: Increasing productivity in Welsh agriculture is critical to achieving our vision of a profitable and resilient industry. The Welsh Government offer farmers support via a wide range of mechanisms to enable them to become more productive.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on food waste in Wales, and explain what consideration the Welsh Government has given to introducing statutory measures to limit the amount of food being thrown away in particular by supermarkets?
answer: Wales has made significant progress reducing the amount of food we unnecessarily throw away. Figures published by WRAP show a 12% reduction of household food waste in Wales between 2009 and 2015 (on a per person basis from 115.0 kg to 102.9 kg per person per year). Wales’ household food waste per person is now lower than the rest of the UK by around 9%.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on food labelling, and explain what measures the Welsh Government will take to help consumers to be certain of the origin of the food they are eating?
answer: Currently, there is a wide body of law about food labelling, much of it in place to protect consumers.  The European Union’s Food Information to Consumers Regulations (No. 1169/2011) makes allergy labelling, nutritional information and country of origin information a mandatory requirement on food products.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that she recognises the importance of UK-wide frameworks in agriculture following Brexit?
answer: I have stated on a number of occasions that I believe UK frameworks will be necessary to cover certain agriculture matters post-Brexit. Importantly, I have also been clear that where they are necessary, UK frameworks must be developed on the basis of agreement between the four governments, drawing on the traditions of co-operation built up during the years of EU membership.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Infrastructure
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain whether the Welsh Government is looking to increase the number of destinations from Anglesey Airport, and provide details of those places currently under consideration?
answer: Anglesey Airport is currently served by a Cardiff to Anglesey double daily weekday return. The service has struggled significantly over recent years with failing operators which had seriously damaged passenger confidence; however the current operator, Eastern Airways, has increased patronage on the route by around 39% in the last 12 months when compared to the previous 12 month period – clearly demonstrating demand. Our priority for the next few years is to re-build passenger confidence and continue to grow the route in the long term.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies

The amount spent on transport varies from hub to hub, depending mainly on the geography of the hub and the travelling required to attend various sessions across the hubs, and to partner universities.

answer: The Water Strategy for Wales sets out our priorities for water and sewerage services. It sets out our long term strategy to ensure the people of Wales receive first class value for money water services and the water environment is sustainably managed to support healthy communities, flourishing businesses and the environment. Ensuring access to fair and affordable water and sewerage services, both for people and businesses is a key priority.

name: Russell George

question: What are the minimum standards for sound insulation in social housing in Wales?
answer: Part E (Resistance to the passage of sound) of the Building Regulations 2010 sets the minimum standards for sound insulation for all new and converted housing, including social housing, in Wales.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Does the Welsh Government have any plans to amend the legislation concerning the minimum standards for sound insulation in social housing in Wales in order to protect residents from nuisance noise in attached dwellings?
answer: There are no plans to amend Part E (Resistance to the passage of sound) of the Building Regulations 2010 which controls the minimum standards for sound insulation in new and converted housing, including social housing, in Wales. The requirements were last reviewed 2016 as part of the sustainability review of building regulations.

name: Dai Lloyd

answer: Due to the scale and complexity of the Social Services and Well-being Act (Wales) 2014, the evaluation of the Act will explore a wide range of themes and questions in order to establish the impact of the Act on people in Wales who need care and support and carers who need support.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders

answer: There is a duty of care on all animal keepers to protect the welfare of animals in their care, whether on a permanent or temporary basis, in the Animal Welfare Act 2006.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How is the Welsh Government currently ensuring that animal sanctuaries in Wales are operating to the highest possible welfare standards?
answer: There is a duty of care on all animal keepers to protect the welfare of animals in their care, whether on a permanent or temporary basis, in the Animal Welfare Act 2006.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how the Review of the Community and Town Council Sector will be taking into account the findings of the Wales Audit Office's report Financial Management and Governance in Local Councils 2016-17?
answer: The latest Wales Audit Office report on Financial Management and Governance in Local Councils has been provided to the Review of the Community and Town Council Sector as a key part of their evidence base. The Panel have also taken oral evidence from the Wales Audit Office.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Has the Welsh Government given any consideration to hosting broadband equipment on church spires?
answer: We have considered the use of both public and privately owned buildings, including church spires, for improved digital connectivity across Wales. We welcome the re-use of existing infrastructure to extend the reach of broadband and mobile services and note the recent accord between DCMS and The Church of England regarding the use of church buildings to support telecoms infrastructure across England. We will be engaging with DCMS to learn more about this accord and to explore how Wales can benefit from this work.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide figures for the last 5 years on the number of GP practices that have: closed; or have services that are now run by the local health board?
answer: The latest GP Access in Wales statistical release published on 21 March 2018, shows there were 436 GP practices in Wales at 30 November 2017 compared with 466 GP practices at 30 November 2013. The reduction in number is a result of a combination of factors including practice closures and practice mergers.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What plan is in place between Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board and the Welsh Government to support the board to deliver its performance targets, including its referral to treatment times?
answer: The Welsh Government and the NHS Wales Delivery Unit are working with the health board under the special measures arrangements to improve performance across a number of key areas.  The health board was allocated over £13 million of funding from the performance fund in 2017-18 to support the reduction of long waiting times by the end of March 2018. The health board is developing its plans for 2018/19 and will be discussing them with my officials in due course.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on progress in delivering the Economic Contract and the Call to Action as outlined in the New Economic Action Plan?
answer: We have been discussing our approach with businesses and other organisations across Wales, ahead of a targeted rollout of the Economic Contract, Calls to Action and Economy Futures Fund in the Spring.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement in relation on progress in delivering the Wales Digital Gateway project as outlined in the New Economic Action Plan?
answer: The Digital Gateway is an important investment in new digital infrastructure and in very high-quality, engaging content about Wales for the future and good progress is being made with the project to date.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on progress in developing a Brand for Wales as outlined in the New Economic Action Plan?
answer: A new brand for Wales was introduced in 2016 and our aim is to build on its successes to date through the new Economic Action Plan.

name: Russell George
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on progress in delivering campaigns to boost Welsh tourism as outlined in the New Economic Action Plan?
answer: Visit Wales delivers high-profile, multi-channel campaigns to promote Wales to consumers and the impact of this activity has doubled since 2013 – with our award-winning consumer marketing generating £360m of additional spend in the Welsh economy in 2016.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on progress in delivering campaigns to boost Welsh exports as outlined in the New Economic Action Plan?
answer: We are using our Trade and Invest campaign to identify and work with a range of businesses who successfully export from Wales. We are asking these companies to tell the story about how exports have contributed to their success.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Further to WAQ75819, will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on when guidance will be issued to local authorities on paying kinship carers a family placement fee?
answer: As stated in WAQ75819, work to develop an all-Wales approach to fostering fees and allowances will be undertaken as part of the National Fostering Framework during 2018-19. This will consider different models and approaches, and the need to develop further policies and guidance for local authorities. The National Fostering Framework Strategic Steering Group is currently drawing up plans for taking this forward during 2018-19.

name: Mark Reckless
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education

answer: As you will be aware, I wrote to the Children, Young People and Education Committee on 15 February 2018, providing an update against all of the Committee’s recommendations following their Inquiry into Youth Work:

name: Mark Reckless
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Has the Welsh Government held any discussions regarding the continuation of the Erasmus programme with the Vice-Chancellor of Cardiff University?
answer: The Welsh Government’s position is clear that we would wish to retain access to Erasmus+ as set out in our White Paper “Securing Wales’ Future”. The future of access to this and other EU programmes is subject to the negotiations with the European Union being led by the UK Government.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What guidance does the Welsh Government provide to health boards concerning the planning and accessibility of NHS services, given that research published by the British Medical Journal in 2016 found that outcomes were worse for people who had to travel further for NHS treatment?
answer: The BMJ research did not definitively conclude that outcomes were worse for people who had to travel further for NHS treatment. It stated that the results of the studies were mixed and concluded that a relationship between travelling further and having worse health outcomes cannot be ruled out.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Welsh Government follow the lead of the UK Government and assess whether the travel times and distance for NHS treatment negatively affects patient outcomes?
answer: The BMJ research did not definitively conclude that outcomes were worse for people who had to travel further for NHS treatment. It stated that the results of the studies were mixed and concluded that a relationship between travelling further and having worse health outcomes cannot be ruled out.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how much funding the Welsh Government gave GwE in 2015-16, 2016-17, 2017-18?
answer: Further to my response in December, the information requested is provided by GwE on their website. GwE’s accounts, including details of the grant funding spent, are available for 2015-16 and 2016-17 within the 2016-17 report below:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain whether GwE has given every teacher in schools across north Wales an opportunity to provide anonymous feedback about the service?
answer: GwE has processes in place to gather stakeholder feedback about the quality of their school improvement work. These include stakeholder’s questionnaires (including headteachers, teachers and support staff), user group forums, headteacher strategic forums, subject specific networks, etc. In addition, all developmental programmes and training are routinely evaluated through participant’s feedback.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how much money was spent on making the 2018 Visit Wales promotional video, and provide a breakdown of all the relevant costs?
answer: The promotional video you refer to is a key part of the Year of the Sea campaign, and - due to the integrated nature of marketing - the high-quality footage that was produced is being used for a wide-range of purposes. Versions of the film are available in Welsh, English and German; and as well as being shown on television to audiences of millions across the UK and in Ireland, the film material is also being used for on demand, online and social media marketing and at events globally, including in Berlin and New York. The video also features some pre-existing footage and all of the material will be re-used after 2018.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain how the Welsh Government is working with farmers to improve soil health?
answer: The Welsh Government continues to work with farmers through a wide range of activities to conserve and enhance soils.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain what consideration has been given to introducing an agriculture GCSE and state whether she recognises the benefits this could bring to students?
answer: I fully recognise the benefits teaching in agriculture can bring to students. The current curriculum provides the flexibility for teaching and learning about agriculture, natural resources and food.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the latest figures for usage of the Conwy Valley Line, including the increase in use of stations on the southern section, and explain whether a direct service can be introduced from Manchester Airport to Blaenau Ffestiniog so to build on existing popularity?
answer: I welcome any increase in popularity of the Conwy Valley Line services between Blaenau Ffestiniog and Llandudno and am pleased to be supporting the Conwy Valley Rail Initiative - which promotes the use and enjoyment of the line - with grant again this year.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How many schools has Estyn rated as performing poorly on school food standards and what action has been taken to improve these?
answer: Estyn report on the arrangements made to promote healthy eating and drinking in maintained schools, it does not report on the school’s performance on compliance with the Healthy Eating in Schools (Nutritional Standards and Requirements) (Wales) Regulations 2013.  Estyn has produced guidance on inspecting how well maintained schools (primary, secondary and special schools and pupil referral units) develop pupils’ understanding of healthy living. The guidance can be accessed from the link below:

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of Welsh Government spend over £25,000 on charities between October 2017 and February 2018, by month and charity?
answer: The Welsh Government publishes information on payments to all suppliers who receive more than £25,000 in any month. The way in which information is recorded does not allow the system to generate a report which isolates payments to charities. All payments to charities are included, however in the information published, and can be found at the Welsh Government web site at –

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Further to the First Minister's answer in Plenary on 20 March 2018, will the Cabinet Secretary for Finance provide a breakdown of the allocations made using the Barnett consequential from the Soft Drinks Industry Levy plus any planned allocations?
answer: Between 2016-17 and 2019-20 the Welsh Government has received £57m Barnett allocations following the increase in spending on programmes in England that are devolved to Wales as a consequence of the revenues expected from the soft drinks industry levy.

name: Mark Reckless
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What impact did the Land Transaction Tax rate of six percent for high value commercial property have on discussions involving the Welsh government on funding of a new Cardiff bus station and associated offices?
answer: Land Transaction Tax, and its predecessor Stamp Duty Land Tax, is payable on completion of the purchase of land or buildings and to date there have been no transactions connected with the proposed Bus Station and related commercial uses that would create a liability for tax. Discussions between Welsh Government and the private sector are ongoing and it is not yet possible to determine what, if any, impact there will be as a result of the change in taxation.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary working to increase hospice funding in Wales, in line with that of England, Northern Ireland and Scotland, where over 32 percent of funding comes from government?
answer: The Hospice UK figures referenced are not comparable across UK nations. They do not take account that in Wales, all Specialist Palliative Care teams in Hospitals and four out of the nine Hospices inpatient units are fully funded by NHS Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how Natural Resources Wales have dealt with the recent pollution incident at the Nant Cae Person stream in Llanrwst, Conwy, and advise what steps are being taken by the Welsh Government to avoid any further such incidents in future and protect fish in these areas?
answer: Natural Resources Wales  received a call on 30 March reporting 10-15 dead fish (sea trout & brown trout) on the stream at grid ref: SH 809 612 where it passes through Ysgol Dyffryn Conwy, Llanrwst.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what steps the Welsh Government is taking regarding future flood prevention works at Llandudno North Shore Beach, and provide the reasons this area was not included in the recent announcement of the £56 million flood and coastal erosion risk management programme?
answer: Work is already underway, lead by Conwy County Borough Council, on a future scheme for Llandudno North Shore.  Funding has been provided through the Coastal Risk Management Programme to undertake an Outline Business Case which will be submitted to Welsh Government later this year.  This is the first phase of any potential future works for Llandudno North Shore.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Following the First Minister's comments in Plenary on 21 November 2017, will the Cabinet Secretary provide further information as to how TAN 1 is being reviewed, including the timescale and scope of the consultation, and confirm whether this is separate to the ongoing Planning Policy Wales consultation?
answer: TAN 1 is being examined in the context of helping to ensure the Local Development Plan process improves the delivery of new homes, an aim which lies at the heart of the changes to housing policy in the draft revised Planning Policy Wales. I will reflect on the responses to the current consultation on Planning Policy Wales, which is open until 18th May, before deciding whether to make changes to TAN 1.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm when the policy statement in relation to the review of designated landscapes will be published, and what assurances can she give as regards the permanency of the Sandford principle in this area?
answer: I intend to publish my priorities for the designated landscapes before the summer recess. My statement to the Senedd on 13 March confirmed the Sandford principle will be retained.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the monies available to Penarth town via the Vale of Glamorgan Council or Town Council for regeneration projects within the town of Penarth?
answer: The Targeted Regeneration Investment programme was launched last October with funding of up to £100 million available across Wales for the period 2018-21.  It will be for the local authority to make the case for investment in Penarth within the context of the Regional Plan for Regeneration for south east Wales.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how much Welsh Government money has been spent/made available for regeneration projects in the town of Penarth for the last three financial years and identify the projects where money has been spent/made available?
answer: As with all our regeneration funding, we are guided by local authorities in determining local priorities for investment.  The focus for regeneration in the Vale of Glamorgan in recent years has been in the town of Barry.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the Welsh Government has received any bids from either the Vale of Glamorgan Council or the Penarth Town Council for financial support for Penarth Headlands projects and, if so, when will the Welsh Government confirm availability of funding and a timeline for expenditure?
answer: The Vale of Glamorgan Council applied for funding for the Cardiff – Vale Coastal Transport Network (which includes Penarth Headlands) through the Local Transport Fund for 2018-19. Their bid was successful and they were informed of the decision, including the terms and conditions of the grant on 12 April.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: How many community asset transfers have been completed in each year since communities were given this ability?
answer: The Welsh Government does not hold this information.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make available further information detailing the proposed changes to the Quality and Outcomes Framework following his recent statement regarding the General Medical Services contract for 2018/2019?
answer: As part of our GMS Contract agreement with GPC Wales for 2018/19, the Quality and Outcomes Framework will remain in place with the current indicators and points. However, within the clinical domain only the disease registers and two Flu indicators remain active. All other clinical indicators have become inactive. Data for all clinical indicators, active and inactive will continue to be available to view at a practice, cluster and health board level through the primary care portal. Data on inactive indicators will discussed at peer review sessions within clusters.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Which elements of the Quality and Outcomes Framework will be removed for the General Medical Services Contract for 2018/2019, following the recent written statement noting a reduction in the use of the Quality Outcomes Framework, and what consultation will be undertaken to assess the implications of any proposed reduction?
answer: As part of our GMS Contract agreement with GPC Wales for 2018/19, the Quality and Outcomes Framework will remain in place with the current indicators and points. However, within the clinical domain only the disease registers and two Flu indicators remain active. All other clinical indicators have become inactive. Data for all clinical indicators, active and inactive will continue to be available to view at a practice, cluster and health board level through the primary care portal. Data on inactive indicators will discussed at peer review sessions within clusters.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of the total cost of the Welsh Government's trip to the Gold Coast, and explain the outcomes of the trade discussion held during his trip?
answer: I was pleased to take advantage of the opportunity presented by the Commonwealth Games to promote Wales on the world stage.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide details of all the criteria that must be met by Wales's national parks and areas of outstanding natural beauty to receive some of the £3.4 million that has been made available, and explain how much will be allocated to each National Park or AONB?
answer: This additional funding has been allocated to unfunded projects and pressures submitted by the designated landscapes authorities. The activities are aligned with the strategic priorities letter for the core revenue grant and with the respective National Park’s statutory management plan. For the Areas of Outstanding Natural Beauty the activity is aligned to their Sustainable Development Fund Grant.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain how much the new National Coastal Monitoring Centre will cost to establish, and provide the names of the local authorities who are making a financial contribution, and detail of their specific amounts accordingly?
answer: The new Wales Coastal Monitoring Centre (WCMC) will cost in the order of £4,000 to establish to cover the recruitment costs.  The Consortium managing the WCMC is made up of Conwy County Borough Council, Gwynedd County Borough Council, Vale of Glamorgan Council and Welsh Local Government Association but all coastal authorities will benefit from its monitoring programme.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain whether some of the £56 million designated to the Flood and Coastal Risk Management Programme can be made available to help protect Gwydir Castle, especially given the amount of times it has been flooded and the importance of the site to the history of Wales?
answer: The £56 million Flood Risk Management Programme will allocate funding to communities at the highest risk of flooding, where reducing risk to life remains the priority. Whilst I acknowledge the historical significance of Gwydir Castle, the building itself is at low risk of flooding and it is the gardens and an uninhabited cellar which have been affected to date.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Following WAQ76174 will the Cabinet Secretary provide a list of all events taking place in England which the Welsh Government directly funded and organised in 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18, and details of the associated costs?
answer: This information could only be provided at disproportionate cost.

name: Jack Sargeant
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on whether Welsh Doctoral Loans are still on track to be introduced for 2018/19, or if not, if there are any similar matters being considered?
answer: I anticipate that regulations for the payment of doctoral loans will be laid with the National Assembly for Wales during June and come into force later that month to apply to courses beginning on or after 1 August 2018, in line with the commitment made in the response to the Review of Higher Education and Student Finance.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the Welsh Government's 21st Century School building programme with specific reference to how bids are evaluated?
answer: Kirsty Williams: The 21st Century Schools and Education Programme is a strategic investment programme jointly funded by Welsh Government and our delivery partners that will see investment of £1.4 billion over the five year period ending 2019.  A further £2.3 billion investment has been confirmed from 2019.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on how the 21st Century Schools money is allocated, specifically confirming if the money is allocated on a school by school basis or via the local authority's education improvement plan?
answer: The 21st Century Schools and Education Programme is a strategic investment programme jointly funded by Welsh Government and our delivery partners that will see investment of £1.4 billion over the five year period ending 2019 (Band A). A further £2.3 billion investment (Band B) has been confirmed from 2019.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether 21st Century School money can be used to facilitate the closure of either a primary or secondary school in Wales?

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What is the level of Welsh Government involvement in devising a local authority's school rebuilding programme that would benefit from 21st Century School money?
answer: Within the overall objectives set for the 21st Century Schools and Education Programme by Welsh Government, local authorities are required to submit a strategic programme of the school infrastructure investment needs within their area.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of the number of beneficiaries of the school uniform grant in Wales for the last five years, by local authority?
answer: A breakdown of the number of beneficiaries of the school uniform grant in Wales over the last five years, by local authority is provided below.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the sufficiency of Welsh Government funding allocated for school uniform grant in Wales and what analysis has been undertaken of whether any local authorities needed to top up the grant from their own funds?
answer: A breakdown of the number of beneficiaries of the school uniform grant in Wales over the last five years, by local authority is provided below.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How does Welsh Government monitor whether the statutory right to an Individual Mental Health Advocate is adhered to on mental health inpatient wards in Wales, including on older people's mental health wards in Wales?
answer: There is a statutory duty to provide information about the right and availability of advocacy services and all health boards submit quarterly all-ages data on the provision of Independent Mental Health Advocacy (IMHA) under Part 4 of the Mental Health (Wales) Measure.  This dataset was developed during 2016-17 to provide assurance that every person has contact with an IMHA within five working days of their request.  The data provided by health boards show that they are meeting this standard.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: When was the last round of spot checks on older people's mental health wards in Wales and what steps is the Cabinet Secretary taking to ensure high quality care on those wards?
answer: The spot checks of older people’s mental health wards were conducted in November and December of 2014 and 22 wards of 51 units in Wales were visited. An All Wales report was compiled bringing together results and good practice from all the visits to enable further improvement action to take place.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why the Welsh Government has chosen to use the 2016 Pupil Level Annual School Census data rather than more recent data to calculate the Pupil Development Grant awards for the 2018/19 financial year?
answer: The Welsh Government has used the 2016 pupil level annual school census data as the basis for allocations for 2018-19 because the number of pupils eligible for free school meals has fallen over recent years.  Using the 2016 data has allowed us to direct more money overall to schools.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Is the Welsh Government playing a part in the decision on the application to identify fields in Llanerch, Llanelli as a greenfield site?
answer: Local residents have submitted an application to register the site as a Village Green. This is a matter for the Local Planning Authority, which is Carmarthenshire County Council, and the Welsh Ministers have no role in the process.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What steps does the Cabinet Secretary suggest that Carmarthenshire County Council should take so that the planning committee can decide on a matter that conflicts with the council's own modernising education programme, as well as the Welsh Government's 21st Century Schools programme?
answer: Responsibility for the day to day operation of the planning system lies with Local Planning Authorities in the first instance. It is for Carmarthenshire County Council to determine the relevant planning application in accordance with the policies set out in its adopted Local Development Plan, unless material considerations, such as representations from the public, lead the Council to decide otherwise.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary held regarding Hywel Dda University Health Board's failure to provide an out-of-hours GP service for periods over the weekend at the end of March 2018?
answer: I meet regularly with all NHS Chairs and Chief Executives collectively, and individually with individual organisational Chairs and Chief Executives, where a range of issues are discussed.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether Wales will receive payment for mud from Hinkley Point when it is dumped off the coast of south Wales?
answer: Wales will not receive payment for sediment disposed of at the Cardiff Grounds disposal site. No payment is received at the point of deposit. There is a fee for the determination of the Marine Licence to gain permission to carry out the activity, but not for the activity itself.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: In light of targets announced by the UK Government and Scottish Government to phase out the sale of new diesel and petrol vehicles, is the Welsh Government also considering setting an earlier target than 2040?
answer: The UK Government’s target is to phase out the sale of diesel and petrol cars and vans by 2040 through its commitment to end the registration of such vehicles from 2040.  We recognise that this measure will be the key driver in phasing out conventional fuel vehicles and encouraging the uptake of low emission vehicles and that vehicle registration remains a reserved matter.  Whilst setting a devolved target based on a reserved measure is likely to be problematic, we would encourage the UK Government to consider bringing forward the date for ending such registrations and will be consulting this summer, as part of our decarbonisation programme, on measures the Welsh Government should take forward to encourage an earlier uptake of low emission vehicles.

name: Gareth Bennett
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the number of unregistered schools and educational establishments in Wales?
answer: Where unregistered provision is brought to our attention, immediate action is taken. When it has been confirmed that an education setting is operating outside of the law the Welsh Government directs the setting to stop providing education on a full time basis until they are registered with the Welsh Government.

name: Gareth Bennett
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How many applications to open a school were turned down in 2017, and in the year to date; and can these be broken down by local authority area?
answer: Where unregistered provision is brought to our attention, immediate action is taken. When it has been confirmed that an education setting is operating outside of the law the Welsh Government directs the setting to stop providing education on a full time basis until they are registered with the Welsh Government.

name: Gareth Bennett
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How many schools have had their registration withdrawn in 2017, and in the year to date; and can these be broken down by local authority area?
answer: Where unregistered provision is brought to our attention, immediate action is taken. When it has been confirmed that an education setting is operating outside of the law the Welsh Government directs the setting to stop providing education on a full time basis until they are registered with the Welsh Government.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: NA
question: What steps is the Cabinet Secretary taking to promote and ensure the safe use of slings and hoists by care staff in Wales, and to ensure all those using such equipment are provided with comprehensive training?
answer: To be answered by: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What support is the Welsh Government considering for farmers who are experiencing low stocks of hay and silage, in light of reports that prices to purchase this feed have doubled?
answer: The late spring has created additional pressure on forage supplies in some parts of the country. I continue to monitor the situation and at this stage do not feel there is a need for Government intervention.

name: Suzy Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the Welsh Government has plans to implement immigration checks in the Welsh NHS?
answer: There is a legal requirement for local health boards to establish if the people to whom they are providing NHS hospital services are chargeable for those services, based on establishing whether they are normally resident in the UK or they have any other specific exemption from charging.  This requirement to establish whether hospital services are chargeable has been in place since 1989 and there are currently no plans to change the process by which these checks are made.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What plans does the Cabinet Secretary have to make advanced microprocessor-controlled knees available to patients in Wales who have undergone amputations?
answer: In Wales, NHS Prosthetic and Amputee Rehabilitation services are delivered in-house by three specialist Artificial Limb and Appliance Centres (ALAC) located in Cardiff, Swansea and Wrexham. The service is centrally commissioned by the Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee (WHSSC) on behalf of the seven Local Health Boards in Wales.

name: Angela Burns

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs

It was considered the issues are not of more than local importance and the application should not be called in for determination by the Welsh Ministers. The decision not to intervene was issued on 20 April 2018.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders

answer: Welsh Government does not hold this information.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
