answer: The purpose of the visit was to effectively represent Welsh interests on the international stage and learn lessons from agricultural and environmental policies in New Zealand. As we leave the EU it is more important than ever Wales is able to build constructive networks overseas. The costs of my visit will be published in due course as usual. I have outlined the objectives and outcomes of the visit in my recent Written Statement, please see attached link:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state what the franchise objectives for the next Wales and Borders rail franchise are, and advise as to a) what consultation has been undertaken with the public and politicians in relation to this, and b) whether any further consultation will be forthcoming?
answer: In the first quarter of 2016, an initial public consultation was held which aimed to inform the Welsh Government’s approach to procuring the next Wales and Borders Rail Service Contract.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What measures will the Welsh Government take to ensure that we have enough qualified nurses in Wales in both the short and long term to adhere to the Nurse Staffing Levels (Wales) Act 2016?
answer: The evidence base is unequivocal about how having the right number of registered nurses reduces morbidity and improves patient outcomes, and in Wales we are committed to ensuring the nursing workforce is fit to meet the diverse needs of our patients.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state whether she has received recommendations from the Wales Land Management Forum sub-group on agricultural pollution, and explain what the options tabled are for addressing concerns about agricultural pollution?
answer: I received the Wales Land Management Forum sub-group’s report on tackling agricultural pollution last week. I will be giving consideration to the report as well as the views of other stakeholders to inform next steps.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the fact that almost 9,000 trains were cancelled in Wales in 2016-17, and clarify whether reducing cancellations can be made a franchise objective?
answer: It is always disappointing when a service is cancelled and I sympathise with travellers' frustrations when it occurs. Arriva Trains Wales and Network Rail are working together via the Operations Governance Board to improve performance and minimise cancellations.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education

answer: We are currently considering the responses to the consultation on revisions to the School Organisation Code and will publish a summary before the summer recess.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment

answer: The design of any future scheme to reduce the risk of flooding and coastal erosion at Llandudno North Shore is the responsibility of the Risk Management Authority.

name: Sian Gwenllian

question: Following his written statement on 19 March 2018, will the Cabinet Secretary list the additional Welsh-language conditions that are now in the revised general medical services contract for 2018/2019?
answer: As part of the General Medical Services contract agreement for 2018/19 a baseline of Welsh Language provision will be identified at a cluster level which will provide a better understanding of the current availability of Welsh Language provision.

answer: It is proposed that Welsh Language duties will be placed on independent primary care providers, namely General Practitioners, General Dental Practitioners, Community Pharmacists and Optometrists through their primary care contracts or terms of service.

name: Sian Gwenllian

question: Will the Cabinet Secretary list the meetings that have been arranged to discuss the Welsh Language (No. 7) Regulations 2018 regarding primary care contracts or terms of service between providers and health boards, which will place duties on them to provide services in Welsh, as referred to on page 10 of the explanatory memorandum to the regulations?
answer: It is proposed that Welsh Language duties will be placed on independent primary care providers, namely General Practitioners, General Dental Practitioners, Community Pharmacists and Optometrists through their primary care contracts or terms of service.

answer: These questions are requests for recorded information and as such have been passed to the appropriate Division for answer as a freedom of information request.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education

answer: The Welsh Government has been mindful during our budget process of the requirements on Welsh Ministers to have due regard to the UN Convention of the Rights of the Child. We have taken an integrated approach to our impact assessment. A Strategic Integrated Impact Assessment of the high-level spending decisions was published as part of the outline draft Budget 2018-19.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary agree to meet with members of the Caerwnon Park Residents' Association to discuss their campaign to abolish the 10 percent commission on sales of park homes in Wales?
answer: I have considered all of the information that was submitted in response to the consultation and have arranged for additional work to be undertaken to review the accounts of those park owners who offered access to their financial records for review. I will be announcing my decision shortly.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following the National Assembly resolution on 14 February 2018 to establish a taskforce to look into the issue of unadopted roads in Wales, will the Cabinet Secretary provide details of membership, chairperson, lead secretariat/ contact, terms of reference, reporting timescales, date of first meeting and plans for public consultation?
answer: Discussions between officials and officers from the Welsh Local Government Association and Home Builders Federation are ongoing. Draft Terms of Reference is being developed as well as the governance arrangement for the review. These will be finalised at the Taskforce’s inaugural meeting. I am expecting advice on the resource requirements to support the review which is anticipated to commence in late May and completed in early 2019.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How many schools in Wales currently have asbestos assessment management plans?
answer: Information about asbestos management in schools is completed as part of our annual schools condition survey.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: With regard to Betsi Cadwaladr's waiting time reduction plan, how many referral cases have been treated in hospitals or services that are not managed by Betsi Cadwaladr Health Board since September 2017?
answer: This information is not held centrally.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: With regard to Betsi Cadwaladr's waiting time reduction plan, how much has the health board spent on hiring mobile theatres in order to support the reduction of waiting times?
answer: This information is not held centrally.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Children and Social Care
question: What steps will the Cabinet Secretary and Cabinet colleagues take to work to improve levels of upskilling amongst care staff in Wales, including agency staff, to ensure that appropriate care at home can be provided, particularly in a palliative setting?
answer: To support the training of care workers, the new All-Wales Induction framework for Health and Social Care, which came into effect on 1 April, sets out the essential skills and experience new workers should develop and provides a structure for employers to support their staff in gaining and safely evidencing this knowledge. Section 5 of the induction framework relates to Professional Learning and outlines the principles of continuous professional learning and provides a progress log for staff to evidence the training that they have received – and that it has been assessed - as meeting the necessary requirements. Social Care Wales also provides funding to the regions to deliver social care training across a range of priority areas which include Care and Support at Home.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

answer: All GP practices in Wales hold and maintain palliative care registers.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how many GP practices in Wales hold and maintain a palliative care register?
answer: All GP practices in Wales hold and maintain palliative care registers.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

answer: This information is not held centrally.  There is no single definition for ‘hospital at home care’ and by its very nature it will be a constantly changing figure.  As such any information held by individual health boards will be a ‘snapshot’ of patients in receipt of care at any given time.

name: Mark Reckless
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: When did the Welsh Government acquire its leasehold interest in the Cardiff Bus Station site and how much Stamp Duty Land Tax was paid on the transaction?
answer: The Welsh Government completed the purchase of a new 999 year lease on 29 March 2018; the transaction was not subject to Stamp Duty Land Tax.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What action is the Cabinet Secretary taking with regards to the regulation and monitoring of intensive poultry farming units in Wales?
answer: I will write to you as soon as possible and a copy of my letter will be published on the internet.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm if there are plans to re-tender contracts under the The Provision of Cleaning and Janitorial Materials Framework (NPS-CFM-0026-15) set to expire in September this year?
answer: The Provision of Cleaning and Janitorial Materials Framework will expire on 20 September 2018. There is an option to extend for a further 12 months until September 2019.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline what the Welsh Government is doing to ensure that contracts awarded under The Provision of Cleaning and Janitorial Materials Framework (NPS-CFM-0026-15) provide the best possible value for money for Welsh taxpayers?
answer: The Provision of Cleaning and Janitorial Materials Framework was competitively procured after being advertised through Sell2Wales. Fifty-nine per cent of spend to date is with Welsh-based SMEs.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state whether the Welsh Government monitors the use of the carparks at Wrexham Maelor Hospital, Glan Clwyd Hospital, and Ysbyty Gwynedd, and explain what measures can be taken to improve capacity and ensure that people with appointments can always find a place to park?
answer: The operation and management of car parking at hospital sites across NHS Wales is the responsibility of the individual health boards not Welsh Government. Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board is responsible for the operation of their three main hospital sites.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Further to WAQ76074, when will the Cabinet Secretary respond to the findings of the Natural Resources Wales consultation on the catch control byelaws for salmon and sea trout in Wales?
answer: NRW’s consultation on catch controls for salmon and sea trout on Welsh rivers generated a significant number of responses. My officials are currently considering these and other associated responses.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Children and Social Care
question: How does the Cabinet Secretary intend to address the estimated need for an additional £344m in funding for social care in Wales by 2021-22, as noted by the joint report by the WGLA and ADSS?
answer: Social care is one of five priorities in our national strategy, “Prosperity for All”. As such we invested an additional £55 million a year from 2017-18 and are investing a further £115 million over the next two years. This is to protect front line social care from the worst of the cuts imposed by the UK Government on the Welsh budget.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline what the Welsh Government is doing to ensure that Welsh-medium education schools are being promoted in marketing campaigns for new housing estates across Wales?
answer: We work with local authorities in their preparation of Welsh in Education Strategic Plans (WESPs). These are statutory three year plans aimed at developing Welsh-medium education in each area. Welsh Education Forums, consisting of head teachers, Mudiad Meithrin, Mentrau Iaith etc, and led by the authorities, have been established to advise on the implementation of WESPs. They also play a vital role in identifying opportunities to promote and raise local awareness of Welsh-medium education.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: How is the Welsh Government monitoring housing developers to ensure that Welsh-medium education schools are being promoted in any marketing strategies?
answer: There is no doubt that the Welsh Government has a role to play in working with new housing developers to agree a marketing strategy that promotes all schools without bias or disadvantage – be they English-medium or Welsh-medium.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: What discussions has the Welsh Government had with housing developers to ensure that Welsh-medium education schools are being promoted in marketing campaigns  for new housing estates across Wales?
answer: When it comes to the planning and promotion of Welsh-medium schools, my relationship is with Local Authorities. My priority is ensuring that the content of Welsh in Education Strategic Plans consider Welsh-medium education planning developments, and include opportunities, whatever they may be, for increasing Welsh-medium provision through housing development contributions (called section 106 agreements or obligations)

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain what measures, in addition to supporting the Get Up and Go campaign, the Welsh Government will take to ensure that those patients who can are encouraged to get out of bed in every hospital across Wales, to help tackle muscle loss during bed rest?
answer: We recognise the impact prolonged lengths of stay in hospital can have on patients’ mobility and independence and that research suggests that too much bed rest could do more harm than good. Keeping active, both physically and mentally helps patients keep up their strength and aid recovery so they can go home more quickly.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how much his recent trip to Noord-Holland cost, provide a breakdown of the expenditure and outline the benefits of the declaration of friendship?
answer: The Declaration of Friendship and Solidarity exemplifies our priority to build and strengthen Wales’ relationships with European regions beyond Brexit.  The Declaration includes commitments to work together for the benefit of citizens and businesses – demonstrated by the projects I visited whilst in Noord-Holland.  Costs of the visit will be published annually.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Children and Social Care
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how much each local authority has received from the £1.7million put forward by the Welsh Government to expand and improve play opportunities for children and young people?
answer: In December 2017, £629,000 was provided to local authorities to support the play agenda.  It was allocated using population, deprivation and sparsity measures specific to children for each Local Authority.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the fact that the number of full time equivalent staff recorded for hospital specialities as a whole in Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board in 2015, 2016, and 2017, was lower than 2014, and explain why this health board has not seen increases?
answer: Although there is now a record number of staff working in the Welsh NHS, there remain challenges recruiting to some medical specialities. This is a UK wide issue and the health board is not alone in experiencing similar difficulties.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many Freedom of Information Requests were submitted by Assembly Members to the Welsh Government in 2015, 2016, 2017, and how many were answered within the statutory time frame?
answer: The figures requested are in the table below. These figures refer to all requests made under the statutory access to information regime and include requests made under the Freedom of Information Act 2000, The Data Protection Act 1998 and the Environmental Information Regulations 2004. This is consistent with the way statistics on information requests are published.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the outcome of the Welsh Government's request to Conwy and Denbighshire on 14 December 2017, inviting them to prepare a joint local development plan?
answer: Following my invitation to both Local Authorities to optimise the plan preparation process and deliver better outcomes by preparing a Joint Local Development Plan, I have received responses from both authorities confirming they have the commitment, capacity and resources to prepare individual Local Development Plans. I have agreed they may progress individual LDPs subject to a number of stringent conditions in relation to the time taken to prepare the LDP, the need for effective collaboration on cross border issues and the potential impact of local government reform proposals.

name: David Melding
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: What procedures are in place to mitigate children's exposure to air pollution in schools and nurseries throughout Wales?
answer: Our new statutory policy guidance recognises schools, amongst others, as “sensitive receptor locations” and in doing so requires local authorities to give special consideration to the same when carrying out their duties of local air quality management.

name: David Melding
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: What use is made of air pollution monitors in schools and nurseries in Wales when assessing children's exposure to poor air quality?
answer: We issued new statutory policy guidance to local authorities in Wales last year which recognises schools and active travel routes, amongst others, as “sensitive receptor locations” and in doing so requires local authorities to give special consideration to the same.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how many functioning collaborative working partnerships between local authorities are operating in Wales currently, and provide a list of all such projects?
answer: There are a wide range of strategic partnerships operating in Wales which the Welsh Government have a role in, for example Education Consortia; delivering school improvement services via an agreed National Model for Regional Working.  The Welsh Government is also aware of a number of operational partnerships between local authorities such as the Shared Regulatory Services in Cardiff, the Vale of Glamorgan and Bridgend, and the North Wales Residual Waste Treatment Project between Gwynedd, Anglesey, Conwy, Denbighshire and Flintshire.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of rates relief for small businesses in the years 2010-11, 2011-12, 2012-13, 2013-14, 2014-15, 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18 as well as the percentages of small businesses provided with a tax cut in these years?
answer: Statistics on non-domestic rates relief for both the mandatory and discretionary schemes operating in Wales are published on StatsWales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What action is the Cabinet Secretary taking to monitor whether general practice palliative care registers are identifying people with conditions such as dementia and older people with frailty who are approaching the end of their life?
answer: Through the General Medical Services Contract: Quality and Outcomes Framework contractors are required to have GP practice palliative care registers that establish and maintain a register of all patients in need of palliative care/support irrespective of age or condition. The contractor is also required to have regular (at least 2 monthly) multi-disciplinary case review meetings where the team can ensure all aspects of a patient’s care have been assessed and future care can be co-ordinated and planned proactively.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Assembly Commission

answer: First class travel can be provided where it is strictly necessary for work related reasons and where an application is supported by an authorising officer. This may be for the following reasons:

name: Andrew R.T. Davies

answer: I can confirm that legal advice was sought in advance of presenting the letter to the Presiding Officer.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the establishment of a task-force to address problems arising from unadopted roads in Wales?
answer: Officials are continuing discussions with the Welsh Local Government Association and Home Builders Federation. They have developed draft terms of reference, governance arrangement and commenced scoping the areas that will be covered by the Review.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister confirm whether any form of legal advice or guidance was taken prior to drafting and issuing his letter to the Presiding Officer ahead of the debate on the leak inquiry in Plenary on 18 April 2018, and confirm who provided this advice?
answer: Legal advice and guidance was provided by the Counsel General supported by the Welsh Government’s Legal Services Department and a member of the Welsh Government’s Panel Counsel.

name: Suzy Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: When considering a Swansea Bay Metro, will the Cabinet Secretary provide details of what proposals from which individuals, groups, or organisations have been considered to date?
answer: Swansea County Council are leading on this project in partnership with Carmarthenshire County Council, Neath Port Talbot County Borough Council and Pembrokeshire County Council. Consultants AECOM have been appointed to develop the South West Wales Metro concept and relevant stakeholders and interested parties have been involved. We are awaiting a report on that initial work from Swansea. I have allocated a further £700,000 to Swansea County Council in 2018-19 to ensure the business case work can continue without delay.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the availability of prostate artery embolisation on the NHS in Wales?
answer: Prostate artery embolization is not routinely offered in the NHS in Wales. We expect health boards to provide evidence-based care, following the publication of the NICE guidelines regarding this treatment; I expect health boards to review their pathways accordingly. I have asked the Welsh Urology Board to review the availability of this treatment and to advise health boards accordingly.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the closure of the A40 between Llanwrda and Llandovery and its impact on travellers?
answer: The A40 between Llandovery and Llanwrda was closed on 18 April due to the partial collapse of a water culvert. On 25 April the road was partially reopened and the diversion route through Llangadog removed. Traffic signals will continue to be in operation to allow the completion of the works, which we anticipate taking approximately two weeks.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: When will the Cabinet Secretary publish a response to the consultation on the mandatory concessionary fare scheme which ended on 12 January 2018?
answer: The consultation about maintaining free bus travel for older people, disabled people and some injured service veterans ended on 12 January. During the consultation, 456 unique responses were received from passenger groups and individuals. I expect to publish the outcome report shortly.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to increase the age threshold for concessionary bus passes in line with increase in the state pension age?
answer: The consultation about maintaining free bus travel for older people, disabled people and some injured service veterans ended on 12 January. During the consultation, 456 unique responses were received from passenger groups and individuals. I expect to publish the outcome report shortly.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What assurances will the Cabinet Secretary provide to those currently in receipt of a concessionary bus pass that they will retain the same concessions following the consultation review?
answer: The consultation about maintaining free bus travel for older people, disabled people and some injured service veterans ended on 12 January. During the consultation, 456 unique responses were received from passenger groups and individuals. I expect to publish the outcome report shortly.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following the written statement on 25 April 2018 regarding the M4 corridor around Newport project, will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the Welsh Government will table a motion that will be subject to a vote as part of the promised debate?
answer: My statement of 25 April provided the most up-to-date information on the M4 Corridor around Newport project. Further information on the debate will be made available in due course.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how many recorded intensive poultry units in Wales recorded non-compliance during the latest inspection period (2017-18), and state how enforcement will be taken against repeat offenders?
answer: Larger intensive poultry units with 40,000 or more poultry places are closely regulated by Natural Resources Wales (NRW) under the environmental permitting regime in accordance with the requirements of the Industrial Emissions Directive.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a commitment to bring forward a database in Wales, similar to the UK Environment Agency's online register of enforcement actions database, which provides information on all formal cautions and prosecutions against companies, to assist consumers in making an educated choice in sourcing poultry products?
answer: Natural Resources Wales (NRW) already maintains a public register of information in relation to the environmental permits they have issued.  The public register includes the application, the permit and associated monitoring data, inspection records and enforcement information.  It can be accessed by contacting NRW directly.  In addition, NRW is in the process of developing an online platform for public register information.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary commit to working with Conwy County Borough Council to ensure that Llandudno North Shore is returned to a sandy beach, in a long-term sustainable and environmentally sound manner, and urgently address the build-up of debris and decaying sealife caught in the quarry rocks?
answer: We are already working closely with Conwy County Borough Council to carry out preparatory work for a future scheme to reduce the risk of coastal flooding and erosion.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many of the health boards in Wales have met the 26-week target for first appointment when it comes to accessing autistic diagnostic services?
answer: The 26 week neurodevelopmental waiting time target is currently being piloted with health boards prior to formal introduction. Piloting allows us and health boards to test the appropriateness of data definitions; reporting and data capture systems; and data robustness ahead of formal introduction. The intention is to commence formal reporting later in 2018 at which point we will work with health boards to consider what further action, if any, is required for any health board not meeting the target. Performance against targets is kept under review by Welsh Government and discussed at the regular meetings I have with the Vice Chairs of the health boards.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What actions will be taken by Welsh Government against those health boards failing to meet the 26 week average waiting period for a first appointment for accessing autistic diagnostic services?
answer: The 26 week neurodevelopmental waiting time target is currently being piloted with health boards prior to formal introduction. Piloting allows us and health boards to test the appropriateness of data definitions; reporting and data capture systems; and data robustness ahead of formal introduction. The intention is to commence formal reporting later in 2018 at which point we will work with health boards to consider what further action, if any, is required for any health board not meeting the target. Performance against targets is kept under review by Welsh Government and discussed at the regular meetings I have with the Vice Chairs of the health boards.

name: Lynne Neagle

answer: Specific budgets are not set for pharmacy or GP tobacco control work or smoking cessation services. Local health boards determine how much is required to fund this work and services locally. answer: Natural Resources Wales (NRW) took a decision to postpone the implementation of any potential new measures on catch controls for salmon and sea trout on Welsh rivers, until after the 2018 seasons. This was done to avoid confusion for anglers, in the current season, which has already started.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: In relation to the decision to introduce non-invasive prenatal tests, will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how widely the Welsh Government consulted with people with Down’s syndrome and families where a member has Down’s Syndrome?
answer: The Welsh Government follows the expert advice of the UK National Screening Committee (UK NSC), which recommended that NIPT should be offered to women who have a higher chance result following Down‘s, Edward‘s and Patau‘s screening as part of an evaluative implementation. This recommendation took into account the conclusions of an ethics workshop held in January 2016, which confirmed that no new ethical issues were raised by the use of NIPT as a test. The antenatal screening programme in Wales already offers testing which estimates the chance of a baby having Down‘s syndrome and has done so for many years. The new test has been included in the screening offer in Wales from 30th April 2018

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs

answer: We take animal welfare seriously and expect others to do so. Those who commit the worst acts of animal of cruelty should face tough punishments and we have agreed to the UK Parliament legislating for England and Wales to increase the maximum sentence for animal cruelty offences from six months to five years. Officials are working together on the introduction of Animal Welfare (Sentencing and Recognition of Sentience) Bill which underlines our commitment to continue improving standards of animal health and welfare in Wales.

The change in the process of how women are able to take the second pill in a termination of pregnancy will be informed by clinical stakeholders.

In recognition of this, and to support the transition to electric vehicles, the Welsh Government is investing £2m for additional electric charging points, with a focus on rapid chargers.

question: Will the First Minister explain whether the Welsh Government was responsible for selecting the 10 companies taking part in the trade mission to Qatar, and if so, state why only one of these were from north Wales?
answer: All companies have an opportunity to participate in trade missions and we do not set a limit on the number of companies able to apply for individual market visits.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: Further to WAQ76437 regarding developing Welsh winter sports talent, will the Cabinet Secretary state whether the Welsh Government would support the development of a new ski slope in north Wales, particularly given that Sport Wales are actively involved in proposals for an indoor skiing facility in Merthyr?
answer: I have written to you on this matter advising that the contact involved in the potential ski-slope project should get in touch with the North Wales Head of Appraisal within Tourism Development at the Welsh Government to arrange a meeting.  His contact details were provided.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why the Welsh Government is issuing right-to-enter notices to land owners, on routes other than the preferred route for the proposed Caernarfon bypass, to carry out ecological and topographical survey work up until December 2018?
answer: All surveys being undertaken relate to the preferred route. A number of the areas are some distance from the route due to the need to cover the maximum area relating to the foraging and commuting flight paths of bats.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how the Welsh Government is working with Public Health Wales to address concerns relating to potentially missed breast cancer scans, and confirm how he is ensuring that full communication is made with all those who may have been affected, as an immediate priority?
answer: On 11 May, I issued a written statement updating members on the breast screening issues in England and whether they affect Wales

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Children and Social Care
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the pilot schemes for free childcare, including the numbers of households covered, the numbers of families and children taking part, and the number of free childcare hours currently provided in total, per week?
answer: We began testing the offer in September 2017, working with seven Early Implementer Local Authorities (EILAs) - Blaenau Gwent, Caerphilly, Flintshire, Rhondda Cynon Taff, Swansea and Gwynedd and Anglesey.  Testing of the offer has expanded since then and from April 2018 the offer is available across the whole of Anglesey, Gwynedd, Blaenau Gwent, Caerphilly and Flintshire and in specific pilot areas within Rhondda Cynon Taff and Swansea.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Children and Social Care
question: What financial support will the Welsh Government give local authorities seeing rising costs of caring for children, given that figures from the Children and Family Court Advisory and Support Service show an increased number of section 31 applications issued annually?
answer: Safely reducing the numbers of children taken into care is a key aim of my Improving Outcomes for Children Ministerial Advisory Group. In 2017-18, Welsh Government announced an additional £8m of recurrent funding to local authorities to support looked after children and care leavers.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many women have presented to each local health board in Wales with problems relating to vaginal mesh in 2015-16, 2016-17, and 2017-18?
answer: The information provided below relates to the number of patients who have undergone procedures involving the total or partial removal or over sewing of mesh, which can be surrogate indicators for problems resulting from prior surgery:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how he will be working with local health boards across Wales to implement the recommendations of the report of the task and finish group on the use of vaginal synthetic mesh tape and sheets for stress urinary incontinence and pelvic organ prolapse?
answer: An implementation group directly reporting to me and under the chairmanship of Tracy Myhill, Chief Executive of ABMU Health Board will be established comprising representatives of NHS (Wales) and Welsh Government to plan and guide the implementation of the recommendations. In time this could be extended to oversee the implementation of other related areas of healthcare requiring urgent attention. I am anxious that the recommendations be implemented at pace and I will be engaging with the health boards to establish what local improvements can be made immediately.

name: Suzy Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the NHS Wales final mammogram screening process is being reviewed?
answer: On 11 May I issued a Written Statement updating members on the breast screening issues in England and whether they affect Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain the outcome of the community safety scheme promised for Glan Conwy in 2017/18, and state how the safety of the A470 will be improved for the community?
answer: A pedestrian crossing at Church Street will be considered under the Active Travel programme. We are also currently in the process of carrying out a three year Speed Limit Review, looking at road safety issues at over 600 sites on all trunk roads in Wales. Comments that we have received from the community will be taken on board as part of this process when this section of the A470 is reviewed. The results of the review will be made available online and any works arising from the wider review will be prioritised, as funding allows for a programmed completion over the next three to four years.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the number of infected badgers removed under the refreshed Bovine TB eradication programme that was launched in October 2017?
answer: In terms of reporting on the TB Eradication Programme, as you know I have committed to doing this formally on an annual basis at the appropriate time.  We are now 8 months into our refreshed TB Eradication Programme.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on road improvement between junction 34 and Sycamore Cross junction on the A48, with specific reference to potential construction dates, costings and Ministerial approval?
answer: Our National Transport Finance Plan 2017 Update sets out the investment for transport infrastructure and services from 2017 to 2020.  Under road schemes to be developed this includes to ‘explore options from Sycamore Cross to Junction 34’.  Further information can be found on our website at:

name: Leanne Wood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Welsh Government recommend that the Assembly give its consent to the Trade Bill?
answer: As we set out in our previous Legislative Consent Memorandum, whether consent should be given needs to be looked at in the light of any further amendments to the Trade Bill.

name: Leanne Wood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Welsh Government recommend that the Assembly give its consent to the Taxation (Cross-border Trade) Bill?
answer: The Welsh Government has not tabled a Legislative Consent Memorandum for this Bill. It does not intend to do so. Accordingly no question of recommending legislative consent for this Bill arises.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide more detail as to how the employability plan will effectively tackle the gender pay gap in Wales, including a clear plan of action that will be taken by the Welsh Government?
answer: The goal of our recently published Employability Plan is to provide opportunities for all individuals to gain the skills, enthusiasm, drive and creativity to fulfil their potential, irrespective of their gender.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on research conducted by the Welsh Government into domestic electrical fires?
answer: Carl Sargeant wrote to AMs in October last year advising that we were undertaking research into the increase in certain types of domestic electrical fires. That research is now being finalised and I will report the findings before the summer recess.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the Welsh Government's review of Fire and Rescue Service reports of actual fires?
answer: Carl Sargeant wrote to AMs in October last year advising that we were undertaking research into the increase in certain types of domestic electrical fires. That research is now being finalised and I will report the findings before the summer recess.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many full bursary packages have been made available for each of the last four academic years and how many were awarded in each of those years?
answer: The NHS Bursary Scheme in England was replaced with a grant based system for students commencing their studies from September 2017.  In Wales, the NHS Bursary Scheme was retained in full for those individuals prepared to commit to working in Wales for a period of up to two years following qualification. These arrangements were put in place for the academic year of 2017/2018. Due to the length of the training programmes supported by the bursary, the first cohort have not yet completed their studies and as a result information about post qualification employment is not yet available.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: For the latest cohort available, what percentage of individuals since the launch of the NHS Wales bursary have remained working in Wales beyond the agreed two years?
answer: The NHS Bursary Scheme in England was replaced with a grant based system for students commencing their studies from September 2017.  In Wales, the NHS Bursary Scheme was retained in full for those individuals prepared to commit to working in Wales for a period of up to two years following qualification. These arrangements were put in place for the academic year of 2017/2018. Due to the length of the training programmes supported by the bursary, the first cohort have not yet completed their studies and as a result information about post qualification employment is not yet available.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: For the latest cohort available, what percentage of individuals since the launch of the NHS Wales bursary have relocated outside of Wales before the end of the agreed 2 years, and what mechanisms are in place to recoup this funding?
answer: The NHS Bursary Scheme in England was replaced with a grant based system for students commencing their studies from September 2017.  In Wales, the NHS Bursary Scheme was retained in full for those individuals prepared to commit to working in Wales for a period of up to two years following qualification. These arrangements were put in place for the academic year of 2017/2018. Due to the length of the training programmes supported by the bursary, the first cohort have not yet completed their studies and as a result information about post qualification employment is not yet available.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Following the publication of the interim report of the UK Government's mental health review, how is the Welsh Government collaborating with the UK Government to ensure that any recommendations made in regard to legislation and practice will be relevant to Wales?
answer: Welsh Government officials continue to engage with the independent review process through membership on the Advisory Panel to the review. The Wales Alliance for Mental Health is also represented on this group.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Following the announcement by the UK Government that it will be employing 200 clinical endoscopists and 300 reporting radiographers to improve access to cancer treatment, when will the Welsh Government be publishing a workforce plan for Wales's cancer services?
answer: Our approach to improving cancer services and outcomes is set out in the Cancer Delivery Plan for Wales which was updated in November 2016. It includes a particular focus on detecting cancers earlier, at more treatable stages and supporting ongoing improvement in the quality of services.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary working with police and local authorities to promote the safety of motorcyclists on Welsh roads, following the tragic deaths of of two bikers in north Wales over the recent bank holiday weekend?
answer: I was sorry to learn of the recent fatal collisions and we await the formal police reports which will help us to understand the factors relating to these specific incidents.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish the papers and minutes of the Welsh Marine Fisheries Advisory Group, and confirm how often the pages relating to this group are updated on the Welsh Government website?
answer: I will write to you as soon as possible and a copy of my letter will be published on the internet.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how much each ministerial department within the Welsh Government spent on external consultants during the financial year 2017-18?
answer: Welsh Government expenditure on consultancy in 2017-18 by ministerial portfolio is set out below:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What action is the Cabinet Secretary taking to ensure the timely response by local health boards to concerns and complaints raised with them, and what steps are being taken to improve response times in this regard?
answer: The NHS (Concerns Complaints and Redress Arrangements) (Wales) Regulations require health boards and Trusts to take all reasonable steps to respond to concerns within 30 working days of receipt.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update of how the recommendations of the NRW Flood Investigation Report: Llanrwst Flooding December 2015 have been taken forward, and include a timeline?
answer: NRW are continuing to progress the actions to address the recommendations from their flood investigation report following the Llanrwst flooding. Of the actions set out in the report, to date, 14 are complete with a further 8 in progress.  Many of those still in progress require the completion of other work in order to implement the action.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: NA
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the fact that the Welsh Ambulance Service has the highest sickness absence of NHS organisations in Wales since 2008, and explain whether the Welsh Government will cooperate with the trust to identify the cause of the high rate and implement helpful measures?
answer: To be answered by: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the fact that the Welsh Ambulance Service has had the highest sickness absence of NHS organisations in Wales since 2008, and explain whether the Welsh Government will cooperate with the Trust to identify the cause of the high rate and implement helpful measures?
answer: By the very nature of the vital role our ambulance staff perform every day in our Welsh communities, you might expect that the Trust has a higher level of absence compared to other parts of NHS Wales. The health and wellbeing of staff is taken very seriously both by the Trust and by Welsh Government. A combination of initiatives by the Trust and Welsh Government has seen absence levels between 2014/15 and 2016/17 reduce from 8.3% to 6.8%.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary respond to road safety concerns caused by vehicles parking along the A5 by Llyn Ogwen, and outline what measures the Welsh Government, in conjunction with relevant authorities, will take to address this roadside parking problem?
answer: A draft report on parking issues in this area is currently being produced, which will outline potential improvement options. The delivery of any changes will be subject to budget availability and will be prioritised against other similar schemes across Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the appropriateness of the 60mph speed limit along the A470 from Zip World Fforest to the A5, and explain whether it could be reduced to 40mph to improve safe access to and from the tourism businesses at that location?
answer: At present, there are no plans to reduce the speed limit on the A470 from Zip World Fforest to the A5. However, as you are aware, we are currently in the process of carrying out a three year Speed Limit Review, looking at road safety issues at over 600 sites on all trunk roads in Wales. My officials will consider your comments as part of this process when this section of the A470 is reviewed. The results of the review will be made available online and any works arising from the wider review will be prioritised, as funding allows for a programmed completion over the next three to four years.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the recently refused application for a cycle path between RSPB Conwy and Glan Conwy will be reconsidered, and state whether some of the £60 million investment in active travel over the next three years might be used to fund this project?
answer: Conwy County Borough Council submitted a bid for funding of £1.26m from the Local Transport Fund for 2017-18 for phase 1 of the proposed Glan Conwy to RSPB active travel route. Phase 1 included the construction of a route through the RSPB Site and a new bridge over the Llandudno to Blaenau Ffestiniog rail line.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how much of the £3.5m investment to improve the on-bus and bus stop environment will be received by each local authority, and explain why this funding is not aimed at improving bus services for rural communities, such as Ysbyty Ifan?
answer: Of the additional £3.5m, £3m was allocated to local authorities as part of their 2017-18 Bus Services Support Grant (BSSG) allocations, and in accordance with the formula used to allocate the earlier allocation of £25m in BSSG for 2017-18.  This brings the total of BSSG allocated to local authorities for 2017-18 to £28m.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What consideration has the Cabinet Secretary given to undertaking a review into learning disability mortality rates in Wales?
answer: Improving the mortality rates for people with a learning disability is a priority for us in Wales. We have recently undertaken a whole scale review of learning disabilities services and the soon to be published  ‘Improving Lives’ report makes important recommendations about how we must try and reduce the health inequalities, people with learning disabilities experience. We will use these recommendations and the findings from the recently published LeDeR report[1] in England to ensure we develop the most effective way of both reviewing and improving the mortality rates in Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Further to WAQ75930, will the Cabinet Secretary state which local authorities actually used the money allocated to them on providing free town centre parking, and explain why some might have not done so?
answer: We need to recognise that there are different approaches to supporting the vitality and viability of town centres and we respect that the funding allocated to local authorities will be used in different ways in line with local considerations.  This includes, in some areas, the decision not to support new pilot activity.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm when work will progress on the restoration of the headframes (which are in Welsh Government ownership) at Cefn Coed Museum, Neath Port Talbot?
answer: Engineering Consultants have been appointed to manage the restoration of the head frame structures at Cefn Coed Museum on behalf of the Welsh Government. Following the conclusion of the necessary design work agreement will be required with the Local Authority Planning Department to the proposed restoration to enable the works contract to be tendered. It is currently anticipated that work will commence on site in late 2018.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why the number of new entrants for initial teacher education at primary and secondary level are below target, and state what measures the Welsh Government will now take to encourage more into teaching, including those able to do so in Welsh?
answer: We want teaching in Wales to be a first choice profession so that we can attract the very best.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: NA
question: Will the Welsh Government release the number of follow-up patients currently waiting for an ophthalmology outpatient appointment in Wales who are past their target date, by health board, following confirmation by Welsh Government officials at the most recent Cross-Party Group on Vision that this data is available?
answer: To be answered by: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary had with universities in Wales about the implementation of Universities UK 's framework to improve the mental health and well being of students?
answer: I have regular meetings with Universities in Wales and I am aware that our institutions are committed to working to improve the mental health and wellbeing of students and staff.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What action is the Welsh Government taking to ensure that young people are financially literate when leaving school?
answer: Financial education has been part of the school curriculum in Wales since 2008 and through the ‘Manage money’ element, has been a statutory requirement in the National Literacy and Numeracy Framework (LNF) for 5 to 14 year-olds since September 2013.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Of the £50 million recently provided to health boards to reduce waiting times, how much will each health board need to repay if they have not been able to reach their agreed targets?
answer: The publication of the March RTT, diagnostic and therapy waiting times on 17 May 2018 showed a 2% improvement on the all-Wales 36 week waits, a 69% improvement in diagnostic eight week waits and a 90% improvement in therapy 14 week waits compared to March 2017.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline details of any management internship schemes offered within NHS Wales?
answer: Academi Wales has run a number of cohorts of the NHS Wales Graduate Scheme.  These arrangements are changing and, in the future, Academi Wales is planning a Public Sector wide Graduate Scheme in Wales, which would include the NHS Wales.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: In relation to WAQ75489, is the Cabinet Secretary satisifed with each health board's proposals to prepare for increased demand for endoscopy services as a result of the introduction of the faecal immunochemical test (FIT), and what guidance or support will the Welsh Government be providing to LHBS to ensure proposals are robust?
answer: Public Health Wales (PHW) is leading on the implementation of the faecal immunochemical test (FIT) in Wales.  The introduction of FIT in the bowel screening programme will offer a more sensitive test that is more acceptable to participants.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on progress towards introducing a localised form of a tourism tax?
answer: The Welsh Government is working with the tourism sector, the Welsh Local Government Association and other organisations and businesses to explore ways in which local authorities could be given permissive powers to develop and implement a local tourism tax in the future.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary had to date with the Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services about localised taxes and how they fit into his plans for local government reform?
answer: I have regular discussions with the Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services about delivering Prosperity for All: the national strategy. I am exploring the potential for localised taxes and the potential to reform the existing suite of local taxes. These explorations are grounded in a wider context of the Welsh Government’s commitment to stronger and more sustainable local government and the commitments set out in our tax work plan. The Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services is exploring the scope for additional powers and flexibilities for local authorities which could help them to deliver transformed and modernised services. He has invited local authorities to come forward with their ideas. Some of the ideas include different approaches to raising revenue locally.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the Welsh Government's progress towards its commitment to eradicating fuel poverty in Wales by 2018?
answer: The three key factors which influence whether a household will be in fuel poverty, and the severity of the fuel poverty are income levels, fuel prices and the energy efficiency of the home. The first two factors are outside the control of the Welsh Government and so our focus continues to be on investing significantly in domestic energy efficiency improvements. My Welsh Government Warm Homes programme which includes our fuel poverty schemes Nest and Arbed is delivering on this to several thousand of low income households and those households living in deprived communities. For the period 2017-2021 I am investing £104 million to help up to a further 25,000 fuel poor households receive free energy efficiency measures.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the effect that increases in charges for using local authority sports pitches will have on independent sports clubs?
answer: Local authorities face tough budgetary challenges, especially in respect of services and facilities which they provide on a non-statutory basis.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What discussions and/or correspondence have taken place between the Welsh Government and Arriva Trains Wales in the past six months, in relation to a possible extension to the term over which Arriva Trains Wales manages rail services in Wales?
answer: As part of the demobilisation process for the current franchise, discussions have been held between Welsh Government/Transport for Wales and Arriva Trains Wales to ensure rail services would continue to operate in the unlikely event that the procurement process is delayed.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What guidance is issued to local CAMHS teams to ensure looked after children who are in temporary placements are able to access CAMHS support if needed, or are able to access CAMHS services if placed in a local authority area that is not the initial place of their care order?
answer: General guidance from the Chief Medical Officer on looked after children is available to CAMHS teams. It is not mental health specific. CAMHS teams should follow this guidance when they are made aware that the child is a looked after child.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on access to advocacy services for looked after children and outline what funding is in place to ensure all looked after children can have timely access to an advocate?
answer: The National Approach to Statutory Advocacy services for children and young people has been rolled out across Wales since July 2017.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care
question: In relation to WAQ75259, will the Cabinet Secretary provide information on the use of the St David's Day fund, outlining how many care leavers applied to use the fund, how many received funding and how much was awarded in financial support to all care leavers?
answer: Following WAQ75259, end of year returns have not yet been received from all local authorities in Wales. My officials are working to collate and analyse the use of all the additional £9m, including the £1m St David’s Day Fund, allocated to support looked after children and care leavers in 2017-18. We will have this information by July and I have asked my officials to write to you with the details.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: To what level does the Welsh Government intend to ask the UK Government to raise the capital borrowing cap?
answer: At this stage in proceedings I have written to the Chief Secretary to the Treasury to signal that I will be seeking an increase to the Welsh Government’s annual and aggregate borrowing limits as part of the next Spending Review. The actual level of borrowing will be subject to more detailed discussions as we begin our preparations in earnest.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport

answer: The Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs is responsible for minerals planning in Wales and the British Geological Survey was commissioned to produce Mineral Resources Maps for Wales in 2009.  These maps indicate the sporadic and limited nature of metallic minerals in Wales. name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What consideration will the Cabinet Secretary give to calls for hair and beauty to be designated as a named economy within the foundation economy in Wales?
answer: The Welsh Government recognises that the hair and beauty sector offers valuable employment and training opportunities for people across Wales. The Welsh Government supports a range of training to support the hair and beauty sector. During 2016/17 there were 810 apprenticeship programme starts and 2,890 further education learner starts in the sector. The Welsh Government also supports the sector through its Business Wales service, which provides Welsh micro-businesses and SMEs, and aspiring entrepreneurs of all ages with the information, advice and support they require to start and grow their businesses. The Welsh Government would welcome proposals from the sector on how the sector can help deliver the calls to action set out in the Welsh Government's Economic Action Plan.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide information on the number of businesses that have received support through project Helix?
answer: The overall performance target is for 403 businesses to be assisted by 2023.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Does the Cabinet Secretary plan to replace the current target to eradicate fuel poverty by 2018, given that, if current schemes continue at the same rate, it would take 48 years to eradicate fuel poverty in Wales?
answer: The commitment made within in The Fuel Poverty Strategy of 2010 stated as far as reasonably practicable, fuel poverty will be eradicated in Wales in 2018. I have asked my officials to prepare a new Fuel Poverty Plan following the availability, at the end of 2018 of updated fuel poverty data. Welsh Government will also involve stakeholders in developing future actions on tackling fuel poverty in Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the service provided to Welsh patients at the gender identity cinic, and explain whether it is acceptable that some are receiving letters from consultants at the clinic transcribed almost two months after dictation?
answer: The Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee (WHSSC) is responsible for the planning of specialised services on behalf of local health boards, this includes gender identity services. The aim of WHSSC is to ensure the population of Wales has fair and equitable access to the full range of specialist services.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: How much will each individual local authority receive of the £15 million of capital funding made available to further improve recycling collection systems and infrastructure, and explain on what exactly the money can be spent?
answer: The additional £15 million capital funding over three years will be administered through the Waste and Resource Efficiency Division’s Collaborative Change Programme (CCP) and Infrastructure Team. The money will be allocated on a discretionary basis to support major service changes to Local Authority recycling, the provision of additional infrastructure to help Local Authorities recycle a wider range of materials and, where appropriate, to procure material and equipment used in supporting an all Wales Behaviour Change Campaign.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How much money is being invested in the National Academy for Educational Leadership, how much is coming from the Welsh Government, and is it enough to provide strategic support for all leaders and aspiring leaders in Welsh education?
answer: The National Academy for Educational Leadership will receive grant funding of £1m per annum. This funding will help ensure that the NAEL will nurture and inspire leaders now and for the future across the entire system in both Welsh and English medium settings.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many requests for planning applications to be determined by Welsh Ministers were received in 2015-16, 2016-17, and 2017-18, and give the number of those actually considered?
answer: The following table details the number of requests for planning applications to be called in during the financial years 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Given that the Welsh Government has stated that Visit Wales marketing generated an additional value of £356 million to the Welsh economy in 2017, what evidence was used for this figure?
answer: The figure is an estimate of visitor spend influenced by Visit Wales marketing activity. £345 million is attributable to consumer marketing and a further £11 million to travel trade activity. A sample of consumers who have visited the website, or had some other interaction with Visit Wales marketing, are asked if they visited Wales in 2017 and if  these trips to Wales were definitely influenced by the communications and information provided by Visit Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: After complaints by local authorities about missing funds from the Gypsy, Roma, Traveller and minority ethnic element of the education improvement grant in the 2018-19 budget, what assurances can the Cabinet Secretary provide to local authority leaders that this will not happen to other grants in the 2019-2020 budget?
answer: The reprioritisation of resources through the Welsh Government budget is a matter for the Cabinet Secretary for Finance and the relevant portfolio Cabinet Secretaries.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary had with the Cabinet Secretary for Education on the Education Improvement Grant provided to local authorities in 2018-19 and what were the outcomes of these discussions?
answer: The Education Improvement Grant is the responsibility of the Cabinet Secretary for Education.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the total amount of money spent on providing infrastructure and utilities at Parc Felindre business park, directly from Welsh Government, the European Union, the former WDA and local government since the site came into public ownership?
answer: The annual audited accounts for the joint venture show that the spend on the Parc Felindre site prior to 2007 by the former WDA, the Welsh European Funding Office and the City and County of Swansea was £24.9 million. This expenditure was for site acquisition, remediation and off site highway improvements. Post 2007, spend to provide site infrastructure and utilities from the Welsh Government was £2.9m. The City and County of Swansea received £6.87m of EU funds to deliver its Felindre Strategic Business Park project which also received match-funding of £1.77m from the Welsh Government’s Targeted Match Fund. No concerns have been raised with the Welsh Government team dealing with this site in relation to incomplete services and utilities at Parc Felindre.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport

answer: The annual audited accounts for the joint venture show that the spend on the Parc Felindre site prior to 2007 by the former WDA, the Welsh European Funding Office and the City and County of Swansea was £24.9 million. This expenditure was for site acquisition, remediation and off site highway improvements. Post 2007, spend to provide site infrastructure and utilities from the Welsh Government was £2.9m. The City and County of Swansea received £6.87m of EU funds to deliver its Felindre Strategic Business Park project which also received match-funding of £1.77m from the Welsh Government’s Targeted Match Fund. No concerns have been raised with the Welsh Government team dealing with this site in relation to incomplete services and utilities at Parc Felindre.

name: Bethan Sayed

answer: We obtain estimates of the proportion of young people not in education, employment or training from the Annual Population Survey. Due to the small sample size we publish the data as a 3 year average to produce more robust estimates.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What steps is the Welsh Government taking to address youth homelessness in Wales?
answer: In 2016 the Welsh Government launched the ‘Welsh Youth Homelessness Positive Pathway’, which sets out a comprehensive approach to helping young people avoid homelessness. We believe this is the best approach to planning local services for young people, and are working to embed this approach across government, in particular in relation to access to mental health services.

We believe this is the best approach to planning local services for young people, and are working to embed this approach across government, in particular in relation to access to mental health services.
