name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What provisions are currently available to assist armed forces veterans who have become homeless?
answer: The Housing (Wales) Act 2014 contains provisions that ensure people receive help to prevent and relieve their homelessness. People who have been homeless since leaving the armed forces are contained within the priority need categories and as such should be provided with suitable emergency accommodation.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What estimate has the Cabinet Secretary made of the number of armed forces veterans classed as homeless in each of the last 10 years?
answer: The Housing (Wales) Act 2014 contains provisions that ensure people receive help to prevent and relieve their homelessness. People who have been homeless since leaving the armed forces are contained within the priority need categories and as such should be provided with suitable emergency accommodation.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: In light of events in Powys County Council, will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on removing barriers faced by those with disabilities in standing for election and working as elected representatives?
answer: The Diversity in Democracy programme ran from 2014 to 2017. It was specifically targeted at encouraging those with protected characteristics to stand for election. I have commissioned an evaluation of this Programme which will help inform future initiatives around improving the representation of under-represented groups, including considering the barriers faced by disabled people when participating in democracy.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: For each of the drugs/medicines made available via the new treatment fund, have all been made available for prescribing within two months, and will the Cabinet Secretary publish the time it has taken for each drug/medicine to be made available for prescribing since being appraised by each LHB?
answer: Of the 112 medicines recommended from 1 January 2017 to 30 April 2018, 109 (97%) were available for prescribing within two months.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: For each of the last three years, will the Cabinet Secretary outline all of the medicines or drugs that have been NICE approved, but superseded or rejected by the All Wales Medicines Strategy Group, stating the grounds for each of the decisions?
answer: There are none as the All Wales Medicines Strategy Group does not review NICE recommendations.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the use of pertuzumab (Perjeta) within NHS Wales?
answer: NICE has recommended pertuzumab to treat HER2-positive breast cancer in adults that is locally advanced, inflammatory, or early-stage with a high risk of recurrence; and to treat HER2-positive, locally recurrent or metastatic (secondary) breast cancer in adults, in combination with trastuzumab and docetaxel.

name: David Melding
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What impact will the amalgamation of local authority government grants have on the protection of grassroot schemes such as the Teulu partnership?
answer: Local Authorities have told us the current grant structures can be a barrier to improving the outcomes for the most vulnerable in our society.  People’s lives, the challenges they face and the support they need do not necessarily correlate with the boundaries of our grants. We want to improve outcomes and deliver improved support for vulnerable families and individuals – unhindered by the artificial constraints sometimes created by individual grants.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

answer: The number of admissions of patients aged under 25 where treatment speciality was mental health, by health board, 2015-16 to 2017-18

name: Angela Burns

answer: The number of admissions where the primary diagnosis was an eating disorder, by health board, 2015-16 to 2017-18

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Following the answer to WAQ76497,  will the Cabinet Secretary outline what direction he will be providing for the new Health Education Improvement Wales body once it is established in October?
answer: Health Education and Improvement Wales (HEIW) will be directed through a remit letter from the Welsh Government. This letter will set out the priorities for the organisation and the resources it will have available. Discussions regarding that letter are underway and it will be my intention to publish the letter for members of the Assembly following its issue in due course.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Further to WAQ76534, will the Cabinet Secretary provide the breakdown for how much will each local authority receive of the £15 million of capital funding made available to further improve recycling collection systems and infrastructure through the Waste and Resource Efficiency Division’s Collaborative Change Programme (CCP) and Infrastructure Team?
answer: The additional £15 million capital funding over three years will be administered through the Waste and Resource Efficiency Division’s Collaborative Change Programme (CCP) and Infrastructure Team. The money will be allocated to support major service changes to Local Authority recycling, the provision of additional infrastructure to help Local Authorities recycle a wider range of materials and, where appropriate, to procure material and equipment used in supporting an all Wales Behaviour Change Campaign.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to ban the sale of primates as domestic pets in Wales?
answer: RSPCA Cymru issued a briefing document in October 2016 calling for a ban on keeping primates as pets in Wales. Officials have met with the RSPCA to discuss this matter and the RSPCA has since provided data, for England and Wales combined, on the number of primates known to be kept as pets or in private collections, for those species where a licence is required. No person may keep any dangerous wild animal (including many primates) without first obtaining a licence from their Local Authority under the Dangerous Wild Animals Act 1976. Under this Act Local Authorities inspect premises, and as part of the inspection, consider welfare requirements.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide the number of reported cases of Lyme disease in Wales for 2013-14, 2014-15, 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18?
answer: Both laboratory confirmed and clinically reported cases of Lyme disease in Wales are recorded by calendar year to correspond with the annual tick life cycle and human exposures.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary working with the farming industry across Wales to reduce the numbers of ticks in sheep and other livestock?
answer: Tick control remains the responsibility of the animal keeper and they are encouraged to work closely with their private veterinarians to consider methods of control.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What steps is the Cabinet Secretary taking to address the large amounts of usable reserves held by local authorities in Wales, including the £148 million by Rhondda Cynon Taf and £120 million by Caerphilly?
answer: It is the responsibility of each authority to ensure it has an appropriate and transparent strategy in place for holding reserves. Decisions in these matters are the responsibility of each authority and the scrutiny of these decisions rests with Local Elected Members. In February 2018 the Welsh Government reissued guidance to Elected Members to assist them in undertaking effective scrutiny of reserves.

name: Russell George
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Will the Leader of the House provide details of which mobile network operators have informed the Welsh Government that if they were to be given the permission to install taller masts, coverage issues would be fully resolved, and when was the Welsh Government informed of this?
answer: As far as I can ascertain, the mobile phone network operators have never categorically informed the Welsh Government that, if they were given permission to install taller masts the coverage issues in Wales would be fully resolved.

name: Russell George
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Welsh Government provide an update on the implementation of recommendation 7 and 8 from the National Assembly for Wales’s EIS Committee Report on Digital Connectivity, relating to reform of the planning regime to support the installation and sharing of masts that cover a wider geographical range?
answer: Revisions to permitted development rights for telecommunications are included in a consultation on proposed changes to the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) Order, which will begin imminently.

name: Russell George
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Will the Welsh Government provide details of the discussions it has held with mobile network operators and Ofcom regarding the impact which non-domestic rates relief would have on investment in mobile infrastructure?
answer: Reducing non-domestic rates on new mobile masts, particularly in areas where the investment case for mobile infrastructure is marginal, has been the subject of discussions with the mobile network operators and Ofcom in developing the mobile action plan. In addition, we have recently issued a call for evidence to the industry seeking clear evidence of the tangible benefits that introducing a reduction on non-domestic for new mobile masts would bring. Officials are currently reviewing that evidence.

name: Russell George
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: What is the Welsh Government’s view on the principle of mandatory national mobile roaming and has the Welsh Government conducted an assessment of the impact which this may have on competition in the mobile industry and investment in mobile infrastructure in Wales?
answer: We believe that roaming remains an attractive proposition, albeit on a geographically differentiated basis rather than on a national scale, to provide connectivity to all mobile operators in partial notspots. Ofcom is best placed to make an assessment of the impact on competition however, we are not convinced that any impact on market competition and industry investment would outweigh the gain to be achieved in transforming the availability of mobile services in rural Wales.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care
question: In relation to WAQ76525, what specific arrangements/targets are in place with the Ministerial Advisory Group to help monitor progress of the National Approach to Statutory Advocacy?
answer: The Ministerial Advisory Group established a Task and Finish Group (T&FG) in February 2018 to drive forward implementation and ensure monitoring of the National Approach to Statutory Advocacy for children and young people.

answer: The Welsh Government cannot provide direct support to deal with any planning applications, as this would prejudice the Welsh Ministers’ ability to determine those applications at a later stage, such as at appeal or via call-in.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Does the new Wales and Borders rail franchise include a break clause?
answer: The Welsh Ministers will be responsible for Operator of Last Resort duties for the whole of the Wales and Borders rail service from 14 October 2018.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Has the Welsh Government commissioned any work or received any expert advice that suggests that Neath station should be removed from the main railway line between Cardiff and Swansea?
answer: I have made clear the Welsh Government’s position in relation to Neath Station.  I believe that the station and its services shouldn't just be protected but enhanced.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the availability of bisphosphonate treatment for breast cancer patients in north Wales?
answer: Bisphosphonates have been available as a treatment for breast cancer patients in north Wales, where clinically appropriate, since 2016.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What plans does the Cabinet Secretary have to raise awareness of the issue of electrical fires in homes among older people in Wales?
answer: The Fire and Rescue Service already provides comprehensive advice on domestic fire safety, and carries out around 60,000 home safety visits every year.  This programme focuses on those, such as older people, who may be at greater risk of fire; and each visit covers all risks that are relevant to the premises and residents concerned.  However, there is no overall evidence that older people are at significantly greater risk of electrical fires in particular.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: In each of the last five years, how many times have a) the armed forces, b) the police, c) the ambulance service, and d) the fire brigade visited schools to promote careers within these services?
answer: This information is not held centrally, and schools, through head teachers and governing bodies are responsible for decisions about which organisations should be able to visit their school. However, we want to strengthen links between schools and employers to raise awareness of career opportunities, and have commissioned Careers Wales to establish a new, online resource called the ‘Education Business Exchange’, which will support a national network of business education partnerships with an employer engagement database.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Following the Cabinet Secretary's confirmation that the Hwb+ data can be restored for schools should they require it post contract, what is the process for a school to retrieve any data post the Hwb+ contract, and how long will a school have to wait for it?
answer: As previously outlined, officials have been extensively engaging with schools across Wales to raise awareness around the cessation of Hwb+.  This includes communications to schools, local authorities and regional consortia, highlighting key dates and action points.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Following the Cabinet Secretary's confirmation that the Hwb platform already provides access to industry-leading collaborative tools such as Microsoft Office 365, which industry-leading collaboration tools are being currently being used by schools through Office365 in addition to the email and Onenote already mentioned?
answer: As previously outlined, the Hwb platform provides access to a wide range of collaborative tools including Hwb Networks, Hwb Classes, Just2easy, Microsoft Office 365 and the soon to be introduced Google for Education. Specific Microsoft Office 365 collaboration tools, other than e-mail and OneNote include Word Online, Excel Online, Teams, Groups and Skype.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Following the Cabinet Secretary's confirmation that the Hwb+ supplier is a data processor and so must act on the instructions of the data controller, i.e. the schools, is the Welsh Government also a data controller or data processor under the contracts with the various Hwb suppliers?
answer: The data processing arrangements that were established at the start of the programme were done on the basis that individual schools and local authorities were joint data controllers for pupil information used to create and allow access to the Hwb platform.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether it is individual schools or Welsh Government that have an obligation to keep the Hwb+ data for safeguarding purposes?
answer: The Hwb+ platform is provided by Welsh Government as an educational resource for schools and learners.  There is no obligation on either individual schools or the Welsh Government to retain data stored within the Hwb+ platform for general safeguarding purposes.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Following the Cabinet Secretary's confirmation that the Welsh Government has undertaken a number of evaluation exercises to shape the Hwb platform, will the independent evaluation exercises, the number of participants and its results be made public?
answer: The original independent evaluation of the implementation of the Learning in Digital Wales platform was published on 4 October 2016.  There are no plans to release any further evaluation details.

answer: Nid yw Llywodraeth Cymru yn dal gwybodaeth ynghylch nifer yr athrawon sydd wedi bod yn absennol o’u gwaith oherwydd straen a achoswyd gan eu gwaith.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the statistic that more than one agricultural worker a week in the UK dies by suicide, and explain what action the Welsh Government will take to help those working within the sector combat stress and improve their mental health?
answer: Suicide has an absolutely shattering impact on families and on the friends of the family involved. In the context of Agriculture, suicide may also have a devastating impact on the farm business. It is important that Government works alongside partner organisations within the industry to promote good mental health and well-being in the workplace.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the Welsh Government Concessionary Travel pilot scheme which enabled pass holders to travel freely on designated rail routes up to March 2018, confirm the outcome of the pilot and the future plans for the scheme?
answer: The concessionary rail fares scheme will continue on the same routes for the same periods until the end of the current franchise in October.   The specification for the future rail services contract from October 2018 includes the provision of the current scheme, as a minimum.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary working with the education sector to help combat ageist stereotypes of older people?
answer: The Personal and social education framework for 7 to 19-year-olds in Wales is designed to support and provide scope for schools to allow learners to develop respect for themselves and others, value and celebrate diversity and equality of opportunity locally, nationally and globally.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that the £1.6 million Barnett consequential from the UK Government policy of £1,000 rate relief for pubs with a rateable value under £100,000 has been earmarked for the same purpose in Wales, and if so, provide a breakdown of take-up of this relief so far?
answer: We have established a number of schemes which help pubs, and ratepayers in Wales, with their non-domestic rates bills.  Our Small Business Rates Relief (SBRR) provides 100% relief for eligible businesses with a rateable value of up to £6,000 and tapered relief for those valued between £6,001 and £12,000.  Our Transitional Relief provides support to ratepayers who saw a reduction in their entitlement to SBRR in April 2017 due to the revaluation.  And our High Street Rates Relief scheme is providing support to food, drink and other eligible retail outlets which occupy high street premises.  We do not hold information centrally on the take-up of these schemes by sector.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: Further to the announcement about Caergwrle Castle, what plans does the Cabinet Secretary have to ensure that all hill forts in Wales have verified custodians, and are in receipt of funding for conservation and promotion as sites of historical importance over the 2018-19 and 2019-20 financial years?
answer: There are no plans for Cadw custodians to be placed in all the hillforts of Wales. There are currently 463 defended prehistoric enclosures across Wales, including hillforts and promontory forts that enjoy legal protection as scheduled monuments. The vast majority of these are located on private land, largely in agricultural areas on hill top or coastal locations. Only three of these sites are directly in the care of the Welsh Ministers, Caer y Twr on Anglesey, the Bulwarks near Chepstow and Llanmelyn near Newport and these are unstaffed.  However, along with all other scheduled monuments, the hillforts receive periodic visits from Cadw’s Field Monument Wardens. They work with owners, occupiers and managers to promote their ongoing conservation and management. There is no specific fund set aside for the conservation of the hillforts although over the years numerous individual sites have benefitted from ancient monuments grants and management arrangements, including through agri-environment schemes such as Tir Gofal and Glastir.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: How much funding is the Welsh Government investing in ensuring that the history of Wales is told and understood through our castles in 2018-19 and 2019-20, and what measurable targets will be used to ensure worthwhile outcomes of the spend?
answer: Telling the history of Wales through the monuments in the care of Welsh Ministers, including the castles, is one of Cadw’s main objectives. Cadw does this in a number of ways, including through its visitor services - the marketing and promotion of its sites, through first class site interpretation, relevant events and the facilitation of its learning visits. £1,265, 000 is being invested for these activities across all of Cadw’s properties in care during 2018-19 and £1,275,000 is ear-marked for 2019-20.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care
question: For each local authority piloting the Welsh Government's childcare offer: how many a) families/households and b) children are eligible for this; how many a) families/households and b) children take part in the scheme; what is the estimated or full annual cost, and is this fully funded by the Welsh Government?
answer: We began early implementation of our childcare offer in seven local authorities across Wales from September 2017.  At that time the offer was available across the whole of Blaenau Gwent and in parts of Caerphilly, Gwnynedd, Anglesey, Flintshire, Swansea and Rhondda Cynon Taff.  Since then we have expanded delivery within these pilot authorities and the offer has been available across the whole of Caerphilly, Gwnynedd, Anglesey, and Flintshire from April 2018 and will be available across the whole of Swansea and Rhondda Cynon Taff later this year.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how the £20m clean air fund will be allocated?
answer: The primary focus of the £20m air quality fund is to support local authorities to reduce concentrations of nitrogen dioxide around roads where levels are above legal limits in Wales.   Funding will therefore be allocated in consultation with local authorities so as to identify priority areas and ensure the fund delivers maximum improvements in these hotspots.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Welsh Government confirm whether it will prioritise the allocation of the £20m clean air fund to those areas reporting exceedances in air quality standards?
answer: The primary focus of the £20m air quality fund is to support local authorities to reduce concentrations of nitrogen dioxide around roads where levels are above legal limits in Wales. This includes provision of ongoing support, guidance and finance to develop and implement plans to achieve compliance in the soonest possible time.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: What investment will the Welsh Government make to improve the level of air quality monitoring across Wales, and in particular real-time monitoring?
answer: Monitoring and reporting on local air quality remains the statutory duty of local authorities.  In carrying out this duty they must take a risk-based approach to siting monitors, informed by evidence, including evidence drawn to their attention by local communities, which indicates where people are likely to be exposed to the highest levels of air pollution.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What consideration has the Welsh Government given to requiring the installation of air quality monitoring equipment on all school buildings in receipt of 21st Century Schools funding?
answer: Ventilation provision in schools should be made in accordance with the guidance in Building Bulletin 101, Ventilation of School Buildings and the Education (School Premises) Regulations.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Welsh Government enshrine in law the World Health Organisation guidelines and limits on air quality as part of its clean air plan?
answer: Our National air quality objectives in Wales are founded in EU Limit Values.  However, our focus in relation to improving air quality in Wales is clearly that levels of pollution should be reduced as far as reasonably practicable, and not simply kept within a specified limit.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Welsh Government outline whether it intends to introduce a system of personalised air quality alerts and health advice (including a right to breathe) whereby local authorities are obliged to inform parents when air quality levels are breached?
answer: Air quality alert systems have operated in the UK for a number of years, and include ‘airText’ (London), ‘airAlert’ (Sussex) and ‘Know and Respond’ (Scotland). All operate on forecasts of air quality for the following day.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide the salary bandings and remit for the additional learning needs transformation leads for each of the education regional consortia, stating how many have been employed by each and for what term lengths?
answer: Salaries for the five Additional Learning Needs (ALN) transformation leads range from circa £60,000 to £80,000. The ALN transformation leads are responsible for supporting the effective implementation of the Additional Learning Needs and Education Tribunal (Wales) Act 2018 across Wales.  Each ALN transformation lead plays a key role in delivering the ALN transformation programme, supporting local authorities, schools, early years settings, the further education (FE) sector and local health boards. They provide a strategic interface between delivery partners and the Welsh Government.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state to which bodies/organisations the additional learning needs transformation leads employed within the regional education consortia are directly accountable?
answer: Salaries for the five Additional Learning Needs (ALN) transformation leads range from circa £60,000 to £80,000. The ALN transformation leads are responsible for supporting the effective implementation of the Additional Learning Needs and Education Tribunal (Wales) Act 2018 across Wales.  Each ALN transformation lead plays a key role in delivering the ALN transformation programme, supporting local authorities, schools, early years settings, the further education (FE) sector and local health boards. They provide a strategic interface between delivery partners and the Welsh Government.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the number of vacant posts for speech and language therapists within the education sector in Wales, and make a statement on concerns raised that there is a deficit of such therapists?
answer: Prime responsibility for the provision of speech and language therapy (SALT) services to children rests with the NHS. However, under the Education Act 1996, local authorities (LAs) and their schools are responsible for providing suitable educational provision for all children including those with special educational needs (SEN) such as speech language and communication difficulties (SLCD).

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the number of vacant posts for speech and language therapists within the health and social services sector in Wales, and make a statement on concerns raised that there is a deficit of such therapists?
answer: Data on Speech and Language Therapies vacancies is not collated or held centrally.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the number of vacant posts for Welsh-language speech and language therapists within the education sector in Wales, and make a statement on concerns raised that there is a deficit of such therapists?
answer: Prime responsibility for the provision of speech and language therapy (SALT) services to children rests with the NHS. However, under the Education Act 1996, local authorities (LAs) and their schools are responsible for providing suitable educational provision for all children including those with special educational needs (SEN) such as speech language and communication difficulties (SLCD).

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the number of vacant posts for Welsh-language speech and language therapists within the health and social services sector in Wales, and make a statement on concerns raised that there is a deficit of such therapists?
answer: Data on Speech and Language Therapies vacancies is not collated or held centrally.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: In 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18, on how many occasions were ministerial cars used for journeys between north and south Wales and, of these, how many were single journeys and how many were return journeys?
answer: This question is a request for recorded information and as such have been passed to the appropriate Division for answer as a freedom of information request.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary consult with the Permanent Secretary and provide the following information: the job titles of all officials within the legislation branch of the Welsh language division, not the names of the officials themselves?
answer: Staffing is a matter for the Permanent Secretary, I will ask her to write to you directly.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Has the Welsh Government purchased any land in the Cogan area of Penarth for the provision of a park-and-ride scheme, and if so, provide the cost and size of the land purchased?
answer: The Welsh Government has acquired two adjoining parcels of land in the Cogan area for the South Wales Metro project, totalling 0.69 acres at a cost of £650,000 (exclusive of VAT).

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following the Cabinet Secretary's answer to WAQ76472, will all trains and services on the Valleys Lines as part of the next Wales and Borders Franchise have on-board toilet facilities?
answer: My written statement on Monday 4 of June provides members with an update of the benefits across Wales the new rail services contract will provide passengers, including details on the provision of toilet facilities under the new contract.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following the Cabinet Secretary's answer to WAQ76472, was the requirement to include toilets on all services specified to the franchise bidders in the invitation to tender?
answer: My written statement on Monday 4 of June provides members with an update of the benefits across Wales the new rail services contract will provide passengers, including details on the provision of toilet facilities under the new contract.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What steps is the Welsh Government taking to promote angling in Wales?
answer: Angling on Wales’ rivers, seas, lakes and ponds provides important economic benefit to rural and coastal communities as well as being a healthy activity undertaken by many individuals across Wales.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What reassurances will the Cabinet Secretary provide regarding the sustainability of Welsh fisheries?
answer: Sustainability of fisheries, at sea and in our rivers, requires healthy populations of fish, as well as healthy riverine and marine environments. The Welsh Government is committed to delivering clean, healthy, safe, productive and biologically diverse rivers across Wales and in the seas around Wales.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What consideration has the Welsh Government given to supporting voluntary access agreements for Welsh fisheries?
answer: The Welsh Government has, to date, followed the recommendations put forward by the Sustainability Committee following the Inquiry on Access to Inland Waters in 2010.  This includes supporting the use of access agreements and other opportunities on inland waters through a funding scheme (the SPLASH fund) between 2009 – 2014 (£2.6 million).

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the economic impact of angling in Wales?
answer: Recreational fisheries, including angling for the iconic fish species of salmon and sea trout bring economic benefit in excess of £74 million annual expenditure in Wales. They support around 1,500 Welsh jobs and £32 million in household income, often to rural communities; and are widely recognised as indicators of good environmental quality.

name: Jenny Rathbone
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Following publication of the tobacco control delivery plan in 2017, what assessment has the Welsh Government made of progress against its target to reduce smoking prevalence in Wales to 16 percent?
answer: The next National Survey headlines release is due on 20th June, so we will have a better idea of progress when those are published.

name: Jenny Rathbone
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many local health boards have achieved the tobacco control delivery plan target to treat five percent of their smoking population in the last three years?
answer: The next National Survey headlines release is due on 20th June, so we will have a better idea of progress when those are published.

name: Jenny Rathbone
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What assessment has the Welsh Government made of setting a target to halve childhood obesity and by what date; in light of the Scottish Government’s pledge to halve childhood obesity by 2030?
answer: The Welsh Government is in the process of developing a Healthy Weight strategy in response to the requirement within the Public Health Wales (Act). A consultation on the strategy will be going to Cabinet ahead of launching the public consultation in the autumn.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have for the implementation and monitoring of its Implementation Plan for Rare Diseases?
answer: To support the implementation of the plan, the Welsh Rare Diseases Implementation Group (RDIG) was established. The RDIG includes broad representation from each health board in Wales, Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee (WHSSC), the Rare Disease and Genetics Alliance and, crucially a patient representative. The Group is chaired by Dr Graham Shortland, Medical Director, Cardiff and Vale University Health Board. They produce an annual update on progress which was last published on 28 February 2018 and can be found at:

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to provide free fire safety checks to those over the age of 80?
answer: We have long funded the three Fire and Rescue Services to provide home safety checks completely free of charge to householders.  These cover fire safety as well as other hazards such as falls. While anyone can request a check, those who may be at higher risk of fire, such as older people, receive priority.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to improve the promotion of electrical safety within the home, especially amongst the elderly?
answer: The Fire and Rescue Service already provides comprehensive advice on domestic fire safety, including electrical safety, and carries out around 60,000 home safety visits every year. This programme focuses on those such as older people who may be at greater risk of fire – although there is no evidence that older people are at greater risk of electrical fires in particular.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary give any consideration to increasing the length of the required periods of commitment to work in Wales for future students considering applying for the NHS Wales Bursary Scheme?
answer: On 10th May I launched a 12 week consultation on the longer term arrangements about key aspects of the current support arrangements for health care students. This open consultation includes a series of questions on the post qualification employment period.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Since May 2016, are there any treatments which GPs in Wales are no longer able to refer patients for under the Welsh NHS, and if there are, will the Cabinet Secretary provide a list?
answer: There has been no change since May 2016. In respect of referral for treatment to a specialist consultant or other healthcare professional, GPs in Wales use their clinical judgement as to how best to meet the needs of individual patients.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why the 28-day target for local primary mental health support services continues to be missed for so many individuals at Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, and state how the Welsh Government is working to ensure that assessments take place within the appropriate timeframe?
answer: Since Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board was placed in Special Measures in 2015, it has made improvements in its performance in delivering assessments and interventions within target by the Local Primary Mental Health Support Services (LPMHSS). The ongoing challenge for the Health Board is to consistently sustain its performance in meeting these targets.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Who will be responsible for the enforcement of the ban and issuing of fines for smoking in hospital grounds, school grounds, and playgrounds, and how much funding will the Welsh Government make available to ensure that the law is enforced in 2018/19 and 2019/20?
answer: The Public Health (Wales) Act 2017 designates local authorities as enforcement officers in relation to smoke-free premises, places and vehicles in their area.  Enforcement officers may issue fixed penalty notices to persons caught smoking within any smoke-free grounds. We will be working with local authorities over the next year to look at the detail of enforcement of smoke-free hospital grounds, school grounds and public playgrounds.  The law will not come in to force until summer 2019.  A consultation on draft Smoke-free Premises and Vehicles (Wales) Regulations 2018, which includes provisions on enforcement of the smoking chapter in the Public Health (Wales) Act 2017, was launched on 25 May - https://beta.gov.wales/smoke-free-premises-and-vehicles-wales-regulations-2018.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How many students currently spend time abroad studying and for work experience, and how much money will be invested in the pilot scheme to fund international study and work experience opportunities in 2018/19, 2019/20 and 2020/21, providing the target number aimed for through the scheme?
answer: Erasmus+ is the current EU programme for education, training, youth and sport, open to all sectors of lifelong learning including higher education, vocational education and training, school education, adult education as well as youth and sport.  Wales has a good participation rate in Erasmus+, and the predecessor Lifelong learning programmes, which allow students to study or undertake work experience/ volunteering in another EU country.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Following the Cabinet Secretary's recent comments regarding GCSE Science and BTEC Science, will she explain whether the Welsh Government is looking to replace some BTEC qualifications with GCSEs?
answer: I am pleased that we are seeing an increase in the number of pupils being entered for Science GCSE.  I expect that momentum to continue.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide the business case for the new Planning Application Wales website, state the cost of its development, and explain how any transitional processes with local planning authority systems will be managed?
answer: The “Planning Applications Wales” service is the successor to the Planning Portal in Wales. The service was previously financed by grant aid, however, this had to stop as a consequence of privatisation of the Planning Portal by the UK Government in 2015.  A procurement exercise to secure the most cost efficient successor service has been undertaken as a bilingual service is not commercially viable.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Further to WAQ76536 and only one planning application being determined by Welsh Ministers, what consideration has the Cabinet Secretary made of reviewing the current guidance for call-in requests to ensure that applications affecting more than the local area may be determined nationally, to include taking into account impacts on tourism?
answer: The power of the Welsh Ministers to call-in planning applications is discretionary and wide. These powers are used selectively and call-in is generally only considered appropriate where an application raises planning issues of more than local importance. Examples of proposals where call-in may be considered appropriate are those which:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the cancellation of the Conwy Valley line rail service, and advise as to how he will work to ensure that appropriate safeguards are in place within the forthcoming KeolisAmey contract to avoid such an occurrence in the future?
answer: I was very disappointed to hear services on the Conwy Valley line have been cancelled due to trains requiring maintenance. I expect Arriva Trains Wales to manage their resources effectively to deliver timetabled services, and they will be financially penalised for failure to operate services. Transport for Wales will ensure that KeolisAmey meet their contractual obligations to operate services on this route.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide details of any financial contributions made by the Welsh Government to trade unions and the Cooperative Party over his term as First Minister?
answer: Substantive response

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Assembly Commission
question: Will the Commission provide details of any financial contributions it has made to trade unions and the Cooperative Party in the period since Carwyn Jones became First Minister?
answer: The Commission has not provided any financial contributions to trade unions or the Cooperative Party in the period from 10 December 2009 to date.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Further to WAQ76378, will the Cabinet Secretary publish the Welsh Government's full response regarding the regulation and monitoring of intensive poultry farming units in Wales?
answer: I have asked my Chief Planner to issue a letter to Local Planning Authorities (LPA). The letter will advise on the need for LPAs to exercise particular care when considering planning applications for livestock units close to residential or sensitive environmental areas. It will remind LPAs, where necessary, to take into account the cumulative impacts resulting from similar developments nearby. We are also exploring the options for strengthening the controls on polluting emissions from intensive farming.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: For each of the last three years, will the Cabinet Secretary list all of the medicines or drugs that following an appraisal by the All Wales Medicines Strategy Group will not be recommended for routine use in NHS Wales and the reasons for each decision?
answer: This information is available on the All-Wales Medicines Strategy Group website at:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why the milestone requirement to provide evidence of continual sustainable improvement on referral to treatment times with no patient waiting longer than 36 weeks for treatment for Betsi Cadwaladr UHB between April 2019 and September 2019 excludes orthopaedics?
answer: The specific milestone referred to in the framework relates to the period April 2019 to September 2019 and that no patient is waiting longer than 36 weeks for treatment with the exception of orthopaedics. This milestone is not achievable for orthopaedics within the timeline due to the transformational and service re-design work needed to develop a sustainable service. I am therefore not going to set an improvement target that is plainly unachievable.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how many landlords are now registered in Wales, and how many are estimated to remain unregistered?
answer: The latest figures released by Rent Smart Wales show that 90,812 landlords are now registered. Rent Smart Wales’ latest estimate for the number of unregistered landlords is approximately 3,000. This is based on the dwelling stock estimates recently published by StatsWales, and an estimation of the average number of properties owned by each landlord.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the legal status of a Section 21 eviction notice when issued by a landlord in Wales who is not registered under the Rent Smart Wales scheme?
answer: A landlord who is not registered with Rent Smart Wales is unable to serve a valid Section 21 eviction notice.

name: Vikki Howells
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How do local health boards ensure that there are appropriate systems and protocols in place to respect and enable patients, in particular those with Parkinson’s, to self-manage their medication whilst in hospital where deemed appropriate?
answer: I wish to see that patients receive their medication in hospital in a timely manner and which meets their clinical needs. It remains the responsibility of health boards and trusts, including those that refer into English hospitals, to plan how services will be delivered within their local area. These services should be regularly reviewed to ensure they meet the needs of their resident population. I expect health boards to ensure there are appropriate systems and protocols in place to respect and enable patients to self-manage their medication whilst in hospital where deemed appropriate.

name: Vikki Howells
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary monitoring local health boards to ensure that they have appropriate systems and protocols in place to respect and enable patients, in particular those with Parkinson’s, to self-manage their medication whilst in hospital where deemed appropriate?
answer: I wish to see that patients receive their medication in hospital in a timely manner and which meets their clinical needs. It remains the responsibility of health boards and trusts, including those that refer into English hospitals, to plan how services will be delivered within their local area. question: How is the Cabinet Secretary liaising with NHS England to ensure that Welsh patients who receive treatment in English hospitals, particularly those with Parkinson’s, are enabled to self-manage their medication where deemed appropriate?
answer: I wish to see that patients receive their medication in hospital in a timely manner and which meets their clinical needs.
