These services should be regularly reviewed to ensure they meet the needs of their resident population. I expect health boards to ensure there are appropriate systems and protocols in place to respect and enable patients to self-manage their medication whilst in hospital where deemed appropriate.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the Welsh Government's progress towards increasing Welsh-medium early years provision by 40 nursery groups by 2021?
answer: To reflect the importance of the early years and childcare sector to the vision set out in Cymraeg 2050, an additional £2m has been allocated to Mudiad Meithrin over the next two financial years. This has enabled Mudiad Meithrin to undertake a specific programme of work aimed at establishing new Welsh-medium nursery groups across Wales in areas with a current lack of provision.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the Welsh Government's progress towards ensuring that 3,100 primary teachers can teach Welsh or teach through the medium of Welsh by 2021?
answer: We will be publishing an annual report outlining progress against the aims of Cymraeg 2050 in due course. This report will also include a statistical report on progress against the targets.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the Welsh Government's progress towards ensuring that 2,200 secondary teachers can teach through the medium of Welsh by 2021?
answer: We will be publishing an annual report outlining progress against the aims of Cymraeg 2050 in due course. This report will also include a statistical report on progress against the targets.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the Welsh Government's progress towards ensuring that 600 secondary teachers can teach Welsh as a subject by 2021?
answer: We will be publishing an annual report outlining progress against the aims of Cymraeg 2050 in due course. This report will also include a statistical report on progress against the targets.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the future of thrombectomy services for stroke in Wales?
answer: The Welsh Government is working with the Welsh Health Specialised Services Commission (WHSSC) to implement a 3 phase approach to developing thrombectomy services across Wales.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: When does the Cabinet Secretary plan for thrombectomy services to be made available to all stroke patients in Wales who require the treatment?
answer: The Welsh Government is working with the Welsh Health Specialised Services Commission (WHSSC) to implement a 3 phase approach to developing thrombectomy services across Wales.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide a list of the companies and individuals he met on his recent trip to Washington DC?
answer: As I said in my Written Statement on 6 June, during my visit to Washington I hosted a reception at the British Embassy with the WRU; met senior representatives of the US/UK Business Council of the US Chamber of Commerce; and held meetings with existing & potential investors.  For reasons of confidentiality I am unable to release the names of the individual companies that I met.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide a list of Trump administration officials that he met on his recent trip to Washington DC and confirm whether the discussions held dealt with the imposition of steel tariffs recently introduced by that administration?
answer: As I said in my Written Statement on 6 June, during my visit to Washington I hosted a reception at the British Embassy with the WRU; met senior representatives of the US/UK Business Council of the US Chamber of Commerce; and held meetings with existing & potential investors.  For reasons of confidentiality I am unable to release the names of the individual companies that I met.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide a list of the Welsh Government officials who travelled with him on his recent trip to Washington DC and confirm the capacity they attended in?
answer: As I said in my Written Statement on 6 June, during my visit to Washington I hosted a reception at the British Embassy with the WRU; met senior representatives of the US/UK Business Council of the US Chamber of Commerce; and held meetings with existing & potential investors.  For reasons of confidentiality I am unable to release the names of the individual companies that I met.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What assessment has the Welsh Government made of the likely increase in traffic along the A40 between Abergavenny and Raglan following the anticipated completion of the dualling of the A465 between Brynmawr and Gilwern?
answer: The assessment of the change in traffic volumes on the A40 was modelled as part of the development of the A465 dualling proposals.  Consideration of these changes to traffic patterns have been fed into the future inspection and maintenance regime for the A40.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What estimate has the Welsh Government made of the likely cost of resurfacing the A40 between Raglan and Abergavenny?
answer: The A40 at this location is not life expired and there are currently no plans to resurface it.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the priority status of the A40 between Raglan and Abergavenny in the Welsh Government's 100 noise action plan priority areas?
answer: The sites along the A40 within the concrete carriageway section between the Hardwick Interchange and Raglan Roundabout were identified as Priority 1 NAPPA sites.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: How can members of the public engage with the development of the Welsh Government's five year noise action plan?
answer: We will be consulting on our revised noise and soundscape action plan over the summer.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that funding is available to draw up noise mitigation measures for the eight mile stretch of the A40 between Raglan and Abergavenny?
answer: Funding is available to commence detailed design of the noise mitigation measures on the A40 between Raglan and Abergavenny in 2018/19. The work will be detailed design of proposed noise barriers. The design work will only focus on those locations which were identified as Priority 1 NAPPA sites.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how much Health and Care Research Wales and its predecessors (the National Institute for Social Care and Health Research and the Wales Office of Research and Development) have contributed to work of the National Institute for Health Research for each of the last five years?
answer: On behalf of the Welsh Government, Health and Care Research Wales invests in a number of agreed NIHR programmes, known as the NIHR Evaluation, Trials and Studies (NETS) programmes. These include the Efficacy and Mechanism Evaluation programme, the Health Technology Assessment programme, the Health Services and Delivery Research Programme and the Public Health Research programme.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How much has the Welsh Government spent on funding cancer research in Wales in the last 10 years, broken down by year?
answer: The Welsh Government, through Health and Care Research Wales, invests in a number of cancer related research programmes. These cover a wide portfolio of clinical and laboratory based research.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the impact of an energy price cap?
answer: This is not a devolved matter and therefore the assessment to support the legislation is the responsibility of the UK Government.  I discussed the energy price cap with Claire Perry, Minister of State at the Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy at my last meeting with her. I broadly welcomed the energy price cap and the role it could play in reducing costs for some of the most vulnerable customers.  However, I consider this to be a temporary and somewhat crude measure to address a complex issue and longer term solutions to fuel poverty are needed.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What consideration has the Welsh Government given to expanding the remit and resources of Veterans NHS Wales to enable them to support cadets with mental health problems linked to cadet engagement?
answer: Veterans NHS Wales is a dedicated service for armed forces veterans.  Those eligible to access the service do so in line with the UK Government’s standard veteran definition contained in the Armed Forces Covenant – “anyone who has served for at least one day in Her Majesty's Armed Forces (Regular or Reserve) or Merchant Mariners who have seen duty on legally defined military operations”.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What impact does the Cabinet Secretary foresee that the proposals for local government reform in the current green paper will have on the work of public services boards, with particular regard to the situation should the proposed mergers go ahead?
answer: The Green Paper stated that, if the proposals for local authority mergers were to proceed, it would make sense to move to the new footprint at an early, appropriate point in order to streamline partnership arrangements.  The intention would be to make any transition to new Public Services Boards areas as smooth as possible, to enable boards to focus on making a difference in their areas. The Green Paper consultation closed on 12 June and I will be carefully considering the responses before determining the way forward.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: How have public service boards in Wales utilised the £25,000 per annum provided to them by the Welsh Government for the past three financial years?
answer: In 2016/17 we provided £315,000 and in 2017/18 and 2018/19 we provided £400,000 for PSBs on a regional basis - encouraging the adoption of consistent approaches, and reducing duplication of effort across PSBs.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the scrutiny of the role, remit and performance of public service boards and outline any assessment he has made of the effectiveness of the current scrutiny arrangements?
answer: The scrutiny arrangements for Public Service Boards (PSB) are a matter for each local authority to determine within the parameters of the Well-being and Future Generations Act (“the Act”). This requires local authorities to designate one of its Overview and Scrutiny Committee to review the governance arrangements of the PSB as well as its review or scrutinise the decisions made or actions taken by the PSB and make reports or recommendations to the board regarding its functions or governance arrangements.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What has been the impact of the annual real terms reduction in the local government settlement on the ability of local authorities to employ and retain staff within their budgets, and how many full time equivalent redundancies has each local authority made in each of the past three financial years?
answer: Wales has faced year on year real terms reductions to its budget; the Welsh Government’s revenue budget will be 7% lower in real terms in 2019-20 than it was in 2010-11 equivalent to some £1bn less to spend on front-line services.  Within that context Welsh Government has provided local government with no-cash cuts settlements for the last two years. It is inevitable that there will be impacts upon both staff and services in Local Authorities.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: How many of the 148 brand-new trains announced for the new Wales and Borders rail service, will be made up of the old London Underground D78 stock?
answer: From December 2022 new diesel rolling stock will replace all the North Wales and Marches trains. All trains will be replaced by 2023 when 95 per cent of journeys will be on brand new trains, half of which will be assembled in Wales. The average age of the fleet will drop from 25 years today to 7 years by 2023.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: When does the Cabinet Secretary envisage that an electronic patient record will be implemented within ophthalmology departments in Wales, and how much funding is the Welsh Government committing towards this work?
answer: The Welsh Government is engaging with health boards and NWIS in the development of an electronic patient record for eye care for roll out across NHS Wales. A full business case is in the final stages of development. Until the approved business case is available I cannot give a firm date or elaborate on the funding involved.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Does the Welsh Government still intend to roll-out the outcome-focussed ophthalmic measures in September, and are health boards satisfied that preparatory work is sufficient to enable implementation?
answer: The Welsh Government and the Planned Care Programme are supporting health boards to shadow report this new measure alongside RTT from September 2018.  All health boards have been represented at a number of workshops to support development, implementation and reporting of the new measures.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the scrutiny of the role, remit and performance of regional partnership boards, as set up under Part 9 of the Social Services and Well-being (Wales) Act 2014, and outline any assessment he has made of the effectiveness of the current scrutiny arrangements?
answer: A Plan for Health and Social Care sets out that regional partnership boards will be at the heart of how we develop models of integrated health and social care.  The plan also includes a commitment to introduce joint inspection arrangements between Care Inspectorate Wales and Health Inspectorate Wales for regional partnership working.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline the steps that have been taken by National Resources Wales to investigate the development of a community flood plan for the Conwy Valley/Llanrwst, and explain why the recommendation for a community flood plan, contained in the Conwy Valley Flood Action Plan, is currently on hold?
answer: Natural Resources Wales (NRW) have been working with the Llanwrst Town Council to try and develop the community flood plan and recruit flood wardens.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on access to PET scans for patients in Wales?
answer: The Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee (WHSSC) is responsible for the commissioning of Positron Emission Tomography (PET) on behalf of health boards in Wales. The service specification sets out the indications for which patients can be referred for a PET scan.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline any land sales the Welsh Government has made recently in the Sully and/or Barry area, detailing, where possible, the cost, purchaser and its intended use?
answer: No recent land sales have been completed by the Welsh Government in the Sully and/or Barry area.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of the monthly procurement card spend by Welsh Government officials between April 2017 and April 2018?
answer: The Welsh Government publishes its monthly procurement card spend on its website. The first quarter of 17/18 has recently been published and details for the remainder of that financial year will be published before the summer recess.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish all cancer waiting time breaches reported to the Welsh Government in the last 12 months by each health board?
answer: The Welsh Government publishes the number of cancer breaches by health board and speciality on a quarterly basis. Health boards are challenged on their cancer breaches and are expected to put in place corrective actions.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What urgent actions is the Cabinet Secretary taking to avoid a repeat of the tragic incident in Chirk, where a woman who gave birth to a stillborn child waited over three hours for an ambulance?
answer: Substantive response

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What steps is the Cabinet Secretary taking to improve transitional support for those with eating disorders transferring from adolescent to adult services?
answer: Substantive response

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what is a) the minimum and b) the maximum amount of profit the new Welsh rail franchise operator will receive if it successfully delivers all the requirements expected of it?
answer: The ODP will have the ability to receive a fair commercial return for its investment, which includes £800m in rolling stock and £200m in modernising all 247 stations, if it successfully delivers all of its requirements from the Grant Agreement. There is a profit sharing mechanism in place whereby profit will ultimately be capped so that once the ceiling is reached the ODP will make no further profit. Any excess profits will either be shared with the Authority or reinvested.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the subsidy amount per passenger mile for the new Welsh rail franchise?
answer: The ODP will have the ability to receive a fair commercial return for its investment, which includes £800m in rolling stock and £200m in modernising all 247 stations, if it successfully delivers all of its requirements from the Grant Agreement. There is a profit sharing mechanism in place whereby profit will ultimately be capped so that once the ceiling is reached the ODP will make no further profit. Any excess profits will either be shared with the Authority or reinvested.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Under the terms of the new Welsh rail franchise, who would be responsible for providing and financing new rolling stock in the event of an increase in passenger numbers resulting in demand outstripping capacity?
answer: The ODP Grant Agreement requires capacity based upon an expected substantial increase in passenger numbers. There is a process in place to assure that the service responds to increases beyond the predicted numbers.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether, under the new Welsh rail franchise, the Department for Transport has provided any additional funding to meet costs associated with the Chester to Liverpool Lime Street rail service?
answer: The UK Government and their partners have made a substantial investment in the infrastructure and ongoing operational costs that will enable these services.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What mechanisms will be in place to enable passengers to hold the new Welsh rail franchise operator to account?
answer: The contract includes performance and service quality standards to ensure that staff, passengers and management are clear on what is expected and how well the service is meeting those standards.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What specific provisions have been included in the new Welsh rail franchise towards realising the Swansea Bay and Western Valleys Metro concept?
answer: The rail franchise allows for the future introduction of new or additional services, subject to the usual consultation process, business case and affordability, and suitable infrastructure being available. The Welsh Government will keep pressing for investment in the non-devolved rail network.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What provisions have been included in the new Welsh rail franchise to take account of the possibility of restoring rail services between Aberystwyth and Carmarthen within its lifetime?
answer: The rail franchise allows for the future introduction of new or additional services, subject to the usual consultation process, business case and affordability, and suitable infrastructure being available. The Welsh Government will keep pressing for investment in the non-devolved rail network.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What specific requirements have been imposed on the new Welsh rail franchise operator in terms of providing Welsh-language services?
answer: The Operator and Development Partner (ODP) is required to support the use of the Welsh language and have regard to the official status which the language has in Wales. Public verbal one-to-many communications by the ODP to the public and passengers within Wales will be provided in both English and Welsh including advertisements, audio and audio-visual communications, station announcements including Passenger Information Systems, Customer Information Systems and other electronic systems (excluding those provided by individual station staff who do not speak Welsh),  on-train announcements (excluding those provided by individual on-train staff who do not speak Welsh), automated announcements, and other relevant verbal communications from the ODP.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide the anticipated timetable for delivering the commitment to reducing the scope of the new Welsh rail franchise over its lifetime and, subsequently, the anticipated timetable for expanding the range of services that will be delivered by Transport for Wales directly?
answer: Transport for Wales is mobilising a team to transform rail services including the Operator and Development Partner’s staff and staff from service delivery partners. As an element of the mobilisation process, TfW will be establishing a plan to review, at key milestones through the franchise period, the scope of services and where elements satisfy economic and deliverability tests they will be delivered by TfW.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following the answer to WAQ7657 and the written statement of 4 June, will the Cabinet Secretary clarify what making use of the UK’s buying power for the Welsh Ministers’ operator of last resort duties for the Wales and Border rail service from 14 October 2018 means in practice?
answer: We are required to have an operator of last resort (OLR) process to step in and operate train services in the case that the Operator and Development Partner is unable to continue to do so. Through our relationship with UK Government, we have arranged with the Department for Transport to make use of their agreements for the provision of this service until such a time TfW has capability to provide the OLR function. Work has begun to develop this capability and capacity and TfW expects to be in the position to provide this function, subject to ORR approval, by 2021.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following the answer to WAQ7657 and the written statement of 4 June, what is the anticipated timetable for Transport for Wales to take on responsibility for the Welsh Ministers’ operator of last resort duties for the Wales and Borders rail service from 14 October 2018?
answer: We are required to have an operator of last resort (OLR) process to step in and operate train services in the case that the Operator and Development Partner is unable to continue to do so. Through our relationship with UK Government, we have arranged with the Department for Transport to make use of their agreements for the provision of this service until such a time TfW has capability to provide the OLR function. Work has begun to develop this capability and capacity and TfW expects to be in the position to provide this function, subject to ORR approval, by 2021.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following the answer to WAQ76232 and the written statement of 4 June, will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the Welsh Government ambition for the South Wales Metro as outlined in the November 2015 'Rolling out our Metro' publication, included the electrification of the Ebbw Vale and Maesteg lines?
answer: The 'Rolling out our Metro' document stated that it was expected that much of the current Valley Lines network would remain purely heavy rail with electric (EMU) and/or diesel (DMU) rolling stock. The Ebbw Vale and Maesteg lines are not part of the infrastructure that will transfer to the Welsh Government. They will remain part of the UK rail network and normally be subject to the investment plans of DfT and delivery through Network Rail.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following the answer to WAQ76232 and the written statement of 4 June, will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the specific technical solution being offered by the winning bidder of the Wales and Borders rail services contract includes the electrification of the Ebbw Vale and Maesteg lines?
answer: The 'Rolling out our Metro' document stated that it was expected that much of the current Valley Lines network would remain purely heavy rail with electric (EMU) and/or diesel (DMU) rolling stock. The Ebbw Vale and Maesteg lines are not part of the infrastructure that will transfer to the Welsh Government. They will remain part of the UK rail network and normally be subject to the investment plans of DfT and delivery through Network Rail.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Further to WAQ76573, will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of permanent and fixed term exclusions in primary and secondary schools for all pupils; pupils with special educational needs; and looked after children; in each of Wales's local authorities?
answer: The information requested is in the ten tables below. Figures greater than zero but fewer than 5 have been suppressed to protect the confidentiality of data about individual pupils. These are denoted by an asterisk.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why the waiting list for ENT treatment is up to 55 weeks long at Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, and explain what action is being taken to  reduce these waiting times for the over 537 patients, including the 70 noted as awaiting urgent treatment?
answer: I expect all patients to be seen as quickly as possible and in order of clinical need, which is a decision for the relevant clinician to make.  It is the responsibility of health boards to plan and deliver services to meet the need of their local populations.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how many patients are currently on the waiting list for a CT scan in Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, what the target waiting time for the scan is, and how many have waited longer than the target waiting time?
answer: Waiting times for a CT scan, along with all diagnostic tests, are published on StatsWales at the following link: https://statswales.gov.wales/Catalogue/Health-and-Social-Care/NHS-Hospital-Waiting-Times/Diagnostic-and-Therapy-Services/waitingtimes-by-month

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What is the Welsh Government's position on the Service Animals (Offences) Bill that is currently before the UK Parliament?
answer: I am supportive of any proportionate measure that protects the welfare of service animals whilst in the line of duty. Should the Bill be successful in its passage, it could apply to Wales as well as England; Welsh Government officials are liaising with counterparts in Defra during the Bill’s passage.

name: Suzy Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain how the £33 million funding for the Life Sciences Hub Wales ties in with the Swansea bay city deal and confirm whether this is part of the overall Welsh Government contribution to the city deal or additional one-off funding?
answer: The £33m of funding jointly announced by the Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services and I, on 13 June is not for the Life Sciences Hub.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the progress on each of the milestones set out by the Valleys Task Force in November 2017?
answer: A progress report, the first since the delivery plan was published just eight months ago, is due to be published on the 10th July.  There is already evidence of positive change in the Valleys as a direct result of the actions set out in the delivery plan.  Although we are still collecting data to underpin this change, the progress report will demonstrate what high level actions have already taken place.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the progress of the Cwm Taf area pilot on publically owned land being maximised, as well as the list of economic opportunities gained by the pilot?
answer: Since the publication of the Cwm Taf study report, partner organisations have made good progress in making their public estate more productive, efficient and effective in supporting the delivery of their services.  A number of strategic sites have as a result of the study seen accelerated progress to realise residential and commercial development opportunities; good examples include joint collaborative working between Rhondda Cynon Taf CBC and Welsh Government at Coed Ely, Tonyrefail and Robertstown, Aberdare to develop industrial units on brown field sites.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish the evaluation of the Warm Homes programme's Nest scheme's home efficiency measures, as outlined in the Valleys Taskforce milestones?
answer: Earlier this year I agreed an extension to the pilot to run until 31 March 2019. This additional time will enable the effectiveness of various health professional referral routes to the Nest scheme to be fully tested and will also allow for seasonal NHS health pressures.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of up-to-date wellbeing indicators in the areas covered by the Valleys Taskforce, as well as a breakdown of the wellbeing indicators that existed in those areas prior to the establishment of the taskforce?
answer: The national wellbeing indicators are unchanged from the version laid in March 2016. Data are published at a regional level where it is available.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide details of the continuing Communities First projects which have been transferred to third sector organisations and local authorities, as well as a list of those projects which have stopped since Communities First was brought to an end?
answer: As a government, we have emphasised the need to ensure we deliver for those with the greatest needs and act to tackle the root causes of poverty.  Employment is seen as a key driver in lifting communities out of poverty. During the transition year, the majority of projects focused on helping people towards employment through jobs clubs, improving skills, addressing low level mental health issues and improving people’s confidence.  This supported a smooth transition to the use of the Legacy Fund and Communities for Work Plus delivery.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline where funding originally allocated to Communities First projects was distributed in the 2017-18 and 2018-19 budgets, along with a detailed breakdown of that funding?
answer: During 2017-18 Communities First was distributed to lead delivery bodies across Wales to deliver projects and support transition arrangements. There was no Communities First programme in 2018-19 hence no funding allocated to it in the 2018-19 budget.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the community asset transfers programme with the Wales Council for Voluntary Action and a breakdown of the assets transferred from the public sector to communities and the third sector since 2016?
answer: In 2015-16 the Welsh Government, through the Wales Council for Voluntary Action (WCVA), funded a pilot Regional Community Asset Transfer Support Officer post in Gwent; this post focused on supporting community organisations aiming to take over and manage local assets. This pilot concluded in September 2016 and the findings from it have informed our approach to developing a Made in Wales approach to community asset transfer. There is no current work programme specifically relating to community asset transfer with the WCVA. However, our Third Sector Support Wales grant to the WCVA provides the supporting infrastructure to the third sector in Wales around four pillars of activity: good governance; volunteering; sustainable funding; and engagement and influencing. All of these elements can assist organisations who are taking on community assets or considering doing so.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of the funding the Welsh Government has provided the Wales Council for Voluntary Action to oversee community asset transfers since 2016, by financial year?
answer: The Welsh Government does not provide specific funding to the Wales Council for Voluntary Action to oversee community asset transfers.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish a milestone report for the Well-being of Future Generations (Wales) Act 2015 as well as outline the steps taken to increase co-production in public services since 2016?
answer: In September we will publish the Welsh Government’s Annual Report, where we will report on progress against the Welsh Government’s twelve well-being objectives, which set out how we will use the Well-being of Future Generations Act to help deliver our programme for government, Taking Wales Forward, and maximise our contribution to the seven shared goals.  Also in September, the Chief Statistician will publish the second Annual Well-being Report for Wales, reporting on progress on the seven shared national well-being goals of the Well-being of Future Generations (Wales) Act 2015.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the Wales Council for Voluntary Action’s report, 'Empowering Communities', and its proposals for community anchors?
answer: I welcome discussion and debate on how we strengthen and empower communities. The ‘Empowering Communities’ paper is a useful and timely piece of evidence and thinking, and I have thanked the WCVA for engaging people from across the sector on this agenda.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how the third sector will be involved in the development of the marine protected area management framework and action plan before it is finalised?
answer: Earlier this year my department, on behalf of the Marine Protected Area (MPA) Management Steering Group, invited comments on the structure and content of the draft MPA Network Management Framework and Action Plan from the Wales Marine Advisory and Action Group. This group is a broad forum representing a wide range of marine interests such as Third Sector organisations, marine industries and coastal communities to discuss and debate marine policy in Wales.

name: Steffan Lewis
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide an update regarding discussions between the Welsh Government and the UK Government about the dispute over whether powers over state aid should be devolved, as outlined in the intergovernmental framework analysis document?
answer: The Welsh Government’s position is clear that these powers are devolved, but subject at present to EU rules. Officials from the Welsh Government’s European Transition Team met with officials from the UK Government and other Devolved Administrations last week to discuss post-Brexit state aids arrangements as part of ongoing discussions on withdrawal.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What is steps the Welsh Government taking to address welfare issues around the breeding and selling of kittens and cats?
answer: The Animal Welfare Code for Cats is currently being revised. This will provide an opportunity to strengthen the advice provided relating to the breeding and selling of kittens and cats. We will consult on the draft code before autumn recess. In addition, we continue to endorse the work of the Pet Advertising Advisory Council covering issues such as the responsible advertising and sourcing of pets.

name: Paul Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs

We will consult on the draft code before autumn recess. In addition, we continue to endorse the work of the Pet Advertising Advisory Council covering issues such as the responsible advertising and sourcing of pets.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain how the £100 million assigned to creating a joined-up system between health and social care will be used in 2018-19 and 2019-20, and state what targets will have to be met?
answer: The recently published A Healthier Wales: our plan for health and social care sets out actions which will kick start the shift to a whole system approach to health and social care, together with milestones for achieving those actions, over the next three years. A new Transformation Programme will oversee and be accountable for the implementation of the plan, including management of the £100 million Transformation Fund in 2018-19 and 2019-20.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: As there has been a 13 percent increase in instances of TB in Wales, will the Cabinet Secretary now review the eradication programme?
answer: It is important to view short term trends in TB statistics with caution due to their often volatile nature.  Since 2009 there has been a 34% decrease in new herd incidents and the longer term trend is downwards.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: How much money will be invested in the refill scheme for communities along the Wales Coast Path in 2018-19 and 2019-20, and how many refill points does the Cabinet Secretary aim to have along the path by 2020?
answer: My officials are in the process of finalising the details with partner organisations regarding the level of funding that will be supplied by the Welsh Government to deliver a National Refill scheme in Wales. My ambition is to have Refill points in all key communities along the coastal path by 2020.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ76633, will the Cabinet Secretary state how much the financial penalty will be, and provide the total amount of penalties levied at Arriva during each financial year, separately, for their time running the franchise, and the reasons for the penalties?
answer: Transport for Wales will closely monitor the performance of KeolisAmey and will penalise them should they not meet the benchmarks set out in the contract in areas such as cancellations, short formation of services, passenger time lost and the condition of stations and trains. It is not possible at this stage to advise the level of financial penalties as this will depend on the number and scale of the failure to achieve the benchmarks.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement regarding extending the train line to Hirwaun from Aberdare as part of the new Wales and Borders and south Wales metro rail franchise?
answer: The plans for the South Wales Metro that have been announced have been purposefully designed to allow for future network extensions. The potential option of converting the Aberdare to Hirwaun freight line to passenger use is one that has already been identified by Transport for Wales and the Welsh Government and has been discussed with bidders during the procurement process. It is not a current committed requirement on the new ODP, however Transport for Wales and the Welsh Government will continue to develop options such as this as part of future development of the rail network.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Does the Cabinet Secretary plan to retain the two-tier distinction between hackney carriages and private-hire vehicles in Wales, which a 2017 consultation on licensing reform confirmed a majority of people favoured?
answer: Following the Welsh Government’s public consultation that ended in September 2017 about the Law Commission’s proposed reforms for the licensing of taxis and private hire vehicles published in 2014, my officials have undertaken an initial scoping to determine the relevance of our proposals in relation to the Well-being of Future Generations (Wales) Act 2015, the Welsh Language Standards, the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child (UNCRC), Equality and Human Rights, together with Prosperity for All: The national strategy. Additionally, assessments will be needed in relation to health and wellbeing, justice, and market competition on the basis that these proposals are relevant to all these matters. I am proposing to publish a white paper later this year that will set out our proposals to reform the licensing of taxis and private hire vehicles in Wales which will be supported by our draft impact assessments, which shall also be subject to public consultation.

question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the impact on consumer choice and competition of banning private hire drivers from operating in more than one local authority area?

Additionally, assessments will be needed in relation to health and wellbeing, justice, and market competition on the basis that these proposals are relevant to all these matters. I am proposing to publish a white paper later this year that will set out our proposals to reform the licensing of taxis and private hire vehicles in Wales which will be supported by our draft impact assessments, which shall also be subject to public consultation.

A number of species focussed task and finish groups were also established to enable those with particular areas of expertise to inform and drive priority work streams on individual fisheries. While this trial was running, the Inshore Fisheries Groups were temporarily suspended.

question: What assessment has the Welsh Government made of the public health implications of LED street lighting?
answer: The Welsh Government is advised by Public Health England (PHE) in relation to light pollution and health for the protection of communities. PHE has advised that streetlights are intended to illuminate surfaces and the light that enters the eye from them has usually been reflected from at least one surface. The characteristics of this reflected light, including that from LED streetlights, will be different to that emitted directly by the streetlight. Generally people do not look directly into streetlights and the light emitted by streetlights will be safe in most locations where people will be.
