name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary working with anaesthetists and local health boards across Wales to improve working environments within this speciality, and what is the Welsh Government's response to the calls of the Association of Anaesthetists of Great Britain and Ireland's 'Fight Fatigue Campaign'?
answer: I expect all staff working in the NHS in Wales to able to have the best possible working environments; this is emphasised through the quadruple aim in ‘A Healthier Wales’ of having a motivated and sustainable workforce.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How many meetings has the Cabinet Secretary held with the UK Government Secretary of State of State for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs, over the past 6 months, specifying the date, time, place and reason for each meeting?
answer: Details of meetings are published quarterly as of 1 January 2017; a link to this information is available here:

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: When does the Cabinet Secretary plan to transfer responsibility for the Environmental Permitting Regulations section 3.1 Part (a) of Schedule 1, Part 2 from local authorities to Natural Resources Wales?
answer: Part A(1) installations carrying out the activities described in Section 3.1 of Part 2 of Schedule 1 to the Environmental Permitting (England and Wales) Regulations 2016 are already regulated by Natural Resources Wales. Part A(2) installations carrying out the activities described in that section are regulated by Local Authorities. There are no plans to change this arrangement of regulatory functions.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that Rocksteady Partners are the new promoters that have asked for the financial security that is associated with the Circuit of Wales to be released, which was referred to in the Welsh Government response to recommendation 13 of the Public Accounts Committee's report on the project?
answer: No. We have not received a request from Rocksteady Partners to release our security in the project.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the Welsh Government has received any information, including confirmation through the city region, about any proposal to develop a casino in connection with the Circuit of Wales site and plan?
answer: Whilst we are aware that discussions are taking place with local authorities in relation to the Circuit of Wales site, Welsh Government is not party to those discussions.  Neither my officials nor I have been formally approached or received information from any promoter or local authority about plans to develop a casino. However, as I made very clear on the floor of the Senedd on 11th July, the Welsh Government will not support the presence of a casino in one of the most deprived parts of the United Kingdom.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary comment on concerns raised relating to speeding traffic on the A5 near and through Betws-y-Coed, Conwy, and advise as to the results and recommendations of the most recent speed survey in this area?
answer: Road safety is of paramount importance.  As part of our Safe Routes to Trunk Road Schools initiative we installed part time 20mph speed restrictions in the vicinity of Ysgol Betws-Y-Coed in 2016/17.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many adult day patients are currently being treated for eating disorders at the tier 3 level of care?
answer: The Welsh Government does not hold this information.  You may wish to consider contacting the individual health boards for the information.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on progress made with HM Treasury and the devolved administrations on introducing a UK-wide levy or tax on single use plastic and a deposit-return system for drinks containers?
answer: We are currently working with HM Treasury following their Call for Evidence on single use plastics to inform the best way forward in the coming months. As well as helping to tackle unnecessary plastic use and the associated pollution it causes, I have made clear we want to avoid any disproportionate effects on Welsh businesses should HMT consider introducing a UK-wide tax.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What action does the Cabinet Secretary propose to ensure that Wales has the data collection systems necessary for accurate monitoring and recording of information regarding HIV and STIs on a national basis?
answer: In response to the recommendations from the review of sexual health services, a service specification is being developed which will outline the requirements for a case management and surveillance system for sexual health services in Wales. Once the specification is agreed, a national system will be developed which will host the mandated national dataset that has recently been consulted upon. The dataset will allow comparison to the other UK nations and provide information on all sexual and reproductive health. The new system will improve the HIV surveillance by linking all of the data sources related to HIV.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary give assurances that the Welsh Government is committed to developing at least an equivalent level of data regarding HIV and STIs to that collected in England and in a comparable format?
answer: In response to the recommendations from the review of sexual health services, a service specification is being developed which will outline the requirements for a case management and surveillance system for sexual health services in Wales. Once the specification is agreed, a national system will be developed which will host the mandated national dataset that has recently been consulted upon. The dataset will allow comparison to the other UK nations and provide information on all sexual and reproductive health. The new system will improve the HIV surveillance by linking all of the data sources related to HIV.

name: Suzy Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm when the media investment budget was paused and what action has been taken since this time to find an appropriate expert panel to provide advice for the media investment budget?
answer: The Media Investment Budget was put on hold following termination of the agreement between Pinewood and the Welsh Government known as the Collaboration Agreement, with effect from 31 October 2017. This followed Pinewood’s decision to withdraw from the all provision of fund management services, including those to the Welsh Government.

name: Suzy Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: While the media investment budget is paused, what advice and information is Welsh Government giving to applicants, productions companies, and other organisations that show interest in applying to the media investment budget at this time?
answer: We are currently reviewing appropriate processes for governance of the Media Investment Budget following Pinewood's decision to withdraw from third party fund management and we are currently working to finalise clear guidelines for the fund.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Is the Cabinet Secretary confident that the Welsh grid, especially in Mid and West Wales, will be able to cope with the increased demand on the electricity network when fossil-fuelled vehicles are phased out and domestic heating becomes more decarbonised through heat pumps?
answer: I am committed to ensuring we have a grid which supports our transition to a decarbonised economy, including meeting greater demands for electricity due to electric vehicles and decarbonised heating.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What action is the Cabinet Secretary taking to ensure the Welsh grid, especially in Mid and West Wales, will be able to cope with the increased demand on the electricity network when fossil fuelled vehicles are phased out and domestic heating becomes more decarbonised through heat pumps?
answer: Future network developments will need to be “smarter”, allowing demand and supply to be better matched locally, enabling both new and existing infrastructure to be used more effectively.  We have convened a group to work with us on solutions to ensure we have a grid suitable to support the low carbon transition.

name: Suzy Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What support has Welsh Government provided for the current Netflix production to be filmed in Wales and through which schemes or funding pots has this been provided?
answer: The Welsh Government has awarded a £484,879 grant via the Welsh Government’s Business Finance scheme to Eleven Film Ltd for their Netflix commissioned TV drama series Schooled.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What guidance has the Welsh Government issued to local health boards regarding how to deal with a suspected poisoning similar in nature to the Salisbury incidents?
answer: Following the recent incidents in Salisbury, England, key clinicians in Welsh health boards and ambulance services have been reminded of the importance of recognising possible cases caused by chemical, biological, radiological and nuclear incidents. Specific advice relating to the Novichok poisonings was also included in this communication to health boards.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What work is the Welsh Government undertaking in terms of addressing the pay gap affecting Welsh trainee doctors specialising in histopathology, and when does the Cabinet Secretary envisage that this pay gap between Welsh and English-based trainees will be eliminated?
answer: We are aware the contract introduced in England has had some impact on some specialties, in terms of variations in pay, both higher and lower. In Wales we are committed to working in social partnership and therefore have been monitoring the impact of the junior doctors’ contract in England alongside BMA Cymru Wales and NHS Employers Wales.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the steps the Welsh Government is taking to ensure health boards report on and roll out the new outcome focused measures for eye care by September 2018?
answer: The Welsh Government and the Planned Care Programme team have been working with the NHS Wales to support implementation and shadow reporting of the new measures alongside RTT from September 2018.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the likelihood of all health boards rolling out the new outcome focused measures for eye care by September 2018?
answer: The Welsh Government and the Planned Care Programme team have been working with the NHS Wales to support implementation and shadow reporting of the new measures alongside RTT from September 2018.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the provision of paediatric services at Llandudno General Hospital and advise what support and provisions are available for children under five years old and their families - in particular with regards to minor injury unit services?
answer: Substantive response

name: John Griffiths
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will Welsh Government increase increase funding for water vole conservation in order to enable the creation of a nature recovery programme to help protect their natural habitat, given the reduction in their numbers by up to 30 per cent between 2006 and 2015?
answer: I share your concern over the plight of the water vole and their natural environment.  Habitat loss and fragmentation, inappropriate watercourse management and predation by the introduced American Mink have all contributed to the decline in Water Vole numbers. There have been some successes like the Mink eradication and captive Water Vole breeding programmes, but we need to do more.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: Further to the Equality, Local Government and Communities Committee's Report ‘I Used to be Someone’, will the First Minister provide an update on how Wales is progressing in becoming in Nation of Sanctuary, and make a statement on his Welsh Government's vision for such a concept being put into practice?
answer: The UK Government is responsible for the majority of asylum and immigration policy but the Welsh Government will use all available levers to improve the lives of refugees and asylum seekers in Wales. The draft ‘Nation of Sanctuary Refugee & Asylum Seeker Plan’ reflects the Welsh Government’s commitment to the concept of making Wales a Nation of Sanctuary; to helping people to rebuild their lives here; and to recognising that refugees and asylum seekers have assets which strengthen our country.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide an update of the work of the Welsh Government in implementing recommendation 3 of the Equality, Local Government and Communities  Committee's report, ‘I Used to be Someone’, and advise specifically how he is working with the UK Government to tackle destitution amongst asylum seekers coming to Wales?
answer: We have asked the UK Government not to roll out the ‘Right to Rent’ checks in Wales until it resolves the discrimination issues evidenced in England. If ‘Right to Rent’ is rolled out in Wales, we will update Rent Smart Wales landlords training to ensure that landlords fully understand their responsibilities and the rights of refugees and asylum seekers.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister make a statement to outline all progress made by the Welsh Government towards implementing all recommendations of the ELGC Committee report 'I Used to be Someone' and advise as to what targets and timescales have been allocated to each?
answer: The Welsh Government’s draft ‘Nation of Sanctuary - Refugee and Asylum Seeker Plan’ has been developed in response to the recommendations made by the Equality, Local Government and Communities Committee report, as well as other issues which refugees and asylum seekers have raised with us. Welsh Government officials are currently considering the responses to the consultation on the draft plan which ended in late June. The Leader of the House and Chief Whip will provide an update on the implementation of the recommendations to all members when we publish the final version of the plan later this year.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: How is the Welsh Government monitoring local authorities' progress towards implementing all recommendations of the ELGC Committee report 'I Used to be Someone' , what targets and timescales have been given to local authorities to report back to Welsh Government, and what resources have Welsh Government provided to this end?
answer: Each of the 19 recommendations in the ELGC Committee Report were ostensibly for the Welsh Government to implement, rather than local authorities. However, local government will be a key part of how the Welsh Government seeks to improve outcomes for refugees and asylum seekers in Wales. Our draft ‘Nation of Sanctuary: Refugee and Asylum Seeker Plan’ sets out our proposals to address the Committee’s recommendations and other issues affecting these individuals. We will be analysing responses to consultations over the summer and aim to publish the final plan later this year.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How is the Cabinet Secretary working with colleagues, local authorities, and the health and social service sectors to monitor the mental wellbeing of asylum seekers and refugees in Wales, and what regional support and expertise is being developed to address such needs - with particular reference to north Wales?
answer: Earlier this year we launched a consultation on policy implementation guidance on refugee and asylum seeker healthcare.  It included details on how all agencies providing support for asylum seekers and refugees should collaborate to monitor and evaluate services to ensure their effectiveness.  The consultation closed at the end of June and we are currently considering the responses before publishing the final guidance.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister confirm, to date, how many asylum seekers and refugees were resettled in each local authority in Wales in 2016-17 and 2017-18?
answer: The UK Government does not publish complete statistics about the numbers of asylum seekers and refugees who are resettled in Wales. Figures relating to the number of refugees resettled under the Syrian Resettlement Programme, and the number of those currently receiving asylum support, are published in a quarterly immigration statistics release. This does not include the details of how many asylum seekers were granted refugee status, or arrivals under other schemes such as Section 67 of the Immigration Act 2016. The data can be found here:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: What specific support is available to refugees and asylum seekers in north Wales, with particular reference to legal advice and support, and how is the Welsh Government is working with north Wales local authorities to develop a long-term sustainable plan to support refugee assimilation in the region?
answer: Bawso is a crucial source of support for refugees and asylum seekers in North Wales. Their office in Wrexham has been open for 12 years. Two of Bawso’s key aims are to provide support and services with the intention of empowering service users to define and establish fulfilling and sustainable livelihoods; and to provide support, advocacy and training to enable service users to develop their aptitudes and realise their potential.   Bawso is a partner in the Asylum Rights Programme funded by Welsh Government.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: In light of concerns raised in the area, will the Cabinet Secretary consider closing the Llanfairfechan razor clam beds to prevent harvesting taking place during spawning seasons, and introducing quotas for the harvesting of razor clams at other times, in the long-term, and if so, when will this be implemented?
answer: The Razor Clam beds at Llanfairfechan are currently closed to both recreational and commercial razor clam gathering. As well as enforcing this closure , Welsh Government Officials are in the process of carrying out a stock assessment of the razor clam beds in the area. The results from this piece of work will inform any future management regime should the fishery reopen which will ensure the sustainability of this fishery.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update the Welsh Government's support to develop Welsh language speech to text technology, including the expected timetable for the technology to be used extensively?
answer: Speech-to-text will be one of the main priorities of the Welsh Language Technology Action Plan I will be publishing later in the year. We have been given valuable advice by the members of the Welsh-language Technology Board that I chair in drawing up this Action Plan. Bangor University's Language Technologies Unit has released an app called Paldaruo to crowdsource the voices of the public, with a cross section of accents and dialects to train the speech recognition engine. With the help of Welsh Government grants, this team has been combining command recognition technology with basic artificial intelligence in a prototype called Macsen. This is the beginning of creating some kind of Welsh language digital assistant. This Welsh language technology is available for anyone to download* free of charge under open licence. I am determined to ensure great improvements in speech-to-text Welsh language within the next four years.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: NA
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline the amount that the Welsh Government has invested to support the development of Welsh language speech-to-text technology, and what are the expected outcomes relating to this?
answer: To be answered by: Cabinet Secretary for Education

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Further to the written statement on 17 May 2018, will the Cabinet Secretary outline the terms of reference of the Welsh Government's independent advisory board on the Welsh in education strategic plans?
answer: The role of the WESP Advisory Board is to advise on plans to strengthen the infrastructure supporting the planning of Welsh-medium education in line with the ambition of Cymraeg 2050: A million Welsh speakers.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Further to the written statement on 17 May 2018, will the Cabinet Secretary outline the stage 2 aims and objectives of the Welsh Government review of Welsh in education strategic plans?
answer: The role of the WESP Advisory Board is to advise on plans to strengthen the infrastructure supporting the planning of Welsh-medium education in line with the ambition of Cymraeg 2050: A million Welsh speakers.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on fulfilling recommendation 2c of the Welsh Government's working group on language, work and bilingual services?
answer: The officials for the Minister for the Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning are working closely with Academi Wales to mainstream the Welsh language into all its activities and specifically, on an "Understanding Bilingualism" programme for the public sector more generally. They are also developing new training, "Leading in a Bilingual Nation", for leaders in public services in Wales.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on approving the current round of Welsh in education strategic plans?
answer: Sixteen WESPs have already been approved for the current round. Six local authorities remain to have their WESPs approved (Bridgend, Neath Port Talbot, Merthyr, Monmouthshire, Newport and Torfaen). Discussions with the remaining local authorities are concluding and will be announced shortly.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary commit to publishing all the Welsh language Plans in Education, which have been approved so far, on the Welsh Government's website, or provide links to those final versions on local authority websites?
answer: I will write to you and a copy of the letter will be placed on the internet.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline what consideration the Welsh Government has given to the possibility of setting long term targets - such as every 10 years, as well as even more ambitious ones - for the growth of Welsh-medium education?
answer: Our long term strategy for the Welsh language - The Cymraeg 2050: A million Welsh speakers - is driving a more ambitious approach to Welsh language planning. Integral to this new approach is a renewed determination to examine the way growth in Welsh-medium education is delivered through local authorities’ Welsh in Education Strategic Plans (WESPs). Outlined in the Cymraeg 2050 Work Programme 2017-21, is a commitment to create demand for Welsh-medium education through ambitious planning with achievable yet realistic targets.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Further to WAQ76770 and WAQ76771, is the Cabinet Secretary satisfied that the Welsh language is currently not treated less favourably than English in relation to the services and checks carried out by the Disclosure and Barring Service?
answer: The Disclosure and Barring Service state that until they draft their own Welsh language scheme they have been added to the Home Office’s Welsh Language Scheme. A member of the public can apply in Welsh for a DBS check, and can phone or write to the body in Welsh.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether she considers that the health workforce's professional regulatory bodies fall within the scope of the health sector in relation to Welsh language standards?
answer: The UK wide health professional regulatory bodies are not included in the Welsh Language Standards (No. 7) Regulations 2018, which apply to local health boards, Community Health Councils, the Board of Community Health Councils in Wales, and NHS Trusts in Wales.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: How is the Welsh Government working with local authorities and Sport Wales to ensure there are sufficient playing fields available for community sport in Wales?
answer: There are a number of ways in which the Welsh Government helps to ensure that people from within our communities have access to playing fields across Wales so that they can participate in sport.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: When does the Cabinet Secretary expect Public Health Wales to publish the next thematic review of deaths of children and young people by suicide or probable suicide?
answer: The thematic review of children and young people by suicide or probable suicide is being facilitated by the Public Health Wales Observatory and I suggest you write directly to Prof Ann John who will have further details of the expected publication date of this review.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What steps is Public Health Wales taking to ensure that all those bereaved by suicide have access to Help is at Hand Cymru?
answer: The National Advisory Group has agreed to work with Public Health Wales to raise awareness and the profile of the Help is at Hand resource. Prof Ann John has written to the Jacob Abraham Foundation and Tir Dewi providing copies of the Help is at Hand resource and invited both organisations to meet with Public Health Wales to discuss their concerns. These are direct actions following the concerns that were raised during my recent attendance at the Health, Social Care and Sport Committee inquiry into suicide prevention.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Does the Cabinet Secretary intend to inform the Vale of Glamorgan Council that the Biomass UK No 2 incinerator comes under the schedule 1 waste category of the Environmental Permitting Regulations, and therefore requires an Environmental Impact Assessment be carried out, and if so when?
answer: The Environmental Permitting (England and Wales) Regulations 2016 control certain activities which could harm the environment or human health. The Environmental Permit for the Biomass UK No 2 ltd project was granted by Natural Resources Wales.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish the list of each of the five prime organisations that have qualified through the Initial Pre Qualification Questionnaire stage of the Working Wales programme, for each of the three tender regions?
answer: The tender process for Working Wales is currently underway and is at the Invitation to Tender stage.  For commercial reasons we are unable to provide information on organisations successful at the Pre-Qualification Questionnaire stage until the tender process has concluded.  Information on successful bidders will be publicly available on Sell2Wales and the Welsh Government website once the tender process has concluded.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What has been the uptake rate for pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccination given to adults aged 65 and over in each year that it has been available?
answer: National vaccination uptake figures for pneumococcal polysaccharide vaccination (PPV) in adults in recent years are not currently available. The NHS Wales Informatics Service (NWIS) has recently rolled out modules of general practice software to collect the appropriate data. Public Health Wales is currently quality assuring and analysing the relevant data on PPV provided by general practices with a view to publishing their first report on PPV vaccination uptake in adults during September 2018.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Further to WAQ76826, will the Cabinet Secretary provide more detail on his considerations to better target rate relief for businesses - including what criteria is being considered, and what areas of consideration are being discussed with which Cabinet colleagues?
answer: Our permanent Small Business Rates Relief (SBRR) scheme came into effect in April this year.  This incorporates a number of changes better to target the scheme, including additional support for the childcare sector.  Alongside these changes, additional funding has been provided for relief for community energy projects, to extend our High Street Rates Relief, and to enable local authorities to use their powers to provide discretionary relief to support local businesses and ratepayers.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the funding for the dementia action plan that is to be delivered through the integrated care fund be ring-fenced for projects supporting people affected by dementia?
answer: Yes. This funding is ring fenced for projects supporting people affected by dementia.  When requesting funding, regional partnership boards and trusts are asked to provide details of the projects with reference to alignment to the relevant actions in the Dementia Action Plan.  This information will be considered against the criteria outlined in the ICF Dementia Action Plan addendum guidance (link provided) prior to the release of funding.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How will the Cabinet Secretary ensure the views of people affected by dementia will be reflected in the way funding is allocated in each regional partnership board area?
answer: The ICF Dementia Action Plan addendum guidance includes the expectation for regional partnership boards (RPBs), established under the Social Services and Well-being Wales Act, to engage closely with service users and carers on how the ICF should be used, this includes the funding specifically to support the Dementia Action Plan.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary detail the deadlines for accessing the dementia action plan funding, the process for applying, and whether funding is recurrent?
answer: Regional partnership boards and Trusts have been asked to complete the funding proforma contained in the ICF Dementia Action Plan addendum Guidance (link attached).  The deadline for funding requests is 31 July 2018.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a timetable for introducing Welsh-language standards for the health sector that will encompass professional regulatory bodies for the health workforce?
answer: I will not be introducing regulations to bring more bodies under Welsh language standards for the time being.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that the drafting of Welsh-language standards for the housing association sector has been completed?
answer: The drafting of Welsh language standards housing associations has not been completed.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the Welsh Government conducted a language impact assessment on the decision to end the rolling programme of introducing regulations relating to Welsh-language standards, and publish the content of any assessment made?
answer: A Welsh Language Impact Assessment has been conducted on the Welsh Language Bill and is updated when key policy decisions are taken.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: On what date was the decision taken to end the rolling programme of Welsh-language standards regulations?

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to mitigate the possible detrimental side effects of the decision to end the rolling programme of introducing Welsh-language standards regulations on the rights of Welsh people to use the Welsh language?
answer: Bodies must comply with their existing Welsh Language Schemes until they are required to comply with Welsh language standards. The Welsh Government and the Welsh Language Commissioner also have programmes in place to assist bodies from various sectors with their use of Welsh.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister confirm whether the Welsh Government is considering plans to make courtesy-level and basic level Welsh mandatory for Welsh Government staff, as introduced recently by the Assembly Commission?
answer: Staffing matters are the responsibility of the Permanent Secretary. I have asked her to write to you with the information you have requested.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm which Welsh Minister approved the Welsh Government's annual report on compliance with the Welsh language standards 2017-18?
answer: Minister for the Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary expand on the nature of each of the complaints on compliance with the Welsh language standards, which are mentioned in the Welsh Government's annual report on compliance with the Welsh language standards 2017-18?
answer: See the table below

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister confirm a) what security checks (for example, the Disclosure and Barring Service checks, vetting checks etc) are in place for prospective members of Welsh Government staff and b) what organisation or organisations are responsible for carrying out those checks?
answer: Staffing matters are the responsibility of the Permanent Secretary. I have asked her to write to you with the information you have requested.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister confirm that any new members of staff in the Welsh Government can undertake the required security checks currently in place entirely through the medium of Welsh if they wish to do so?
answer: Staffing matters are the responsibility of the Permanent Secretary. I have asked her to write to you with the information you have requested.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm in what language the white paper on the Welsh-language bill was drafted?
answer: The white paper ‘Striking the right balance’ was drafted in English.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the oral statement issued by the Minister for the Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning on 5 June 2018 was drafted in English and translated into Welsh?
answer: The oral statement issued by the Minister for the Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning on 5 June 2018 was drafted in Welsh in the first instance.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: What use was made of the report on the operation of the Hen Lyfrgell, commissioned by Cardiff Council, prepared by Phillip Lay, and which was paid for by a grant of £20,000 from the Welsh Government?
answer: The report was commissioned by Cardiff City Council and it is a mater for them what use is made of the report.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: What assessment has the Welsh Government made of the success of the £400,000 investment in the Hen Lyfrgell, and if it is considered a success, what is seen as proof of that success?
answer: There was a commitment from the beginning to evaluate the grant scheme and the centers. This work will be commissioned shortly. The Welsh Government has received a monitoring report from each project funded to monitor progress.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: What was the Welsh Government's vision for the Hen Lyfrgell when it agreed to provide it with £400,000 which had been allocated to support the Welsh language, and has that vision been realised?
answer: Cardiff City Council’s application for a capital grant was assessed by an independent panel against the capital grant scheme criteria .

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: What consideration has the Welsh Government given to whether Yr Hen Lyfrgell requires additional capital funding?
answer: I have not received a request for additional capital funding.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Has the Welsh Government asked for a report, or reports, on progress with the development of Yr Hen Lyfrgell?
answer: I have received a progress report and I will be commissioning an evaluation of the grant scheme and centers shortly.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What consideration has the Welsh Government given to looking at what level decisions are taken on determining the number of housing targets for different areas in Wales, and the possibility of doing so locally or regionally in the future?
answer: Planning Policy Wales states the Welsh Government’s Household Projections form part of the evidence for Local Planning Authorities in establishing their housing requirement in their LDPs. Authorities need to consider the projections alongside evidence of the housing needs of their local communities (from their Local Housing Market Assessments), together with other key issues such as what the plan is seeking to achieve, in particular links between homes and jobs.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the costs to local authorities, by authority, of bringing appeals relating to planning applications decisions before the planning inspectorate, during each of the last five years?
answer: This information is not held by the Welsh Government or The Planning Inspectorate Wales.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Welsh Government introduce drafts of the National Development Framework for all the options currently being considered, in addition to the preferred option?
answer: The National Development Framework will be based on the preferred option which includes aspects of all of the options currently being considered.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what advice or guidance the Welsh Government has provided to local planning authorities regarding the language or languages used in naming housing developments, streets and new infrastructure?
answer: Local Planning Authorities may use Local Development Plan policies and Supplementary Planning Guidance to encourage the use of Welsh names for new developments.  This advice is set out in Technical Advice Note (TAN) 20, paragraph 4.1.2.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on achieving the Historic Environment (Wales) Act 2016's aims in relation to the requirement for Welsh Ministers to prepare and maintain a list of historical place names in Wales?
answer: The Welsh Ministers entrusted the Royal Commission on the Ancient and Historical Monuments of Wales with the responsibility for creating and maintaining the List of Historic Place Names of Wales (https://historicplacenames.rcahmw.gov.uk/). Launched in May 2017, it is freely available online and as a dataset for local authorities and other public bodies.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What steps is the Welsh Government taking to encourage local authorities to unlock inactive trusts in Wales?
answer: I am aware of the guide published by the Community Foundation to encourage local authorities to work with their local Community Foundation to utilise inactive Charitable Trusts and will remind chief finance officers of the importance of reviewing any they hold.

name: Russell George
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: When will the Leader of the House be able to update Assembly Members on the successor project to Superfast Cymru?
answer: Work on the procurement exercise for the successor project continues with a view to awarding contract(s) as quickly as the process allows.  I intend to make a statement over the coming weeks to update members on progress and clarify the timetable.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the work of the Welsh in education strategic plans advisory board, including the board’s remit, timetable and priorities?
answer: The WESP Advisory Board was established in May, 2018.  Their remit is to advise on plans to strengthen the infrastructure supporting the planning of Welsh-medium education in line with the ambition of the Welsh language Strategy Cymraeg 2050: A million Welsh speakers.   The Board meets every 4-6 weeks and will be in operation until March 2019.  This timeframe can be extended as necessary.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the progress of the Heads of the Valleys road scheme, with particular reference to any updates relating to the completion date of the eastern section and any cost overruns that may have been incurred by Welsh Government during this project?
answer: On 27 November 2017 I issued a written statement advising on the status of the A465 Section 2 scheme and provided a further update on 6 June 2018. I have not received any indication since that time that the total overspend on the project has increased or that the completion date has been further delayed.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What actions will the Cabinet Secretary take to ensure that all Welsh health boards comply with the All Wales NHS Standards for Communication and Information (2013) and the Equality Act 2010, to ensure that visually impaired patients are able to independently access personal information?
answer: The All Wales Standards for Accessible Communication and Information for People with Sensory Loss set out the standards of service delivery that people with sensory loss should expect when they access healthcare that apply to adults, young people and children and makes recommendations which help the NHS in Wales improve services for patients with sensory loss.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many patients in Wales have been referred to an extracorporeal membrane oxygenation unit elsewhere in the UK?
answer: Between the financial years 2014-15 to 2016-17, 37 patients of all ages were treated at highly specialised centres in the UK providing extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) treatment.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many patients over the last five years in Wales would have been referred to an extracorporeal membrane oxygenation unit had one been available in Wales?
answer: Between the financial years 2014-15 to 2016-17, 37 patients of all ages were treated at highly specialised centres in the UK providing extracorporeal membrane oxygenation (ECMO) treatment.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Has the Cabinet Secretary determined whether a Clean Air Act is needed after the legislative programme did not include a commitment for a Clean Air Act for Wales?
answer: I am aware that there has been some interest in the development of a Clean Air Act for Wales. We already have access to a wide range of levers to take forward action needed to improve air quality, including planning, infrastructure, legislation, regulation and communication measures. A Clean Air Wales Programme is being established to consider evidence and develop and implement actions required across all Government Departments. If the clean air programme identifies gaps, new legislation will be developed to address this.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary be recommending to KeolisAmey that it procure hydrogen-powered trains, since they give zero-emissions at the point of use whilst negating the need for the installation of expensive pylons necessary for electrification?
answer: As I stated during our debate in plenary on 27 June 2018 the option of hydrogen technology was explored with bidders for the Wales and borders rail service during the procurement process.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the Welsh Government’s commitment to improve the electric car infrastructure of Wales by installing much needed rapid-charging points?
answer: We appreciate the growing demand for electric vehicle charging points across Wales. There are already around 500 publicly accessible charging points in Wales but we recognise these will need to be supplemented. In support of this, the Welsh Government is investing £2 million for additional electric charging points. Officials are currently scoping deployment, with a focus on rapid chargers.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What discussions has the Welsh Government had with local councils regarding the £2 million charging points grant scheme?
answer: We appreciate the growing demand for electric vehicle charging points across Wales. There are already around 500 publicly accessible charging points in Wales but we recognise these will need to be supplemented. In support of this, the Welsh Government is investing £2 million for additional electric charging points. Officials are currently scoping deployment, with a focus on rapid chargers.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What assessment has the Welsh Government made of the effectiveness of introducing 50 miles per hour speed limits, as well as other measures in five locations on Welsh roads, in improving air quality?
answer: The Welsh Government has a legal duty to ensure compliance with the EU Ambient Air Quality Directive (2008/50/EC).  There are 5 locations on our motorway and trunk road network that exceed the Directive limit level for NO2 - 40 µg/m3, these are, the A494 at Deeside, the A483 near Wrexham, the M4 between junctions 41 and 42 (Port Talbot), the M4 between junctions 25 and 26 (Newport), and the A470 between Upper Boat and Pontypridd.  Detailed investigations, including modelling using the approach set out in the Welsh Transport Appraisal Guidance (WelTAG), are currently underway to establish the measures required to achieve compliance with the Directive as soon as possible.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Following the UK Government’s proposals to assess if new homes and offices should be required to install charging points as standard and for new street lighting columns with on-street parking to have charging points in appropriate locations, will the Cabinet Secretary consider similar proposals for Wales?
answer: To successfully decarbonise transport in Wales it is essential to deploy all our policy levers to ensure we have the necessary supporting infrastructure for electric vehicles, including the provision of new charging points.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of setting community energy targets for local authorities, ensuring that planning delays are limited, assisting communities hoping to generate their own power and helping the Welsh Government achieve its target of 1GW of Wales's electricity through locally owned energy by 2030?
answer: Welsh Government work on the planning system generally seeks to focus efforts on making the planning system as streamlined and efficient as possible, whilst delivering good quality places for communities.  The Planning (Wales) Act introduced pre-application advice services in local planning authorities for communities to seek support early on in the development process.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What steps is the Welsh Government taking to train farmers so that the shelf-life of sheep carcasses from Wales can be extended?
answer: Extending the shelf-life of sheep carcasses is important and potentially a critical factor for our sheep sector as we move towards Brexit and the uncertainty surrounding future trade deals.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary conduct feasibility studies in relation to changing the T2 bus route that links Bangor in north Wales and Aberystwyth to serve the Blaenau Ffestiniog area?
answer: We continue to work closely with local authorities across Wales to explore opportunities to further enhance the Welsh Government funded TrawsCymru long distance bus network. We are currently developing proposals to introduce a new route linking Bangor to Chirk / Oswestry, and as part of this work will look at opportunities to introduce a new TrawsCymru service to Blaenau Ffestiniog.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What consideration has the Cabinet Secretary given to including Blaenau Ffestiniog in the Welsh bus network?
answer: Local authorities are responsible for assessing their communities’ requirements to be connected to local bus services. Where such services are not provided commercially, a local authority may utilise its own resources or its allocation from the Welsh Government’s Bus Services Support Grant to subsidise a contracted service.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What consideration has the Welsh Government given to the Royal British Legion’s loneliness and social isolation in the Armed Forces community report and how does it intend to respond to the report’s findings and recommendations?
answer: Tackling the causes of loneliness and social isolation is a national priority for the Welsh Government.  During 2018 we will publish for consultation a cross-government strategy on loneliness and isolation, with a final strategy published by March 2019.

name: Simon Thomas
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the effectiveness of the badger culling method used in England as a means of controlling bovine TB?
answer: The published analysis using the first two years of available data on the industry-led badger control in areas of Somerset and Gloucestershire, Brunton el al. (2017), showed that reductions in TB incidence were associated with culling in the first 2 years in both the Somerset and Gloucestershire intervention areas when compared to areas with no culling. An increase in incidence was associated with culling in the 2-km buffer surrounding the Somerset intervention area but not in Gloucestershire.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Further to WAQ76813, will the Welsh Government consider liaising with health boards to introduce a statutory target for typing up notes from the recordings of orthopaedics, ENT, and urology clinics, potentially as part of the Bill on ensuring that health organisations are open and transparent?
answer: The Health and Care Standards in place since 2015 already require health boards to ensure there is compliance with legislation and guidance to ensure effective, accessible, appropriate and timely communication and information sharing.  Open and honest communication is emphasised in the spirit of co-production and to ensure effective communication and sharing of information between members of the multi-disciplinary professional healthcare team and the patient.  This expectation would extend to ensuring that notes of consultations are typed up in good time following a consultation.. Should this not be the case then a concern should be raised with the local provider in the first instance.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ76835, will the Cabinet Secretary state by when the report on parking issues will be finished, clarify what information will be available to the public, and provide a breakdown of the expenditure of £6,500?
answer: My officials expect to receive the report by the end of the month and the final version will be available to view on request.  I will write to you as soon as possible regarding a breakdown of the expenditure and a copy of my letter will be published on the internet.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What action is the Welsh Government taking to ensure that individuals with Lyme disease or its symptoms are receiving adequate guidance, that delayed diagnosis, treatment and misdiagnosis are avoided, and to give assurances that individuals with chronic Lyme disease are referred to adequately trained consultants?
answer: The National Institute for Heath and Care Excellence guidance on Lyme disease, which covers awareness raising for healthcare professionals, clinical guidance on the diagnosis and management of the disease and information for patients, was published in April 2018.  The Chief Medical Officer has communicated this guidance to NHS Wales, with a directive to ensure that GPs and those working in Emergency Departments are aware.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: What action will the Welsh Government take to improve awareness of the risk of domestic electrical distribution fires?
answer: Over the last year, the Welsh Government has undertaken research into the source and cause of electrical distribution fires in Wales.  I published the findings of that research on 17 July (Electrical Fires in Wales: A review of the Evidence ) report.  I have made a number of recommendations which require action from Fire and Rescue Authorities (FRAs) to review and reinvigorate their electrical fire safety messaging.  My officials will monitor FRA progress against these.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the Welsh Gender Team, and explain why Welsh patients are still on waiting lists for treatment in England?
answer: We remain fully committed to improving gender identity services in Wales and we are providing additional funding to support these improvements.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the potential of Llanbedr airfield being developed for horizontal launches of space planes, and clarify whether the Welsh Government is spending any money on matters relating to the project?
answer: We are actively pursuing a number of enquiries relating to the horizontal launch at Llanbedr airfield and subsequent announcements will be made in due course.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Further to WAQ76808, will the Cabinet Secretary provide a list of all the repairs and replacements undertaken between 2010-11 and 2017-18, and state whether the he would be prepared to undertake a review of the spending by the Welsh Government on its own estate?
answer: The Welsh Government does not hold the information in the format you have requested. However we regularly review spending on our administrative estate demonstrating its efficiency and performance through the annual publication of our State of the Estate report (https://gov.wales/about/civilservice/how-we-work/facts-figures/our-buildings/state-of-the-estate-report-2016-17/?lang=en). Our next annual report (covering 2017-18) is due for publication later this year.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the fact that there has been a 20 per cent increase in the number of patients being directed from Llandudno MIU to district general hospitals since removing doctors in 10/2017, and explain whether provision might be available to ensure that a doctor is present daily?
answer: It should be noted that all Minor Injury Units (MIUs), whether staffed by Emergency Nurse Practitioners (ENPs) or by medical staff, will need to advise some patients to go to a District General Hospital (DGH) when their injury is too serious to be managed within the MIU eg a serious fracture or an injury which needs more complex imaging such as a CT scan.

name: Jack Sargeant
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the Mental Capacity (Amendment) Bill and have there been any discussions with the UK Government about the Bill?
answer: The UK Government introduced the Mental Capacity (Amendment) Bill into the House of Lords on the 3rd July 2018.  Whilst the subject matter of the Mental Capacity Act is reserved under the Government of Wales Act 2006, officials are actively working with the Department of Health and Social Care and stakeholders across Wales to assess, consider and represent the impact of the Bill as it moves forward.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: When will the Cabinet Secretary visit the Rutherford Cancer Centre in Newport?
answer: I received an invitation to visit the Rutherford Cancer Centre last year. However, given that the centre is currently being assessed by the Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee as part of the commissioning of proton beam therapy services in Wales, it would not be appropriate for me to visit until that process has completed.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline what progress has been made in relation to including information about the language skills of members of the care workforce on the Social Care Wales register, further to the Welsh language impact assessment - Regulation and Inspection of Social Care (Wales) Act 2016 - workforce regulations?
answer: The 2017 registration data reports produced by Social Care Wales (SCW) in relation to the four social care workforce groups currently registered in Wales (Adult Care Home Managers, Domiciliary Care Managers, Social Workers and Residential Child Care Workers and Managers) show that the percentage of workers providing information about their Welsh language ability has increased since 2016. Across the same period the reports show that for each of these groups the percentage reporting they were either fluent or had some Welsh increased, whilst the percentage reporting they did not speak any Welsh decreased.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a list summarising all correspondence between the Welsh Government and the Ministry of Justice relating to jails in Wales, providing details regarding the subject of the correspondence, for the last five years?
answer: As this question constitutes a Freedom of Information request, it will be handled as such and responded to within the prescribed timeframe.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide the information regarding the Welsh Government's calculations on the number of spaces that would be needed in the prisons estate to satisfy the needs of Wales?
answer: This issue is the responsibility of the Ministry of Justice and has not been devolved to the Assembly. However, the latest published figures advise that at the end of April 2018 the prison population in Wales was four thousand two hundred and ninety one.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what work the Welsh Government has or will do to develop internal capacity to prepare for the possibility of devolving policing and the criminal justice system in the future?
answer: These issues are the responsibility of the Home Office and Ministry of Justice and have not been devolved to the Assembly.  However, we would be very happy to start the work on creating additional capacity to cover policing and justice policy because we see this as a significant policy area where WG already has an input and some involvement.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Counsel General
question: Will the Counsel General confirm for the past five years: 1) how much the Welsh Government spends on legal advice and representation by external companies, and 2) how much of that expenditure went to legal companies that have their headquarters in Wales?
answer: Welsh Government legal expenditure is held as part of a wider record, including legal transaction costs, which cannot at present be extracted without scrutiny of a significant number of transactions.  The information is not therefore currently available in the format requested and could only be provided immediately at disproportionate cost. However, the process of disaggregating is underway and information can be provided when it becomes available.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Counsel General
question: Will the Counsel General outline to what extent the Welsh Government's Legal Department funds training places to support prospective lawyers to qualify as lawyers?
answer: The Welsh Government’s Legal Services Department currently funds 3 in-house Trainee Solicitor posts each year. Our intake in October 2018 will however increase to 6 trainees; and from October 2019 onwards we will provide places for 5 trainees each year. Welsh Government’s Legal Services Department sends our trainees to external organisations in order to gain litigation experience. The Welsh Government’s Legal Services Department also participates in an exchange of trainees which enables external trainee practitioners to spend 4 months working in the department.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that the Welsh Government/Transport for Wales have bought land in Cogan, Penarth to create a hub that links with the Cardiff city region metro and, if so, what was the full cost of that land?
answer: The Welsh Government bought a parcel of land at Cogan, Penarth that has been identified as a potential transport interchange and mixed use development. The cost of the land was £650,000 (excl. VAT).

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ76959, if the Welsh Government/Transport for Wales has bought land in Cogan, Penarth, will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the Welsh Government has any plans to develop that land?
answer: The Welsh Government bought a parcel of land at Cogan, Penarth that has been identified as a potential transport interchange and mixed use development. The cost of the land was £650,000 (excl. VAT).

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ76959, if the Welsh Government/Transport for Wales have bought land in Cogan, Penarth, will the Cabinet Secretary provide a map that demonstrates the size of the site and its relationship with any other land adjacent to it?
answer: The Welsh Government bought a parcel of land at Cogan, Penarth that has been identified as a potential transport interchange and mixed use development. The cost of the land was £650,000 (excl. VAT).

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ76959, if the Welsh Government/Transport Wales have bought land in Cogan, Penarth, will the Cabinet Secretary provide a timetable for the development of this site?
answer: The Welsh Government bought a parcel of land at Cogan, Penarth that has been identified as a potential transport interchange and mixed use development. The cost of the land was £650,000 (excl. VAT).

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ76959, if the Welsh Government/Transport for Wales have bought land in Cogan, Penarth, will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether private investment is associated with that land and provide full details of any investment of this kind?
answer: The Welsh Government bought a parcel of land at Cogan, Penarth that has been identified as a potential transport interchange and mixed use development. The cost of the land was £650,000 (excl. VAT).

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ76959, if the Welsh Government/Transport Wales have bought land in Cogan, Penarth, will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what discussions have been held with external bodies in relation to that land, naming that body/those bodies?
answer: In purchasing the land at Cogan the Welsh Government undertook the relevant due diligence during the purchase. In undertaking this due diligence there was liaison with: Berry Smith (Legal advisors for the vendor); Network Rail (to purchase some of the land); JEHU Construction (owners of the land prior to the Welsh Government); Cogan Hill Ltd (owners of portion of the land); Eversheds (Welsh Government’s Legal advisors); JLL (Welsh Government’s valuation advisors); WSP Parsons Brinkhoff (Welsh Government advisors on development potential and regeneration opportunities on the land); Vale of Glamorgan Council officers; Transport for Wales; and Hafod.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish the full report of the high-level report on T3 bus services?
answer: The Welsh Government commissioned Professor Stuart Cole of the University of South Wales to carry out a ‘high level’ strategic review of the TrawsCymru T3 route in April 2018. A summary of the findings of this review will be made available on the Welsh Government web site soon.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline what progress has been made in relation to the Welsh Government commitment to reduce travelling times and to make the T1 and T2 bus services between Bangor and Carmarthen, which goes through Aberystwyth, more reliable?
answer: We continue to work closely with local authorities and operators to maximise north to south travel opportunities using TrawsCymru bus services. For instance, in January 2018 we introduced additional journeys on the T2 service between Bangor and Aberystwyth to provide more connections throughout the day with other bus and rail services in Aberystwyth.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What discussions has the Welsh Government had with the UK Government regarding a Chepstow bypass?
answer: My officials are working with Monmouthshire County Council on a WelTAG Stage One Assessment of options to improve the flow of traffic along the A48(T) through Chepstow. This is a key cross-border route and stakeholders including Gloucestershire County Council as the A48 highway authority, Forest of Dean District Council as planning Authority and Chepstow Town Council are all involved in discussions.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What discussions has the Welsh Government had regarding congestion in Chepstow and the implications for the town's traffic flow of the abolition of the Severn Bridge tolls?
answer: My officials are working with Monmouthshire County Council on a WelTAG Stage One Assessment of options to improve the flow of traffic along the A48(T) through Chepstow. This is a key cross-border route and stakeholders including Gloucestershire County Council as the A48 highway authority, Forest of Dean District Council as planning Authority and Chepstow Town Council are all involved in discussions.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What discussions has the Welsh Government had with NICE regarding the delays in appraising Brineura?
answer: The Welsh Government has had no discussions with NICE about their appraisal of Brineura® (cerliponase alfa). We are aware of ongoing discussions between NHS England, BioMarin Pharmaceuticals and NICE and we are keeping abreast of these.

name: Russell George
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the process of awarding the contract for phase 2 of the Superfast Cymru project and outline the detailed timetable from now until the award of the contract?
answer: The procurement exercise is complex and we will award contracts as quickly as the process allows. It is absolutely essential and right that time is taken on this so the full benefits from the successor scheme can be achieved. I intend to make a statement over the coming weeks to update members.

name: Hefin David
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: What progress has the Welsh Government made against its designated indicators in terms of its commitment to sustainable development and to enhancing biodiversity in Wales?
answer: There are two indicators relating to biodiversity in our national indicators under the Wellbeing of Future Generations Act.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Local Government and Public Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state whether the Welsh Government is willing to nominate and dedicate existing or future forest conservation projects in north Wales to the Queen's commonwealth canopy?
answer: Wentwood is the only Welsh forest that is currently included in the Queen’s Commonwealth Canopy initiative. Welsh Government may consider supporting other woodlands for inclusion therefore please contact the managers of the Welsh Government woodland estate, Natural Resources Wales to discuss your proposals.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state whether money from the new Healthy and Active Fund could, subject to application, be made available for financing the replacement of the ski slope at Plas y Brenin, or the construction of a new one in Aberconwy?
answer: The overarching aim of the Healthy & Active Fund (HAF) is to improve people’s mental and physical health by enabling them to adopt healthy and active lifestyles. Phase 1 of the fund will support projects that strengthen and develop community assets.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Further to the Leader of the House and Chief Whip's press release concerning Superfast Cymru on 19 July 2018, will she state by when definitive information will be available about the successor project?
answer: It is absolutely essential and right that time is taken on this so the full benefits from the successor scheme can be achieved. The procurement exercise is complex and we will award contracts as quickly as the process allows. I intend to make a statement over the coming weeks to update members.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state which local authorities have successfully applied to the Town Centre Loans Fund, list the names of and amount given to each project supported, and state how many empty sites/premises have now been filled?
answer: Currently 17 Local Authorities are in receipt of Town Centre Loan Funding.  The allocations are as follows:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Further to WAQ76860 will the Cabinet Secretary state when she will announce whether there will be a deposit-return scheme for drinks containers, the amount of money spent on the project so far, and provide a list of solutions to the impact of single-use plastics on the environment being considered?
answer: I am considering the possibility of a UK-wide Deposit Return Scheme (DRS) for drinks containers and I met my counterparts from the UK and Scottish Governments to discuss this issue in July. I am keen to ensure that any scheme delivers optimum benefits for Wales and that we take account of risks and benefits to existing provision and recycling levels here, including the possible effect on Local Authorities’ statutory recycling targets. We are currently working to assess the possible impacts of a DRS and no decisions will be made until the outcome of a public consultation later this year.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why no grants are available to help young farmers/agricultural students registered with Farming Connect with the cost of trailer tests, and state whether funding can be made available in 2017/18 and 2018/19?
answer: There is a finite budget and many calls on the farming connect training budget. In the context of the significant challenges that lie ahead, the Government’s focus and that of individual farm and forestry businesses must at this point, seven months before we depart the EU,  be on addressing the more strategic training needs of the agriculture industry.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport
question: Following the recent Tourism and Agriculture Working Together event, and the Minister for Culture, Tourism and Sport's acknowledgment of the importance of the link between agriculture and tourism, will grants be made available to help farmers to develop existing or pursue new tourism-related schemes on their land?
answer: The Tourism and Agriculture working together event was a great success and emphasises again that a huge part of Wales’ thriving tourism sector is underpinned by the landscape and amenities produced by land managers; they shape the landscape and the landscape is a major attribute that brings people to Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: In light of the impact of dry weather on the land, and the winter/spring fodder crisis, will the Cabinet Secretary state what financial support the Welsh Government will make available to help farmers if they encounter a fodder shortage over the winter?
answer: I chaired a dry weather summit during the recent Royal Welsh Agricultural Show. Action to address the short and long-term implications of the on going dry weather is required at Governmental level but also at farm and industry levels. The action the Welsh Government is taking to support farmers has been published on our website.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that the Welsh Government will be publishing a new strategic framework for the Welsh language in the health and care sector when the current More Than Just Words framework comes to an end next year?
answer: The Welsh Government is commissioning an independent evaluation to assess the progress and impact of More than just words as a follow on strategic framework in improving Welsh language provision in health and social care. This will include making recommendations for future practice and monitoring long term progress. To allow time for the evaluation findings to contribute to future action, officials will be working with members of the Welsh Language in Health and Social Services Partnership Board to agree priorities for action for 2019/20 under the current strategic framework. This work will also involve aligning action to support delivery of the aims under the three key themes in Cymraeg 2050.

name: Mohammad Asghar

answer: The Welsh Government’s sustainable land management grant scheme, Glastir already provides funding for this purpose. It aims to deliver measurable outcomes at both a farm and landscape level and financial support is available for planting trees in areas that continue to be grazed as part of an agroforestry system.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
