answer: The benefits of this method will be considered during our work on future support for the sustainable management of land in Wales post Brexit. We are proposing a new land management programme that will replace the Common Agricultural Policy and we are seeking views on how this should be shaped. I urge you to encourage your constituents to contribute to the Welsh Government’s consultation ‘Brexit and our Land’ which can be found at the following website link:

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on plans to ensure that there is mother and baby unit provision, located in Wales , for women with perinatal mental illness?
answer: The Welsh Health Specialist Services Committee (WHSSC) which is responsible for commissioning inpatient beds have been asked to draw up options for inpatient care in Wales working alongside colleagues within health boards. These discussions are ongoing.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What is the Welsh Government doing to support personal, social, health and economic education?
answer: The Welsh Government recognises the importance of these issues and schools are able to address them through the school curriculum.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary publish the full data sets from July 2017 to April 2018 on Welsh Government procurement card spend?
answer: The July to September 2017 Welsh Government procurement card spend data is on the Welsh Government website and can be found at:  https://gov.wales/about/civilservice/how-we-work/facts-figures/ourfinance/procurement-card-data/?lang=en.

name: Neil McEvoy
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

answer: I can confirm that the Welsh Government will continue to provide funding for the All Wales Schools Liaison Core Programme in 2019-20.

name: Neil McEvoy
response_name: Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm when residents in Fairwater, Cardiff will be eligible for 30 hours' free childcare per week?
answer: Our Childcare Offer is intended to support working parents, providing  a combined 30 hours of government-funded early education and childcare for eligible three and four year olds for up to 48 weeks of the year.

name: Hefin David
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What discussions has the Welsh Government had with the UK Government in order to ensure and maintain the supply of insulin to NHS Wales in the event of a no-deal Brexit?
answer: The Medicines and Healthcare products Regulatory Agency (MHRA), an executive agency of the Department of Health and Social Care, has responsibility for ensuring the UK's supply chain for medicines is safe and secure.  The Welsh Government is working with the UK Government to ensure supplies of medicines are maintained for patients following the UK’s exit from the European Union (EU).

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: First Minister

answer: Staffing matters are the responsibility of the Permanent Secretary. I have asked her to write to you with the information you have requested.

name: David Rees

answer: The Welsh Government has a legal duty to ensure compliance with the Ambient Air Quality Directive.  Detailed investigations, including modelling using the approach set out in the Welsh Transport Appraisal Guidance (WelTAG) have been underway since October 2017 to establish those measures required to achieve compliance with the Directive a soon as possible.

answer: The Welsh Government has a legal duty to ensure compliance with the Ambient Air Quality Directive.  Detailed investigations, including modelling using the approach set out in the Welsh Transport Appraisal Guidance (WelTAG) have been underway since October 2017 to establish those measures required to achieve compliance with the Directive a soon as possible.

name: David Rees

answer: The Welsh Government has a legal duty to ensure compliance with the Ambient Air Quality Directive.  Detailed investigations, including modelling using the approach set out in the Welsh Transport Appraisal Guidance (WelTAG) have been underway since October 2017 to establish those measures required to achieve compliance with the Directive a soon as possible.

name: David Melding
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister provide the targets and indicators the Welsh Government is using for the reduction of youth homelessness, as well as a breakdown of both the £2.6m funding promised and £20m for homelessness services by local authority area?
answer: Data on the age and gender of people seeking help with housing from local authorities in Wales, including whether those aged 16 to 21 have spent time in B&B, is captured as part of the statutory homeless data return.  In addition, data on accommodation outcomes for those leaving the care system is also captured as part of the social services data return.  Taken together, they provide us with a detailed picture of youth homelessness in Wales which we can monitor year on year.

name: David Melding
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how many interventions the Welsh Government made and how many warning notices it issued regarding the quality of social housing in 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18?
answer: The Welsh Government has not intervened or issued warning notices regarding the quality of social housing. At 31 March 2017, 86% of social housing (192,302 dwellings) were compliant with the Welsh Housing Quality Standard (WHQS) (including acceptable fails). All social landlords must improve their housing stock to meet the WHQS by no later then December 2020.

name: David Melding
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a local authority breakdown of dwellings which are not compliant with the Welsh Housing Quality Standards for 2017?
answer: The table shows a breakdown of dwellings which are not compliant with the Welsh Housing Quality Standard for each local authority landlord, and for each landlord that has received the local authority stock following transfer to a Registered Social Landlord (RSL). However the data for the remaining RSLs are not collected by local authority area.

name: David Melding
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how many applications were made in 2015-16, 2016-17 and 2017-18 to Rent Smart Wales, broken down by online and paper applications?
answer: The breakdown provided by Rent Smart Wales is as follows:

name: Vikki Howells
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What assessment has the Welsh Government made of the sensitivity threshold that has been set for the introduction of FIT for bowel screening in Wales, including how it compares with other UK nations?
answer: Through careful modelling Public Health Wales (PHW) has advised that FIT is introduced at a sensitivity of 150 micrograms (<U+F06D>g) of haemoglobin per millilitre of faeces which would allow the test to be introduced safely and sustainably from January 2019.

name: Vikki Howells
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: What plans has the Welsh Government made to optimise the FIT for bowel screening test, following its introduction in Wales?
answer: Through careful modelling Public Health Wales (PHW) has advised that FIT is introduced at a sensitivity of 150 micrograms (<U+F06D>g) of haemoglobin per millilitre of faeces which would allow the test to be introduced safely and sustainably from January 2019.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What action is the Welsh Government taking to increase the number of students registering to undertake teacher training courses through the medium of Welsh?
answer: We are fully committed to the continued development of the Welsh language and the aim of one million Welsh speakers by 2050. The education system has a key role to play in achieving this aim so we need to ensure there is a sufficient workforce to provide Welsh-medium education.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the reduction in the number of students studying through the medium of Welsh?
answer: On 26 July 2018 the Welsh Government published its annual statistical report - Welsh language in higher education institutions. The report noted that the number of students learning some of their degree through the medium of Welsh has fallen in 2016/17 from 7,780 to 6,870.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Following the Drought Summit the Cabinet Secretary attended at this year's Royal Welsh Show, will she provide a list of the actions and plans the Welsh Government will be taking forward following the summit to address the difficulties this summer's weather conditions are causing Welsh farmers?
answer: It is important to recognise this is an issue on which individual farmers, industry bodies and Government must work together, we all have a role to play. A list of the specific actions and support I have made available to farmers has been published on our website:

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide details of the progress that the Welsh Government has made in securing approval for Public Service Obligation designation of nine routes in and out of Cardiff Airport?
answer: We continue to work with the European Commission and counterparts in UK Government to impose a number of new domestic aviation Public Service Obligations (PSOs) routes. One of the routes, between Cardiff and Anglesey, is currently being procured through public tender. The remaining routes will be put to the market in due course.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a copy of the orthopaedic plan, explain why 3,385 patients were waiting over 36 weeks for treatment in May 2018, and note what measures he is taking to help the health board deal with increased referrals for trauma and orthopaedic treatment since December 2017?
answer: The National Planned Care Programme published the Wales National Orthopaedic Plan as a Welsh Health Circular, WHC (2015) 034, on 30 July 2015 and is available at: https://gov.wales/topics/health/nhswales/about/planned/plans/?lang=en

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: What action is the Welsh Government taking to encourage residents not to flush wipes and cotton buds, and explain whether she would be willing to cooperate with Welsh Water and Natural Resources Wales so to promote the message across Wales?
answer: We are supporting through our Water team, the 21st century drainage programme that is being led by Dwr Cymru Welsh Water (DCWW) on behalf of the UK water sector.  Their work includes encouraging customers not to flush products which contain plastics such as wet wipes, as these block sewers.  We are also supporting the programme’s campaigning to get wet wipes to be clearly and boldly labelled as non-flushable to help users understand these are not to be flushed.  More locally here in Wales, we supporters of DCWW’s ‘stop the block’ campaign which informs customers of the costs and pollution caused by flushing wet wipes and other products which contain plastics down the toilet.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why there are no weekend flights to and from Anglesey Airport, and state whether the flights could leave the island earlier in the morning and Cardiff later in the evening?
answer: Anglesey airfield is run by the Ministry of Defence (MoD), to support military operations.  Civilian services are operated from Anglesey with the welcome cooperation and support of the MoD.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state what measures the Welsh Government is considering taking to help ease traffic congestion on the A470 in Llanrwst, and whether a public consultation might be held so that residents can have a say?
answer: Our national congestion Pinch points Programme is focussed on the most heavily congested sections of the trunk road and motorway network in Wales where severe congestion is a daily problem. The A470, Llanrwst has not been identified as a priority area as part of this current programme (2017/2021). However, we continuously monitor the trunk road network to identify future changes and will consider this location should it meet the appropriate criteria.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state what targets the Wales Farm Safety Partnership has to meet so that the £46,000 investment represents value for money, and explain what funding is available to farms which cannot afford to invest in measures to eliminate hazards and reduce risk of accidents within their business?
answer: Through a range of actions and interventions, the Wales Farm Safety Partnership is focused on one strategic outcome; to deliver year on year reductions in the number of deaths and serious injuries that occur on farms in Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Why do two of the five options under consideration for the removal of the roundabout on the A55 in Llanfairfechan involve the potential demolition of new homes, and what assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of these two options?
answer: A consultation process is currently in progress to decide on the most appropriate solution to replace the existing roundabout at Junction 15 on the A55.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport

answer: The information requested is currently being prepared by my officials as part of the investigations into potential measures.

name: Dai Lloyd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a breakdown of how much money was spent, by each health board, to commission ophthalmic surgery, treatment or outpatient capacity from private providers, for each of the past five financial years?
answer: This information is not held centrally.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What estimate has the Cabinet Secretary made of the costs of providing broadband to each of the 11 schools in Wales that are currently not able to access broadband?
answer: I am pleased to confirm that services have been identified for ten of the eleven schools where broadband was previously not available. Ysgol Llanychllwydog remains the only school where a confirmed service has not been identified and work continues to explore wider community benefits from providing a connection to the school but at this stage a set budget has not been agreed. The good news is that a 4G service will be provisioned at the school within the next few weeks which will provide an improved connection as an interim measure whilst investigations continue for longer term options.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education

answer: As mentioned in my joint response to WAQ75693, 75690 and 75692, in terms of intervention taken by local authorities with schools causing concern, Welsh Government officials carried out exercises in December 2013 and 2015 asking local authorities to provide copies of all warning notices issued to schools since the commencement of the provisions in the Schools Standards and Organisation Act 2013 to assess the use of warning notices.

name: Darren Millar

answer: The National Academy for Educational Leadership was launched on 16 May 2018 which included the announcement that the new Chief Executive Office for the NAEL would be Huw Foster Evans.  The first meeting of the new Board took place on 16 July 2018.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What indicators and targets will the Cabinet Secretary be using to measure the outcomes of the National Academy for Educational Leadership?
answer: Officials are currently negotiating all indicators and targets for the National Academy for Educational Leadership now that the Board has been fully established and is in place.

response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education

answer: The Natural Resources Wales (NRW) review on the Use of Firearms on land managed by NRW and its recommendations have been carefully considered by the Welsh Government. In considering all the evidence and recommendations, we noted the review did not go as far as to consider some of the wider policy and ethical issues.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

answer: The Welsh Health Specialist Services Committee (WHSSC) which is responsible for commissioning Mother and Baby Unit  inpatient beds have been asked to draw up options for Mother and Baby Unit  care in Wales working alongside colleagues within health boards. These discussions are ongoing.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How long will the Welsh Government continue to use 2008 and 2009 - the start of the TB health check - as a reference to provide headline statistics on TB reduction levels, given that these years represent some of the highest levels of bovine ever TB recorded?
answer: Statements made on changes in disease levels since 2008 are intended to measure progress since the introduction of the TB Eradication Programme.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the implementation of Global Futures?
answer: In October 2015, the Welsh Government published ‘Global Futures – a plan to improve and promote Modern Foreign Languages (MFL) in Wales’.

name: Vikki Howells
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that as part of the recently announced review into third party sales of puppies there will be consideration of a ban on the sale of kittens in pet shops?
answer: Following my oral statement on the 19 June I have confirmed my intention to build on the improvements made since the Animal Welfare (Breeding of Dogs) (Wales) Regulations 2014 were introduced by investigating the potential banning of third party sales of puppies. Officials will now look at options to take this forward. In addition, we continue to endorse the work of the Pet Advertising Advisory Council covering issues such as the responsible advertising and sourcing of all pets, including kittens.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Are the outreach teams, which were promised to support bids from communities for better broadband connectivity in parts of rural Wales, now in place?
answer: The outreach teams are intended to form an integral part of a novel scheme that supports communities not reached by the successor scheme to Superfast Cymru but also where voucher support may not be the answer. This approach will not be firmed up until the current procurement has concluded and we have clarity on where the successful suppliers will reach.

name: Russell George
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Will the Leader of the House provide details of what complexities and unforeseen issues have occurred, resulting in a delay to the award and implementation of the successor scheme to Superfast Cymru?
answer: Whilst appreciating your interest in the delays surrounding the successor scheme, I am afraid that, due to commercial confidentiality, I am unable to update you on the specific complexities and issues that have occurred. It is imperative we fully adhere to the process. Once the process has concluded I intend to make a statement to update members.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Leader of the House and Chief Whip
question: Will the Leader of the House and Chief Whip explain why some superfast-enabled premises can only be provided with the service by a single company, and state what action the Welsh Government is taking so to ensure that residents have a number of providers to choose from?
answer: Thank you for bringing this matter to my attention. Could I ask that you forward the detail of the issues you raise to me to allow us to investigate the matter further?

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the progress being made by the Welsh Government in the current round of funding for the Rural Community Development Fund?
answer: The current Rural Community Development fund window closed to applicants on the 12 June 2018. 42 expressions of interest were received under this round and 12 applications progressed to the next stage and have been invited to submit a full project application at the beginning of August.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on the progress the Welsh Government is making in relation to reinstating Welsh lamb and beef to the United States and Welsh lamb to Saudi Arabia?
answer: Welsh Government is investing £1.5m over three years for Hybu Cig Cymru (HCC) to deliver an Enhanced Export Development Programme for Welsh red meat which includes intensifying work to obtain access to new export markets, including the US and Saudi Arabia. As part of this, HCC is working closely with the UK Export Certification Partnership (UKECP) to secure access to key export markets for Welsh red meat.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: What guidance does Welsh Government issue to social landlords about passing charges for rodent control onto tenants, including those who are claiming benefits ?
answer: No guidance has been issued by Welsh Government to social landlords specifically about passing charges for rodent control onto their tenants.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state what support adults should be receiving after being diagnosed with mental health concerns, and provide a list of the post diagnosis after-care options provided by each health board in Wales separately and the waiting times for them?
answer: There are a wide range of possible interventions and treatments for each mental health condition.  As with physical health, there are    a number of potential diagnoses.  Clinicians assess and consider a range of approaches, which are then discussed with the service user to determine the best approach.  NICE guidelines and the Matrics Cymru provide guidance on specific treatments and clinicians may also recommend practical solutions to support each individual.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the Welsh Government amend the Learner Travel (Wales) Measure 2008 so that provision of travel arrangements for learners in post-16 education becomes mandatory, and explain whether funding can be made available to help local authorities struggling to meet the cost of this service?
answer: The Learner Travel Measure (Wales) 2008 sets out the duties on local authorities regarding transport for learners including providing free transport based on age, distance and aptitude criteria for learners of statutory school age.  Local authorities are able to make additional discretionary transport arrangements for learners in their areas.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Minister for Children, Older People and Social Care
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to increase the allowance for carers who look after loved ones?
answer: The Welsh Government does not have responsibility for welfare benefits, including Carers Allowance.  This rests with the UK Government through its Department for Work and Pensions.  The Welsh Government is acutely aware of the negative impact of the UK Government’s welfare reforms in Wales, and we continue to relay our concerns to the UK Government.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary had regarding the professional registration fees for teachers, which have been abolished in England?
answer: The fee level for practitioners registered by the EWC was last consulted on in 2016, when youth workers and work based learning professionals were added to the category of practitioners required to register with the EWC.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary had regarding the fact that annual fees for the Education Workforce Council do not align with academic years and result in teachers paying fees while they are not practising teachers?
answer: The fee level for practitioners registered by the EWC was last consulted on in 2016, when youth workers and work based learning professionals were added to the category of practitioners required to register with the EWC.

name: Steffan Lewis
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many endoscopy units have achieved Joint Advisory Group gastrointestinal endoscopy accreditation?
answer: Four NHS endoscopy units in Wales have achieved level two Joint Advisory Committee accreditation and two units have achieved level one accreditation.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the impact of the working pattern of the Chair of Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board, who works 15 days a month?
answer: The details including the role of the Chair of Betsi Cadwaladr University Health Board was set out in the information pack for the public appointment process. The time commitment is based on a notional minimum of fifteen days per month. However, this will be subject to organisational demands and is often higher than the minimum requirement. I met with the Chair designate earlier this month and he is already undertaking detailed preparatory and planning work before he officially starts in post.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state what consideration has been given to democratising health boards so that their members have to face election and greater accountability?
answer: The Welsh Government White Paper ‘Services Fit for the Future’ consulted on proposals to strengthen the governance of local health boards so they function effectively as integrated, accountable, population-based organisations.  The proposals included:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why patients who have been stopped from receiving mesh for stress urinary incontinence in pelvic organ prolapse surgery are waiting around two months to see their consultant to discuss alternative treatment, and state whether he will take measures to have those patients affected seen sooner?
answer: Baroness Cumberlege’s announcement concerning mesh in early July was followed by separate advice from the Chief Medical Officer for Wales and the Mesh Clinical Advisory Group which required health organisations’ compliance with a number of high vigilance procedures. Health boards have been introducing the new procedures before arranging clinical appointments with patients. I expect health boards to be in a position to arrange timely discussions with all patients about the range of treatment options that are appropriate for them. The Women’s Health Implementation Group will review the vigilance approaches adopted by Wales’ health boards and lead work to improve care for women affected by mesh related problems.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Further to WAQ76950, will the Cabinet Secretary state how many Emergency Nurse Practitioners (ENPs) are on duty at one time in Llandudno MIU, and explain whether it is acceptable that a constituent recently found that the unit only had one ENP and a 4 hour waiting time?
answer: This information is not held centrally within the Welsh Government, but would be available directly from the health board.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Following on from the trial of free weekend travel on the Traws Cymru service, will the Cabinet Secretary state how much money the scheme has cost the Welsh Government, and clarify whether Assembly Members will be consulted on whether the initiative should continue?
answer: Between its launch in July 2017 and 31 March 2018, the TrawsCymru free weekend travel initiative generated an additional 133,391 passengers, an increase of more than 65 per cent compared with the earlier, equivalent period, and cost approximately £780,000. The Decision Report confirming my extension of the initiative into 2018-19 was published on 10 May 2018.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state why there has been a major annual increase in the number of sickness absence days at Natural Resources Wales between 2015/16 and 2017/18, and provide a report on the impact 13,331 days of sick leave on the services offered by the public body in 2017/18?
answer: The increase in the number of sickness absence days across the three years quoted is a reflection of the work done to improve reporting of sickness absence in Natural Resources Wales (NRW).

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide the data on the success or otherwise of the TrainWorkLive campaign?
answer: Train Work Live is a marketing campaign highlighting medical and nursing careers in Wales both within the UK and internationally.  The campaign is designed to increase the visibility and reach of NHS Wales and is underpinned by local recruitment activities undertaken by health boards, trusts, the Wales deanery and GP practices.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the culturing of post-mortem samples taken from animals slaughtered with bovine TB and confirm the timeframes for these cultures to be undertaken and the results conveyed to farmers?
answer: The bacteriological culture of samples for Mycobacterium bovis can be complex and the timeframes for culturing and subsequent reporting of the results to farmers can be extremely variable due to multiple possible permutations. For example post mortem examination findings, histological findings and the initial results of both liquid and solid culture.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many cultures were taken in respect of bovine TB over the last three years and provide a breakdown of the figures for each respective year and further indicate the average timeframe of each culture to be determined and sent back to the farmer?
answer: The table below sets out the number of Welsh bacteriological culture samples submitted over the last 3 years (year to date 2018) and the average time it took from receipt of these samples at the laboratory to approval of the culture result (in working days). This does not take into account the time taken for the sample to reach the laboratory (usually within 5 days from collection), or the time taken to notify the farmer of the result, by APHA Field Wales. Farmers are notified of the result at the earliest opportunity.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the purpose and business case put forward for the loan made by the Welsh Government to Tidal Lagoon Power and confirm if a grant was first considered and if so, outline the reasons why it was not made?
answer: As previously reported, the Welsh Government provided Tidal Lagoon (Swansea Bay) Plc. with a £1.25 million commercial loan in February 2015.  This secured commercial loan was drawn down to support the development costs of the Swansea Bay Tidal Lagoon project.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport

answer: Secured loans to both Tidal Lagoon (Swansea Bay) Plc and Tidal Lagoon Plc, in total amounting to £2.5m, were made on a commercial basis. Neither loan has been repaid to date; nevertheless we continue to review the loans and our options for recovering monies owed.

name: Neil McEvoy
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to increase the amount of electric vehicle charging points in Cardiff?
answer: We appreciate the growing demand for electric vehicle charging points across Wales. There are already around 500 publicly accessible charging points in Wales but we recognise these will need to be supplemented.  In support of this, the Welsh Government is investing £2 million for additional electric charging points.  We are currently scoping deployment, with a focus on rapid chargers.

name: Angela Burns

answer: Subject to confirmation of sufficient vaccine availability, the working assumption is that the HPV vaccine will be provided to boys in the 2019/20 academic year. Officials and health professionals are considering the merit of a catch up campaign and a recommendation will be made in due course.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary detail the effectiveness of the delivery of priority treatment for veterans and the advice that is being provided to health boards to ensure that staff are fully aware of how to apply the priority treatment policy?
answer: I understand the Royal British Legion has previously undertaken some research into the application of priority treatment which found awareness was variable among managers and clinicians.  However, the research was primarily conducted among English NHS providers.  As part of our  commitment to raising awareness of the Armed Forces Covenant and healthcare priority for veterans, in September 2017, we issued WHC (2017) 41 Armed Forces Covenant - Healthcare Priority for Veterans to health boards and NHS Trusts in Wales. This guidance provides GPs, consultants, allied health professionals and administrative staff with information on the process of referring veterans eligible for priority healthcare. It goes further than previous guidance in that it encourages staff to ask the question to identify individuals as veterans and to record their veteran status using a consistent clinical code.  We have also worked with the Royal British Legion to facilitate their attendance at clinical and other NHS representative bodies to promote the principle of priority treatment.

This guidance provides GPs, consultants, allied health professionals and administrative staff with information on the process of referring veterans eligible for priority healthcare. It goes further than previous guidance in that it encourages staff to ask the question to identify individuals as veterans and to record their veteran status using a consistent clinical code.  We have also worked with the Royal British Legion to facilitate their attendance at clinical and other NHS representative bodies to promote the principle of priority treatment.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary indicate when prostate artery embolisation is to become available in Wales, as it is now in England?
answer: Prostate artery embolisation is currently not offered in Wales.   The Wales Urology Board has considered the effectiveness of the technique compared to more standard treatment. Our current clinical practice for prostate treatment includes holmium laser enucleation of the prostate (HoLEP), Green Light Laser and transurethral resection of prostate (TURP).

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: With regard to her response to WAQ77016, will the Cabinet Secretary outline how many local authorities have responded to the most recent exercise on warning notices, and will she also publish the replies she has received so far?
answer: Seven local authorities responded to the most recent exercise carried out in April 2018 in relation to the issue of warning notices and intervention activity.  Two local authorities, Swansea and Gwynedd, advised that they had not issued any warning notices or undertaken any intervention activity in the last 12 months. Cardiff, Pembrokeshire, Powys and Torfaen confirmed that warning notices had been issued and previously copied to the Welsh Government. Caerphilly informed that it had issued a pre-warning notice to one school setting out a number of actions for the school to address, and intervention notices were issued to two of its schools informing that the local authority was appointing additional governors to the schools’ governing bodies. My officials will continue to monitor the situation and carry out similar exercises periodically.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

answer: The lung transplant programme is a national transplant programme and there are no lung transplant centres in any of the Welsh health boards.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many successful lung transplants have been undertaken since 2010?
answer: Between 2010/11 and 2017/18, there were 1,528 lung transplants performed in the UK including 94 lung only transplants performed on Welsh residents.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many patients have been refused lung transplants due to lack of organ availability in each year and by each local health board since 2010?
answer: Patients meeting the criteria for lung transplant are registered for transplantation but organ availability influences the number of transplants which can occur. There has been an increase in the number of people waiting for a lung transplant in recent years, yet the number of lung transplants has not changed.  Reasons for this are being investigated but could include changes in the donor profile, with more donors now over 50 and with existing health problems.  This can make successful donation and transplantation of more delicate organs such as lungs more difficult.  This has resulted in an increase in the disparity between the numbers listed and transplanted. Since 1 January 2010, 32 Welsh residents have died whilst waiting for a lung only transplant.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to respond to the animal feed crisis that is likely to hit farmers in Wales as a result of the recent dry weather?
answer: On 22 August I announced a new loan facility to help those farmers who will not be able to receive their Basic Payment Scheme (BPS) payment on day one (1 December) of the payment window. This will make sure all farm businesses are in a better position to deal with the impact of fodder availability this coming winter by managing their cash flow. I expect approximately 90% of farm businesses in Wales to receive their BPS payments on 1 December with the loan facility to be utilised for the remaining 10% of farm businesses where the BPS claims are yet to be validated and unable to be paid.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state what the interest rates will be on the loan facility for farm businesses which do not receive the BPS payment on day one, and state how much finance can be made available to a single business?
answer: Provided an eligible Basic Payment Scheme (BPS) 2018 application has been received, the loan will be calculated and recovered from the BPS payment with no interest charged.  The loan amount will be 70% of a farm businesses BPS claimed value.

However, in an increasingly complicated and modern healthcare system, problems can unfortunately happen. Patient safety in Wales is paramount. When problems do occur, NHS staff are encouraged to report all incidents so they can be investigated openly to promote learning and provide open feedback to patients and their families as part of our commitment to an open safety culture. A high reporting culture can be indicative of such an open patient safety culture

name: Janet Finch-Saunders

question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline why cancer screenings are not granted to those who request them over the age of 75, and what is being done to remedy this?
answer: Eligibility criteria for population screening are based on the latest available evidence. Wales, like the rest of the UK, follows the expert advice of the UK National Screening Committee (UK NSC). The UK NSC does not recommend routine bowel screening over the age of 74 years. Should the UK NSC recommend screening in this age group, the Wales Screening Committee will consider how this could be implemented in Wales.

answer: Services for children with cancer are commissioned by the Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee (WHSSC) on behalf of health boards in Wales. At present access to this therapy for children is only available through a clinical trial at a centre in England. The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) is appraising this therapy and is due to make a recommendation soon.

name: Neil McEvoy
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide information on how the five bimodal trains which the Welsh Government financially contributed to will be used on the Welsh rail network and how much public money was spent on them?
answer: The introduction of the five bimodal (electric/diesel) trains will allow for Persons of Reduced Mobility-compliance works to be undertaken to the existing class 150 and 158 trains and will also provide options for increasing capacity on busy routes.

name: Neil McEvoy
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide an update on progress of the new Environmental Impact Assessment for the proposed biomass incinerator in Barry?
answer: I am considering the need for Environmental Impact Assessment to accompany the planning application currently before Vale of Glamorgan Council and will make my decision shortly.

name: Neil McEvoy
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the recent adverts taken out by Barry Biomass claiming it will begin producing energy in early 2019?
answer: Natural Resources Wales (NRW) granted Biomass UK No 2 Ltd an environmental permit to operate the renewable energy gasification facility. The timing for producing energy at the facility is a matter for the company, NRW and Planning Authority to discuss and agree.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ76948 will the Cabinet Secretary explain when an announcement should be made about Welsh Government enquiries relating to the horizontal launch at Llanbedr airfield, and state how much money has been set aside for matters relating to the project?
answer: Officials continue to engage with the UK Space Agency following the announcement of a new UK Government £2m development fund for potential horizontal launch spaceport sites across Britain to explore further the potential for sub-orbital flight, satellite launch and spaceplane operations. We await further detail expected later in the year, to ascertain how this funding could support space related developments at the Llanbedr site, which forms part of the Snowdonia Enterprise Zone.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state what measures the Welsh Government will take to ensure that Welsh lamb is labelled in supermarkets as being from Wales, and that the origin of meat is clearer on packaging?
answer: Food labelling legislation sets the standards required of food producers to meet its obligation in providing information to the consumer.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Given that Welsh lamb has been served in schools in Rome and is rarely offered here in Wales, what support will be made available to help local authorities ensure that school pupils eat Welsh meat?
answer: The National Procurement Service for Wales (NPS) has set up a number of procurement agreements offering a range of products that can be purchased by its Welsh public sector customers. Purchasing decisions for all products rest with the Welsh public sector organisations who use the agreements.  The agreements have been set up in a way that organisations can request specific products should they wish. This does not impose a requirement on schools which are unable to reach an affordable agreement. I believe this allows schools the greatest degree of flexibility and choice, taking into account the different geographical settings in Wales and individual, regional contexts.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many dental practices offered care through the NHS in each health board in Wales in 2015/16, 2016/17, and 2017/18, and state what measures the Welsh Government is taking to deter practices from closing?
answer: The number of dental practices providing NHS care in calendar years 2015 to 17 is shown in the table below:

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister state whether the Welsh Government have bought or rented the 2 new offices in Germany, how much money has been invested in them so far, and explain how many staff will be there and provide the title of each position accordingly?
answer: The Welsh Government offices in Germany are in the British Embassy in Berlin and the British Consulate General in Dusseldorf

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many pupils the Pupil Development Grant supported in 2016/17, 2017/18, and 2018/19, and explain how it was decided that £125 specifically is to be given to those who qualify?
answer: The Pupil Development Grant (PDG) is made up of a number of elements, providing support to learners eligible for free school meals (eFSM); looked after children; learners who are eFSM and solely registered in education other than at school (EOTAS); and those that are eFSM and in early years provision.  This funding goes directly to schools and other settings, with the exception of funding for looked after children, which is overseen by the four regional education consortia.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary investigate the safety of the A5 and A470 junction near Waterloo Bridge in Betws-y-Coed, and report on the findings?
answer: The last review of speed limits at this location in 2015 recommended consideration is given to reducing the 60mph speed limit on the section of the A5 south of Waterloo Bridge and extending the existing 30 mph through Betws to the bridge itself. The options are being investigated this financial year and changes to the speed limit will be implemented next financial year subject to consultation. The safety of this location will then be kept under review through subsequent speed limit reviews.

name: David Rees
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What funding was given to Excalibur during the steel crisis in 2016 to support its work in developing a proposal to purchase the UK steel operations of TATA, was this funding offered as a grant or a loan or a combination, and what guarantees were sought from Excalibur?
answer: I would refer you to my previous response to your Written Assembly Questions reference 71987 – 71991 on this matter and my subsequent letter to you of 6 November, 2017. Since that response, I can confirm that Tata Steel and Thyssenkrupp have signed a definitive agreement to form a joint venture to combine their European steel businesses. My officials have been advised that as a consequence, Excalibur Steel Ltd is to be wound up.

name: David Rees
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Did the Welsh Government provide any loans to Excalibur to support its development of a proposal to purchase the UK steel-making operations of TATA Steel in 2016/17 and, if so, what guarantees were sought when offering the loan; what conditions were placed on it; what repayment scheme was agreed; and how much has been repaid?
answer: I would refer you to my previous response to your Written Assembly Questions reference 71987 – 71991 on this matter and my subsequent letter to you of 6 November, 2017. Since that response, I can confirm that Tata Steel and Thyssenkrupp have signed a definitive agreement to form a joint venture to combine their European steel businesses. My officials have been advised that as a consequence, Excalibur Steel Ltd is to be wound up.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary had with DEFRA officials following the rebranding of the Food Hall at the Royal Welsh Agricultural show and concerns regarding the effect that it will have on the identity of food from Wales?
answer: DEFRA promotion in the Food Hall was a commercial arrangement between DEFRA and the Royal Welsh Show.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Following DEFRA's decision to rebrand the Food Hall at the Royal Welsh Agricultural Show this year, what steps is the Welsh Government taking to strengthen the identity of Welsh food?
answer: DEFRA advertising in the Food Hall was a commercial arrangement between DEFRA and the Royal Welsh Show.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What arrangements currently exist for patients in Wales to access their medical records digitally and how are these arrangements promoted to patients?
answer: Welsh Government’s digital strategy, ‘Informed Health and Care’, and the recently-published long term plan for health and social care, ‘A Healthier Wales’, both outline Welsh Government’s ambition to use digital services to enable citizens to become more active participants in their own health and well-being.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What arrangements are in place to ensure that patient wishes regarding resuscitation and any other advance directives are appropriately recorded and readily accessible to all health professionals involved in the care of the individual patients concerned?
answer: The End of Life Care Board, in conjunction with the Welsh Government has recently established an Advance Care Planning (ACP) Group in order to provide direction for all aspects of advance care planning in Wales.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What arrangements in place between Wales and other parts of the UK to ensure that patients wishes regarding resuscitation and any other advance directives prior to care or treatment being administered?
answer: In Wales there is a single, consistent approach to recording and sharing patients’ wishes regarding resuscitation based on an all Wales do not attempt cardiopulmonary resuscitation (DNACPR) policy and form. A copy of the completed form, which is a record of the discussions between the patient and clinician, is placed in the front of the patient’s notes and accompanies the patient between care settings. The decision should, however, be regularly reviewed. The recording of the DNACPR status on the digital Individual Patient Record is currently being pursued in order to streamline the administration of the process.  Work is also ongoing to develop an electronic record of advance care plans.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What arrangements are in place to ensure that patient wishes are respected with regards consent to organ donation in the event that relatives do not wish an organ donation to proceed?
answer: The patient’s decision in relation to organ donation is paramount and relatives are always encouraged to accept the decision. Specialist nurses will discuss the matter sensitively with them, including any negative feelings the relative might have about organ donation. Whether to proceed to donation when consent is in place but the relatives object is a judgement for the specialist nurse, taking account of the emotional impact on the relatives and other considerations

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What plans does the Welsh Government have to centrally collect and record the number of NHS vacancies?
answer: Health Education Improvement Wales will work to collect and report on a number of key workforce measures from October 2018. Welsh Government officials will work with Health Education Improvement Wales to put arrangements in place to ensure the accurate collection and publication of NHS Wales vacancy data.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How many and which LHBs have appointed a lead clinician with an established Interstitial Lung Disease clinic?
answer: All health boards, apart from Hywel Dda University and Powys Teaching Health Board, have appointed a lead ILD consultant. Hywel Dda UHB has appointed a specialist nurse who works closely with the tertiary service in Cardiff. Powys does not provide secondary care respiratory medicine. A specialist multi-disciplinary team for south Wales has been established in Cardiff, commissioned by the Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee, to support local management and the treatment of complex patients or where there is diagnostic uncertainty. Patients in north Wales access the specialist service based at Aintree Hospital in Liverpool.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services

answer: All health boards, apart from Hywel Dda University and Powys Teaching Health Board, have appointed a lead ILD consultant.
