A specialist multi-disciplinary team for south Wales has been established in Cardiff, commissioned by the Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee, to support local management and the treatment of complex patients or where there is diagnostic uncertainty. Patients in north Wales access the specialist service based at Aintree Hospital in Liverpool.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What is the mean time to access surgical lung biopsy for Interstitial Lung Disease (ILD) patients, per LHB?
answer: All health boards, apart from Hywel Dda University and Powys Teaching Health Board, have appointed a lead ILD consultant. Hywel Dda UHB has appointed a specialist nurse who works closely with the tertiary service in Cardiff. Powys does not provide secondary care respiratory medicine. A specialist multi-disciplinary team for south Wales has been established in Cardiff, commissioned by the Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee, to support local management and the treatment of complex patients or where there is diagnostic uncertainty. Patients in north Wales access the specialist service based at Aintree Hospital in Liverpool.

name: Mark Isherwood
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What was the total number of eligible patients for a lung biopsy, and the number of patients who underwent a surgical lung biopsy in each LHB, in each year from 2013-2015?
answer: All health boards, apart from Hywel Dda University and Powys Teaching Health Board, have appointed a lead ILD consultant. Hywel Dda UHB has appointed a specialist nurse who works closely with the tertiary service in Cardiff. Powys does not provide secondary care respiratory medicine. A specialist multi-disciplinary team for south Wales has been established in Cardiff, commissioned by the Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee, to support local management and the treatment of complex patients or where there is diagnostic uncertainty. Patients in north Wales access the specialist service based at Aintree Hospital in Liverpool.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What is the reasoning behind the Cabinet Secretary's open letter to farmers on 6 September 2018?
answer: The open letter provided additional clarity on my proposals for agricultural reform set out in the ‘Brexit and Our Land’ consultation, which is open until 30 October.  The letter emphasised the role of the Economic Resilience scheme in providing support for food-producing farmers.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What conversations has the Cabinet Secretary had with officials regarding the issuing of the open letter, and the potential for it to unduly influence the ongoing Welsh Government consultation, 'Brexit and our Land'?
answer: The open letter provided additional clarity on my proposals for agricultural reform set out in the ‘Brexit and Our Land’ consultation, which is open until 30 October.  The letter emphasised the role of the Economic Resilience scheme in providing support for food-producing farmers.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: On which dates and times has the Cabinet Secretary met with farming unions in Wales to specifically address the Welsh Government's ongoing consultation, 'Brexit and our Land'?
answer: The open letter provided additional clarity on my proposals for agricultural reform set out in the ‘Brexit and Our Land’ consultation, which is open until 30 October.  The letter emphasised the role of the Economic Resilience scheme in providing support for food-producing farmers.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm which English language and Welsh language qualifications are required, as well as the expected grades in any qualification, in order to gain access to initial teacher education provision?
answer: For prospective students entering ITE before academic year 2019/20 all providers must ensure that all trainees have achieved a standard equivalent to a grade B in the GCSE examination in English and in mathematics. All providers must ensure that all trainees who enter primary or Key Stages 2/3 training have achieved a standard equivalent to a grade C in the GCSE examination in a science subject.

name: Adam Price
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what standards will be expected in relation to Welsh and English language to enable prospective teachers to gain the status of qualified teacher under the new professional standards for teaching and leadership?
answer: The Welsh Government’s professional standards for teaching and leadership are fundamental for all those in education, providing a strong sense of shared purpose.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: First Minister
question: Will the First Minister outline the agreed parameters and timescale upon which the recent consultation on the future of petroleum extraction in Wales has been undertaken?
answer: The public consultation on Petroleum Extraction in Wales opened on 3 of July and closes on the 25 September 2018.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Further to WAQ76945, are blood test results undertaken outside the UK for Welsh patients concerned about Lyme disease recognised by the Welsh NHS, and what is the Welsh Government doing to help control the number of ticks on agricultural land?
answer: The National Institute for Health and Care Excellence (NICE) guidance on Lyme disease sets out the testing process that should be followed. Tests for Lyme disease should be carried out at laboratories that are accredited by the UK accreditation service (UKAS), use validated tests and participate in a formal external quality assurance programme.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many unsuccessful bids were made by local authorities for Road Safety Capital Funding in 2016/17, 2017/18, and 2018/19, explain how much funding was made available in each financial year, and whether local authorities could be allowed to make more than 3 bids annually?
answer: £4m of Road Safety Capital Funding has been made available each year in 2016/17, 2017/18 and 2018/19 for local authorities to bid for.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement about the inverse care law programme in each of the local health boards in Wales?
answer: Over the last three years, we have invested £0.9million via our Heart Conditions, Stroke and Diabetes Implementation Groups in the rollout and implementation of the Inverse Care Law programme across Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary explain why waiting times for gall bladder operations are currently set at approximately 52 weeks?
answer: Welsh Government waiting times policy is for 95% of people to wait less than 26 weeks from receipt of the referral in the hospital to the start of treatment, including the waiting time for specified diagnostic tests and therapies, with a maximum wait of 36 weeks to allow for clinically complex cases.  For specified diagnostic tests, there is a standard waiting time of eight weeks.  I expect everyone to be treated at the earliest opportunity and in order of their clinical need, which is a decision for the relevant consultant to make, based on the clinical priority of everyone on the waiting list.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What action is the Welsh Government taking to investigate the possibility of enhancing the marine energy industry in the Anglesey demonstration zone and the rest of the North Wales Coast separately, and what marine energy technologies has it invested in so far?
answer: Welsh Government policies have supported the deployment of a range of marine energy technologies and we will continue to work to realise the opportunities associated with this sector. We also recognise the potential of marine energy and this is why we have prioritised the growth of a vibrant energy industry, as a key tool for economic development.   We are currently organising a Marine energy summit which will take place on 6 December in Swansea. This will provide us with a greater understanding of barriers and opportunities for the industry in Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How much of the £1 million investment in the Seafood Market Development project was from the Welsh Government, and what targets have to be met so that the spend is justified?
answer: The total approved value of the Seafood Market Development project is £1,021,727.  The Welsh Government’s contribution is £225,431.75.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many Brexit officers and interns have been recruited and allocated to each Welsh Government department separately?
answer: Staffing matters are the responsibility of the Permanent Secretary. I have asked her to write to you with the information you have requested.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary reconsider the decision not to bring the basic payment date forward, and state whether emergency loans could made available in October to farmers facing fodder problems?
answer: I have introduced a loan scheme to help farmers manage their cash flow and plan their finances in the longer term, especially through the forthcoming winter. This is a better and fairer solution to the difficult circumstances affecting farmers this year. Furthermore, I have made available £500,000 for farming charities to help provide short-term support to the worst affected farmers in Wales.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the fact that the waiting time for urgent elective orthopaedic surgery at Betsi Cadwalader University Health Board is 90 weeks, and explain what immediate measures he will take to reduce this and treat the 100 patients recorded as requiring urgent treatment?
answer: Welsh Government waiting times policy is for 95% of people to wait less than 26 weeks from receipt of the referral in the hospital to the start of treatment, including the waiting time for specified diagnostic tests and therapies, with a maximum wait of 36 weeks to allow for clinically complex cases.  I have made my expectations clear to the Betsi Cadwaladr Board that I expect to see improvements in all waiting times, not just orthopaedics.  Clinical urgency is decided by clinicians and we expect them to work with managers to effectively manage the total demand and resources to meet both clinical and national targets.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on vacancies for school governors, given that these are at their highest since 2004/5, and explain what measures the Welsh Government is taking to encourage more people to put their names forward?
answer: I greatly value all the work governors do to improve educational outcomes for our children and I believe they must get the support they need to be effective in their role. I am aware that there has been an increase of governor vacancies in recent years.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ75948, will the Cabinet Secretary commit to further discussions with Keolis Amey to discuss the future of the Conwy Valley Railway line, and the potential of having improved rail connectivity between Blaenau Ffestiniog and Manchester Airport, and keep Members informed of progress?
answer: Welsh Government and Transport for Wales will continue to keep service development on all lines on the Wales rail network, including Conwy Valley, as a priority. We are pleased with the improvements already planned for North Wales, including increased train services and the retention of access to Manchester Airport. The UK Government has restricted the number of paths available to the Wales and Borders rail service operator between North Wales and Manchester to the current level of 1 train per hour.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Housing and Regeneration
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline what is being done to ensure that individuals receiving DHSS assistance are not negatively discriminated against in the private rental market?
answer: Any discrimination is wholly unacceptable.  If a person claiming welfare benefit support has a protected characteristic specified in the Equality Act 2010, any landlord refusing to rent to them may be breaching Equality law.  We are keeping a close eye on matters in this area.

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: For the most recent academic year, how many medical students have enrolled in Welsh universities and how many of these are Welsh-domiciled students?
answer: The data provided by Cardiff and Swansea Medical Schools for 2018/19 is as follows:

name: Angela Burns
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: How will the Cabinet Secretary ensure that medical staff working in Wales's hospices who are not employed on a NHS contract receive the same competitive pay as NHS workers, as a result of the increase in pay for NHS staff?
answer: I am aware that any lifting of the public sector pay cap will bring its financial challenges and I would expect close collaboration between hospices and health boards to continue to discuss and find ways to avoid negative impact on services.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary or his officials had regarding any community legacy investment for Llanelly Hill, Clydach or Gilwern as a means of recompense for the disruption to the A465 Heads of the Valleys project?
answer: My officials have been in discussions with Monmouthshire CC over a prolonged period to acquire and improve the old CEMEX site in Clydach for future community use. They have also been supporting the Heritage Policy Advisory Group (whose members include the Local Authorities and Brecon Beacons National Park Authority) to deliver a programme of works to enhance key heritage features within the Clydach Gorge.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: What discussions has the Cabinet Secretary had with the South Wales Trunk Road Agency about speeding up the removal of graffiti from its structures?
answer: In line with the requirements of the Welsh Governments’ Trunk Road Maintenance Manual (TRMM), we do not routinely remove graffiti from our structures unless it is considered offensive. Should the graffiti be neither obscene nor offensive, it would not fall under the defect category where it would be removed as soon as practicable.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What risk assessments will the Welsh Government carry out before introducing the proposals in 'Brexit and our land'?
answer: Analysis and modelling is a very important part of the policy development process.  We have included Brexit scenario modelling in the consultation document, but modelling the consequences of policy proposals will not happen until after the consultation has closed.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What detailed economic assessments will the Welsh Government carry out before introducing the proposals in 'Brexit and our land'?
answer: Analysis and modelling is a very important part of the policy development process.  We have included Brexit scenario modelling in the consultation document, but modelling the consequences of policy proposals will not happen until after the consultation has closed.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What evidence does the Welsh Government have to prove that the proposals in 'Brexit and our land' will not be harmful to agriculture and the sustainability of communities in the Welsh countryside?
answer: Analysis and modelling is a very important part of the policy development process.  We have included Brexit scenario modelling in the consultation document, but modelling the consequences of policy proposals will not happen until after the consultation has closed.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the proposals in 'Brexit and our land' are in line with each of the Welsh Government's wellbeing goals?
answer: The proposals in ‘Brexit and Our Land’ were designed in alignment of the Welsh Government’s well-being goals. Chapter 4 of the document covers the principles of the reforms. Figure 5 in this chapter describes how the proposals work towards the principles set out in the Wellbeing of Future Generations Act. Figure 5 makes clear how the proposed future land management program is in line with all the Welsh Government’s wellbeing goals.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how the proposals in 'Brexit and our land' can be reconciled with the Welsh Government's aim of creating a million Welsh speakers by 2050?
answer: The Welsh language is an inseparable part of the social fabric of parts of rural Wales, particularly important in a rural context.  We are committed through the changes proposed in the consultation to keeping farmers on the land, and to working with them to create a better, more prosperous future for their sector.  This approach offers a future for the Welsh Language in rural areas by creating stability and long term viability for these farmers and their families.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What assessment has the Cabinet Secretary made of the Scottish Government document, 'Stability and Simplicity', which says that far-reaching changes to the basic payment scheme for farmers should not be considered until the details of the Brexit deal and its impact on the agricultural industry are clearer?
answer: I have noted the publication of the Scottish Government’s document, ‘Stability and Simplicity,’ with interest. However, I do not agree that its recommendations should form the basis for our policy in Wales at this time.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the timetable for the basic payment scheme following Brexit, and the impact that introducing the public goods scheme by 2021, as well as creating and implementing tens of thousands of other complex agricultural agreements between 2020 and 2025, will have on the timetable?
answer: As I have stated previously, a well-managed transition is important and the ‘Brexit and our land’ consultation seeks views on various aspects including the proposed transition period of 2020 to 2025.  These views will be analysed before further proposals can be developed.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: As regards the two schemes outlined in 'Brexit and our land', what percentage of the funding is allocated to the economic resilience scheme and what percentage is allocated to the public goods scheme payments?
answer: No decision has been made on the balance of funding between the two schemes, particularly because we are still consulting on the principles.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What evidence was the basis for the Welsh Government's decision to proceed urgently with the new economic resilience scheme outlined in 'Brexit and our land'?
answer: We are consulting on high level proposals for the entire scheme. No decisions will be made on scheme design or an implementation timetable until we have consulted again with further details in 2019.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Why will the Welsh Government not waiting until there is more certainty regarding what will replace of the common agricultural policy in the rest of Europe before implementing the plans outlined in 'Brexit and our land'?
answer: I have noted the publication of the Scottish Government’s document, ‘Stability and Simplicity,’ with interest. However, I do not agree that its recommendations should form the basis for our policy in Wales at this time.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether tenants will have the right to change the nature of their businesses and land use to qualify to receive payment from the new public goods scheme?
answer: The nature of a tenancy is a matter to be determined between the tenant and the land owner. I acknowledge a significant proportion of Welsh agricultural land is subject to some form of tenancy, and we are seeking views within the ‘Brexit and our land’ consultation on whether the Welsh Government needs to take action to ensure tenants can access new schemes.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will parameter 2, 'open to all', which is referred to in 'Brexit and our land', include big businesses, forestry businesses and charities that are currently ineligible for basic payments because of the active farmer rule?
answer: We are consulting on each parameter of the public goods scheme.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What assessment has been made of the additional resources that the Welsh Government will need to implement the public goods scheme in comparison with the basic payment scheme?
answer: The integrated impact assessment officials will undertake following the analysis of responses to the current consultation will consider this issue. It will be important to assess resource cost for the delivery of all current schemes will be compared against the resource cost of future proposals.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: What assessment has the Welsh Government made of how many farmers will become bankrupt as a result of the proposals outlined in 'Brexit and our land'?
answer: Analysis and modelling is a very important part of the policy development process.  We have included Brexit scenario modelling in the consultation document, but modelling the consequences of policy proposals will not happen until after the consultation has closed.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether farmers' average incomes will change following the proposals outlined in 'Brexit and our land' compared with the average incomes of farmers in receipt of basic payments?
answer: Analysis and modelling is a very important part of the policy development process.  We have included Brexit scenario modelling in the consultation document, but modelling the consequences of policy proposals will not happen until after the consultation has closed.

name: Adam Price
response_name: First Minister
question: Further to the response to oral question OAQ52604, will the First Minister confirm that the vote following the public inquiry and the statutory orders on the M4 bypass near Newport will be a binding vote?
answer: We have committed to a debate and vote, in government time, on this project once all members have had the opportunity to consider the Inspectors’ report and the decision on the statutory Orders. This debate and vote will be taken into account in final investment decisions on whether to award construction contracts.

name: Mohammad Asghar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement about the availability of the Rezum system for treating patients with benign prostatic hyperplasia in Wales?
answer: Rezum treatment for enlarged prostate has recently been considered as being appropriate for treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia by NICE. NICE have suggested that for certain patients that this treatment may be considered alongside all other available treatments.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Lifelong Learning and Welsh Language
question: How will the extra £1 million investment in the youth engagement and progression framework be spent, and how will the Cabinet Secretary ensure that this represents value for money?
answer: To clarify, the £1 million referenced in the Employability Plan Progress Report is not an additional investment. It is, rather, a continuation of the annual funding we provide to support the delivery of our successful Youth Engagement and Progression Framework (YEPF). This framework represents our coordinated, multiagency approach to supporting young people at risk of becoming NEET (Not in Education, Employment, or Training).

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide a list of the buildings that the Welsh Government is financially liable for repairs and maintenance to, and state how much was spent on maintenance and repairs of these in 2015/16, 2016/17, and 2017/18?
answer: Substantive response

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Why is the Welsh Government pursuing a timed ban on slow vehicles using the A55 when there are no other feasible east-west routes along the north Wales coast, and explain whether implementing specific pull-in lay-bys for slower vehicles would be a feasible alternative?
answer: My officials are currently investigating whether there is a need to prohibit slow moving vehicles on the A55, in its entirety or on part lengths, this is because slow moving vehicles have been involved in serious collisions on the A55 and can also cause flow breakdown.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Why has the Welsh Government decided to invest £4 million in transforming eye care services across Wales when it is unclear how the money will be allocated, and will the Cabinet Secretary clarify what the target waiting time for treatment after referral will be for eye care patients?
answer: The Welsh Government, the Planned Care Programme, NHS Wales and the RNIB have been working together to support the implementation and shadow reporting of a new outcome measure for all eye care patients. Health boards will be required to implement the new outcome measure from September 2018, along with the existing referral to treatment target.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ77095, what consideration has been given to establishing a temporary train station to give direct access to the proposed location of the National Eisteddfod and help reduce pressure on pavements and roads?
answer: Temporary stations can be created and are most often used in emergency situations.  A number of factors including planning, regulatory and other issues as well as cost need to be assessed when considering the feasibility of such stations. Transport for Wales will explore a range of options such as increasing service frequency and the provision of shuttle buses in relation to the National Eisteddfod.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Given that £58 million will be used to rent Conwy County Borough Council’s Coed Pella offices, why does this building which is rented by the public have repair bills not covered by a builders’ warranty?
answer: This is a matter for Conwy County Borough Council.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Given that the number of prescriptions in Wales has increased by 17.9 million since 2007-08, will the Cabinet Secretary undertake a review of universal free prescription with the aim of introducing a nominal charge for those who can afford to pay?
answer: I will not be undertaking a review of this policy.  Providing people with the medication they need helps to keep them well and out of hospital, thereby reducing the overall cost to the NHS. Our decision to abolish prescription charges was based on evidence which showed some people with serious chronic conditions could not afford to collect their prescriptions, and some would choose to have only part of a prescription to reduce the amount of prescription charges they had to pay.

name: Suzy Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Following reports that there are financial implications when changing the Cwm Taf Health Board boundary to include Bridgend, has the Welsh Government worked to ascertain the level of these implications and what they are, and how much money has the Welsh Government given to assist these changes?
answer: The Welsh Government has confirmed funding of up to £2.9m to meet the transitional costs of the transfer for Abertawe Bro-Morgannwg University Health Board and Cwm Taf University Health Board in 2018-19.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How many chronically infected/persistently infected herds were there in Wales when the Welsh Government’s refreshed TB policies were implemented and how many are there now?
answer: There were 69 persistent TB breakdown herds (those which are under movement restrictions for more than 18 months) in October 2017 when I introduced the refreshed TB Eradication Programme. As of August 2018 there were 80 persistent breakdown herds. This is an ever changing picture as every month persistent breakdown herds come off restrictions and new ones are added.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How many TB action plans have been drafted and implemented since the introduction of the new refreshed policy?
answer: In relation to currently ongoing persistent TB breakdowns, 62 Action Plans have been drafted, of which 50 have been discussed with the keeper and actions have been implemented.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How many TB action plans are there where infection from wildlife is noted as a likely or a possible driver of the disease?
answer: In August 2018, 80 persistent breakdown herds had been identified of which 78 had wildlife identified, this is an ever changing picture as every month persistent breakdown herds come off restrictions and new ones are added.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Of the TB action plans which note wildlife as a likely or possible driver of disease, how many have had any action taken in terms of (a) being selected for additional monitoring/surveillance of badger activity or (b) being selected for trapping, testing and culling/release of badgers?
answer: a)    All persistent herds in Wales are eligible for surveillance activity in relational to wildlife if it has been identified as a possible disease pathway, in addition, Welsh Government have been collecting dead badgers pan Wales to monitor the disease status in the badger population.

name: Sian Gwenllian

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the total rural development plan budget allocation to the Farming Connect programme during the current programming period?
answer: The Rural Development Plan budget allocated to Farming Connect for the current programme period is £27,750,295. In total, £13,664,376 has been paid to date.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm rural development programme funds spent to date on the Farming Connect programme as well as the funds committed for the remainder of the RDP programming period?
answer: The Rural Development Plan budget allocated to Farming Connect for the current programme period is £27,750,295. In total, £13,664,376 has been paid to date.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm the number of individual farm businesses the Farming Connect programme has supported to date during the current rural development programme programming period?
answer: Since the beginning of the programme in October 2015, Farming Connect has supported 9,217 businesses, equating to 18,322 individuals.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm whether the independent evaluation of the Farming Connect programme during the 2007-2013 programming period is in the public domain?
answer: Commissioned by Menter a Busnes as part of the Farming Connect contract with that company,  the final evaluation report for the Farming Connect programme period 2011-2015 was published in March 2017. The report can be accessed at the following link: https://gov.wales/funding/eu-funds/previous/project-evaluations/farming-connect-evaluation/?lang=en

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm how many full time equivalent staff are employed on the Farming Connect programme in total?
answer: 6 staff within the Welsh Government are involved full time in the delivery of Farming Connect. 60 people are employed by the two (external to Welsh Government) Farming Connect delivery agents.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm what has been done by Welsh Government to take forward the development of Brand Wales and how much funding has been allocated to the concept development to date?
answer: The award-winning Cymru Wales brand was launched in 2016. The brand was developed in response to Welsh Government’s ambitions and ongoing calls from industry for a more consistent approach to selling Wales to the world. The approach is used to promote Wales internationally as a place to visit, trade, invest and live and does not replace the Welsh Government’s corporate brand.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on the availability of micro-processor knees on the Welsh NHS?
answer: NHS Prosthetic and Amputee Rehabilitation services are commissioned by the Welsh Health Specialised Services Committee (WHSSC) and delivered by three specialist Artificial Limb and Appliance Centres across Wales. NHS Wales does not provide microprocessor knees for civilians; however, they are available to war veterans in line with the criteria set out in the WHSSC War Veterans Enhanced Prosthetic Provision Commissioning Policy.

name: Llyr Gruffydd
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary for provide an update on her discussions with DEFRA regarding the future of the EU school milk subsidy scheme post-Brexit?
answer: The engagement structures that have been established between DEFRA and the devolved administrations include regular quadrilateral Ministerial meetings attended by the Environment and Rural Affairs Ministers across the UK. The Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs represents the Welsh Government in these discussions, including where the legislation involves cross-portfolio issues.

name: Sian Gwenllian
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will it be possible for students to apply this year, 2018, to study for an undergraduate degree in medicine in Bangor from 2019 onwards?
answer: The Health Secretary issued a Written Statement in July which provided an update on our work to expand medical education across Wales.  It explained our expectation that, by 2019, arrangements will be in place to enable students to undertake their medical degrees in north Wales.   This will be achieved through close collaboration between Cardiff and Bangor Universities who are working together to take this important work forward.  They are currently in the process of appointing a project manager to oversee progress and officials will be monitoring progress regularly to ensure we deliver on our plans.

name: Nick Ramsay
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: What were the benefits to Wales of the attendance of board members and employees of the Education Workforce Council at the 2016 and 2018 International Forum of Teaching Regulatory Authorities Conferences in Dublin and New Zealand?
answer: The Education Workforce Council (EWC) was established under the Education (Wales) Act 2014 as an independent professional regulatory body and as such it is not funded by the Welsh Government. The decision for members of the Council and its employees to attend the biennial International Forum of Teaching Regulatory Authorities conferences in 2016 and 2018 was agreed by the body’s Council and the outcomes reported to it.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary provide information on the recruitment of three neuromuscular assistant family care advisor posts?
answer: Via the Neurological Conditions Delivery plan, the Welsh Government has provided additional funding to support these roles. The Welsh Neuromuscular Network is collaborating with Cardiff and Vale University Health Board to progress these posts across the three regional services. We anticipate they will be advertised in November 2018.

name: Bethan Sayed
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline how her department encourages business and entrepreneurship in the school curriculum, particularly in further education?
answer: Through the Economic Action Plan, the Welsh Government is committed to developing an entrepreneurial culture in Wales; this provides a particular focus on developing youth entrepreneurship, working with young people under 25 in schools, colleges and universities.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Since 2007, what is the longest period of time between a proposal to close a school being referred to Welsh Ministers and Welsh Ministers issuing a decision?
answer: Since 2007, 73 proposals to close schools were referred to the Welsh Ministers for determination.  Of these 67 were approved 5 were rejected and one is awaiting a decision.

question: How many proposals to close schools have been referred to Welsh Ministers since 2007 and what decision was issued by Welsh Ministers in each case?
answer: Since 2007, 73 proposals to close schools were referred to the Welsh Ministers for determination.  Of these 67 were approved 5 were rejected and one is awaiting a decision.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: How many of the proposals to close schools that have been referred to Welsh Ministers are still awaiting a decision by Welsh Ministers and how much time has elapsed since the referral was made?
answer: Since 2007, 73 proposals to close schools were referred to the Welsh Ministers for determination.  Of these 67 were approved 5 were rejected and one is awaiting a decision.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ76944, will the Cabinet Secretary provide a copy of the report, state what action will be taken to address the parking problems, and whether parking signs can be erected stopping overnight parking?
answer: The report is currently under review pending final completion. I will ensure a copy of the report is forwarded to the Assembly Member when the final version is agreed. The report will consider numerous options to deal with the parking problems. Before a decision is to be taken on the way forward further consultation with various stakeholders will be required. Any proposed work will be competing for funding against similar work across the country. Overnight parking has not been considered in the report as this has not previously been raised as an issue, however, officials will investigate before taking further action.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Minister for Environment
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary outline the cost of Assembly expenditure on plastic materials used for marketing purposes, detailing the amount spent for each of the three previous financial years?
answer: This is a matter for the Assembly Commission, not Welsh Government.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ77105, will the Cabinet Secretary clarify whether there will be a public consultation on the preferred options for the the A55 Junctions 15 and 16 improvement scheme and an opportunity for the communities affected to reject or accept the options?
answer: Once I have made a decision on the preferred options for Junctions 15 and 16, my officials will arrange public information exhibitions to display and invite comments on the selected options and to explain the next stages of the scheme development. The next stage will involve developing the design in more detail taking into account comments received by stakeholders and the preparation and an Environmental Statement and draft Orders. The Environmental Statement and draft Orders are programmed to be published in the autumn of 2019 and there will be an opportunity at this stage for all stakeholders to support or object the proposals. Depending on the nature of the objections, a Public Local Inquiry may be required where an independent inspector will hear evidence from the any objectors and Welsh Government before making a recommendation to Ministers on whether the scheme should progress onto construction.

name: Lynne Neagle
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: When does the Cabinet Secretary expect to begin the review of the School Admissions Code?
answer: I have made a commitment to commence a review of the School admission code towards the end of this year.

name: Darren Millar
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What action is the Welsh Government taking to build capacity and develop mental health services provided by the third sector in North Wales to support the improvement of those services in the region?
answer: The Together for Mental Health strategy, published in 2012, recognises the importance of delivering a well-designed, fully integrated network of care and specifically references the role that the third sector has in the delivery of services. This is also emphasised in the actions laid out in the 2016-19 delivery plan supporting the strategy. To ensure that progress is maintained in the delivery of the strategy a National Partnership Board has been established which includes third sector representation. Local Partnership Boards have also been established which mirror these arrangements at a local level.

name: David Melding
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: What assessment has been made on the prevalence of foetal alcohol syndrome in Wales, and will the Cabinet Secretary make a statement on it?
answer: Alcohol use in pregnancy is one of the key elements that maternity services address as a public health issue.  All of our health boards now utilise the ‘No Alcohol, no risk’ concept in pregnancy and all women are asked about alcohol intake at the beginning of pregnancy and advised of risks.  Midwives have been widely trained in brief intervention training such as ‘Making every contact count’ (MECC) and substance misuse specialist midwives provide support for any women with alcohol dependence.

name: Rhun ap Iorwerth
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Health and Social Services
question: Further to WAQ77149, will the Cabinet Secretary outline how the inverse care law programme is progressing in Betsi Cadwaladr and Abertawe Bro Morgannwg health boards, including the number of staff employed through the programme in each health board and if the schemes are currently fully operational?
answer: Following the three years of investment via our Heart Conditions, Stroke and Diabetes Implementation Groups, health boards have been continuing to apply the learning from the inverse care law pilots in Aneurin Bevan and Cwm Taf University Health Boards. In doing so they are helping to mainstream the principles of the programme locally, including through their Integrated Medium Term Plans.

name: Russell George
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary confirm that the new rail franchise will continue to offer the use of concessionary bus travel passes for rail travel on the Cambrian Line from Machynlleth to Pwllheli from October to March 2019?
answer: The current concessionary fare rail scheme will be continued into future years under TfW Rail Services from October to March and be operational on the Cambrian Coast and the Heart of Wales Lines.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: Given that 19 of the 25 local planning authorities cannot meet the Welsh Government’s requirement for there to be a five-year supply of housing land, how long will the temporary removal of paragraph 6.2 last?
answer: A decision about whether or not to reinstate paragraph 6.2 of TAN 1 will be made as part of the full review of the delivery of housing through the planning system which I launched on 18 July with a ‘call for evidence’.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: As there is a need to provide more housing land, will the Cabinet Secretary clarify how long will it take for recommendations from the current call for evidence due to end on 10 October to be published and implemented?
answer: As set out in my Written Statement on 18 July, the ‘call for evidence’ is the initial part of the wide-ranging review into the delivery of housing through the planning system. The aim of the ‘call for evidence’ is to identify ways the planning system can assist in increasing the delivery of new homes in sustainable locations. I will decide how to take the review forward based on the responses from stakeholders to the ‘call for evidence’.

name: Andrew R.T. Davies
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: As housing completions are not meeting the identified requirements in local development plans, what measures does the Welsh Government currently have to penalise those local planning authorities who are not making good progress in producing their LDP reviews and what additional measures might be considered following the current review?
answer: Local Planning Authorities must review their adopted LDPs at intervals no longer than 4 years from the date of adoption. On the 29 March I wrote to Authorities who had triggered plan review setting out how LDP preparation should be achieved within 3.5 years. The Delivery Agreements submitted to date confirm plan reviews will be completed within this timeframe. I have invited evidence on appropriate measures as part of the ‘call for evidence’ which has not yet concluded.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Energy, Planning and Rural Affairs
question: How much money has been invested in creating the new app for Welsh food and drink businesses post-Brexit, and how many enterprises is the Cabinet Secretary expecting to join each of the seven clusters in 2018-19 and 2019-20?
answer: The investment in creating a new on-line app was based on business and retail needs identified in discussions with food chain businesses as they prepare for Brexit. The total cost to develop the app was £70,000, which included piloting with businesses in Wales. The app will be rolled out this month. The app operates across the industry and offers a total supply chain response to Brexit preparedness.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Education
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how many pupils are studying biology, chemistry and physics in 2018/19, and explain by how many this should increase following the £8.2 million investment in STEM subjects?
answer: The recently announced £8.2m Trio Sci Cymru programme represents a joint EU and Welsh Government strategic investment.

answer: The Minister for Welsh Language and Lifelong Learning recently announced a £46 million investment via the Welsh-medium and Childcare Offer Capital Grants to support growth in Welsh-medium education.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Economy and Transport
question: Further to WAQ77126, why has the Cabinet Secretary not yet acted on and implemented the recommendations of the report undertaken three years ago, and can the Welsh Government have the speed limits changed during this financial year?
answer: The Speed Limit Review I referred to in my earlier response recommended consideration be given to a reduction in the speed limit on the section of A5 south of Waterloo Bridge (50 & 40 mph to be considered) and the existing 30mph through Betws to be extended to include the bridge itself. This is on the programme for delivery in 2019/20. My officials will arrange for a study to be undertaken to consider the options this year so we can deliver as soon as possible in the next financial year.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Further to WAQ76808, will the Cabinet Secretary explain why the builders of the offices did not register for a warranty with the National House-Building Council, clarify whether any other warranty was arranged, and provide a copy of the contract signed by the builders?
answer: A National House-Building Council warranty is for residential homes and not relevant. The contract for the construction of Welsh Government’s offices in Llandudno Junction included the standard construction ‘defects liability period’ of 12 months during which the contractor retained liability for dealing with any defects. Welsh Government’s rights in respect of ‘latent defects’ would also have been protected covering any inherent defects in design, materials or workmanship which existed but were not apparent on completion of the building works.

name: Janet Finch-Saunders
response_name: Cabinet Secretary for Finance
question: Will the Cabinet Secretary state how the additional £50 million for social care in 2019-20 will be allocated, and whether some will go towards promoting joint-working between health boards and social services departments?
answer: Chapter four of the outline draft budget narrative provides an account of how the additional £50m for social care in 2019-20 will be allocated: £20m will be allocated via the local government revenue support grant; and £30m will be targeted funding for social care via a special grant in line with A Healthier Wales: our Plan for Health and Social Care.
